
Proceedings of the Board of Regents
July 1991 - June 1992
The University of Michigan




JULY MEETING, 1991


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, July 18, 1991
The Regents met at 1:00 PM. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Smith, and Varner.
Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, and Vice Presidents
Cosovich, Johnson, Kelly, Swain, and Womack were also present, as were Chancellors Jones and Wilson. Regent Waters arrived at about 1:25 P.M.; Regent
Baker arrived at 1:55 P.M.
Further Diversification of Endowment Assets; Common Stock Management of
University Endowment Fund; Alternative Fixed Income Investments
President Duderstadt called on Vice President Womack to introduce the discussion of proposed modifications to investments and management of the University Endowment Fund. Vice President Womack introduced Mr. David
Thurston of Cambridge Associates, the University's investment consultant.
Mr. Thurston explained that the action requests are a continuation of the
strategies that the Regents had adopted previously. He distributed a handout
summarizing these goals as maintaining a high equity exposure of 70 percent, diversifying into alternative equity assets (10 percent real estate, 5 percent venture
capital, and 5 percent oil and gas), averaging into alternative equity assets, and
hedging the common stock portfolio with a strategic asset allocation program
which will be discontinued when the endowment is more diversified in both
equity assets and common stock.
Mr. Thurston noted that the current commitment to venture capital is 1.1
percent. The recommended investment of $5 million in Advent Atlantic and Pacific II will increase the venture capital commitment to 2.0 percent.
Consistent with the endowment strategy of maintaining the "value" emphasis
and replacing underperforming managers, the next recommendation was the appointment of Grantham, Mayo, Van Otterloo & Co. (GMO) as a common stock
manager. Mr. Thurston displayed analyses showing that GMO had outperformed
Fidelity Management Trust Company over a ten-year period with an equivalent
risk. He pointed out that other common stock management goals of maintaining
a small capitalization emphasis and diversifying by averaging into foreign stocks
were underway, while adding growth stocks had not yet occurred.
Mr. Thurston noted that Regent Smith had suggested that fixed income investments might be another focus of the investment strategy, and that he agreed
that this was a sound idea. The recommended method to start this strategy is to
expand the 2.5 percent alternative fixed income investments to 5.0 percent and to
commit $3 million to WHR Workout Fund II, managed by Whitman, Heffernan
& Rhein.
Further Diversification of Endowment Assets. Following some discussion,
Regent Varner moved that $5 million be committed to Advent Atlantic and
Pacific II (venture capital fund). Regent Nielsen seconded the motion, and it was




July Meeting, 1991


approved, with Regents Brown, Nielsen, Power, McFee, and Varner in favor and
Regent Smith abstaining. Regents Waters and Baker were absent.
Common Stock Management of the University Endowment Fund. On a
motion by Regent Nielsen, seconded by Regent McFee, the Regents unanimously
approved the appointment of Grantham, Mayo, Van Otterloo & Co. as an
investment manager for the University Endowment Fund.
Alternative Fixed Income Investments. Regent Nielsen moved, Regent
Power seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved the following: that the
0.0 - 2.5 percent allocation to reorganization investments be increased and
broadened to a 0.0 - 5.0 percent allocation to alternative fixed income investments, and that $3 million be committed to the WHR Workout Fund II.
Francois-Xavier Bagnoud Building for Aerospace Engineering and Space Physics
Research Laboratory Addition (Engineering College Projects Student Fee
Bonds, Series 1991)
The Regents were informed in a communication in the regular agenda that
bids for the purchase of the Engineering College Projects Student Fee Bonds,
Series 1991, had been received on July 17, 1991.
Financing for Engineering College Projects Student Fee Bonds, Series 1991
Vice President Womack announced that Merrill Lynch & Company had submitted the low bid to purchase the Engineering College Projects Student Fee
Bonds, Series 1991.
Regent Waters arrived at the meeting at 1:25 P.M.
Following some discussion, Regent McFee moved that the Regents adopt
and incorporate into the minutes of this meeting the resolution which authorizes
the issuance, sale, and delivery of the $8,100,000 Engineering Projects Student
Fee Bonds, Series 1991, to Merrill Lynch. Regent Nielsen seconded the motion,
and it was adopted unanimously. The text of the resolution can be found in the
appendix following these minutes.
Minutes
Regent Waters moved, Regent Varner seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved, the minutes of the meeting of May 16-17, 1991. On a motion
by Regent Varner, seconded by Regent Waters, the Regents unanimously approved the minutes of the meeting of June 13, 1991.
Reports
Vice President Womack submitted reports of Investment Transactions, Plant
Extension, Litigation, Personnel-Labor Relations, and a quarterly report of NonCompetitive Purchases Over $2,000.

Regent Power seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Gifts and Grants
Vice President Cosovich reported that the final report of 1990-91 fiscal-year
gift receipts, including totals for the month of June, would be reported in September. He distributed a handout of summary figures, and President Duderstadt
noted that there was a 13.5 percent increase in the amount of gifts received in
1990-91 compared to 1989-90.
Personnel Actions
On a motion by Regent Power, seconded by Regent Nielsen, the Regents
unanimously approved the following personnel actions:

Retirement Memoirs
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Nielsen, the Regents
unanimously adopted the following retirement memoirs:
Mathew Alpern, professor of physiological optics in the Departments of Ophthalmology and Physiology in the Medical School, and professor of psychology in
the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, will retire from    active faculty
status on June 30, 1991.
Born and raised in Akron, Ohio, Professor Alpern earned his O.D. degree in
1941 from Northern Illinois College of Optometry. After spending a brief period
of time in private optometry practice, he joined the U.S. Army, serving from
1942-46. He received his B.M.E. degree from the University of Florida in 1944,


-10 -



July Meeting 191


and his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in physiological optics from The Ohio State University in 1948 and 1950, respectively.
Having worked prodigiously for nearly 50 years in the field of visual science,
Professor Alpern began his academic career in 1951 as an assistant professor of
optometry at Pacific University in Forest Grove, Oregon. He joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1955 as an instructor in ophthalmology and research
associate in the Vision Research Laboratory. He was promoted to assistant professor in 1956 and associate professor in 1958. He received additional appointments as associate professor of psychology in 1959 and associate professor of
physiology in 1960. In 1963, he was promoted to his present positions as professor of physiological optics in the Departments of Ophthalmology and Physiology
and professor of psychology in the Department of Psychology. A gifted scientist
and educator, Professor Alpern is one of the world's foremost experts on color
vision. He has made significant contributions to our understanding of the mechanisms of vision and his work has had, and will continue to have, a major impact
on vision research.
Over the years, Professor Alpern has received numerous awards, including
the Jonas Stein Friedenwald Award from the Association for Research in Vision
and Ophthalmology, the Edgar D. Tillyer Medal of the Optical Society of America, the Research to Prevent Blindness Senior Scientific Investigator Award, the
Charles F. Prentice Medal, and an Honorary Doctor of Science degree from the
State University of New York, College of Optometry, Manhattan. In 1991, Professor Alpern was elected to the  ational Academy of Sciences. He has just
completed his retirement furlough at Technion-Israel Institute of Technology in
H ia, Israel.
The Regents now salute this distinguished scholar, educator, and researcher
for his dedicated service by naming Mathew Alpern Professor Emeritus of Physiological Optics and Professor Emeritus of Psychology.
Samuel H. Barnes, professor of political science in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts and research scientist in the Center for Political Studies, Institute for Social Research, retired from active faculty status on June 30, 1991,
after a career of scholarship and teaching at the University of Michigan that has
lasted 34 years.
A native of Mississippi, Professor Barnes received his B.A. and M.A. degrees
from Tulane University min 1952 and 1954, respectively, and his Ph.D. degree from
Duke University in 1957. He has held visiting appointments at the Umniversity of
Florence, the University of Rome, and the University of Calabria. He was a
fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences and a visiting
scholar at the Hoover Institution.
Professor Barnes came to the University of Michigan as an instructor in 1957.
He was promoted to assistant professor in 1960, associate professor in 1964, and
professor in 1968. He began his affiliation with the Center for Political Studies at
the Institute for Social Research in 1970 as a research associate, and was named
research scientist in 1974. Professor Barnes served as program director at the
Center for Political Studies from 1970-74 and chair of the Department of Political Science from 1977-82. He has also served as president of the Research Club,
on the executive committee of the Institute for Public Policy Studies, and the executive board of the Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies. His service to the University has always been marked by his dedication to the development of a vigorous academic community.


-11 -



July Meeting 1991


Professor Barnes' research has focused on party organization, political representation, the transition to democracy, and the comparative analysis of political
action. The guiding thread that unifies his large body of work is the relationship
between political participation and democratic government. From his early pioneering work on local party leaders and followers in Italy to his more recent comparative work on political action, his central concern has been to enlarge our understanding of the conditions and consequences of citizens' participation in the
political process.
The Regents now salute this distinguished political scientist for his dedicated
service by naming Samuel H. Barnes Professor Emeritus of Political Science and
Research Scientist Emeritus.
Charles B. Beck, professor of botany in the Department of Biology, professor
of paleobotany in the Department of Geological Sciences, and curator in the
Museum of Paleontology, will retire from active faculty status on August 31,
1991, following 35 years of service.
After serving in the U.S. Army from 1944-46, Professor Beck received his
BA degree from the University of Richmond, in Virginia, in 1950. He then entered Cornell University, where he completed his M.S. degree in 1952 and his
Ph.D. degree in 1955 under the guidance of Harlan Banks, a well-known paleobotanist and botany teacher.
Professor Beck came to the University of Michigan as an instructor in the
Department of Botany in 1956; he was promoted to assistant professor in 1957,
associate professor in 1960, and professor in 1965. In addition to teaching
courses in general botany, vascular-plant anatomy, and paleobotany, he was
active in departmental affairs, serving as chair of the department from 1971-75.
Professor Beck was appointed curator of plant fossils in the Museum of Paleontology in 1980 and served as director of the museum from 1987-89.
Professor Beck has contributed significantly to the understanding of the morphology, anatomy, and evolutionary ongin of seed plants. In 1960, he discovered
that the Devonian fossils Archaeopteris, long believed to be an ancient fern, and
Callixylon, woody fragments previously thought to belong to a large conifer-like
tree, were parts of the same ancient plant. For this plant and others like it, called
seed ferns, he proposed the class Progymnospermopsida, which is now accepted as
the ancestral group from which all other seed plants evolved. More recently, his
work has analyzed the possible relationships of this group with both cycads and
conifers. In collaboration with several colleagues, Professor Beck also studied
the morphology of Archaeosperma, one of the earliest known seeds; redefined the
basic homologies of the plant vascular system; and analyzed extensively the anatomy of seed ferns.
Recognition of Professor Beck's scholarship has come in the form of, among
other things, research funding from the National Science Foundation, appointive
offices in the Botanical Society of America, corresponding membership in the
Chinese Botanical Society, and the presidency of the International Organization
of Paleobotany (1987-93).
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his distinguished contributions by naming Charles B. Beck Professor Emeritus of Botany, Professor Emeritus of Paleobotany, and Curator Emeritus.
Lee E. Danielson, professor of human resource management in the School of
Business Administration, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1991.


-12 -



July Meeting, 1991


Professor Danielson received his B.S. degree from Antioch College in 1947
and his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1949 and
1956, respectively. He joined the School of Business Administration faculty in
1953 as an instructor; he was promoted to assistant professor in 1956, associate
professor in 1959, and professor in 1964. From 1958-59, he served as assistant to
the dean.
Professor Danielson has served the school with distinction and dedication
throughout his career. He has been held in high regard as a teacher, both in
classroom settings and in the numerous seminars he conducts. He has been a
loyal and supportive colleague in his department and the School of Business Administration, including having served on the school's executive committee. He
has also been a good citizen of the University, having served on the advisory committee of the Institute for the Study of Mental Retardation, on the University
Hospital personnel services review committee, and on the financial affairs committee of the Senate Assembly.
Professor Danielson will be missed as a friend, teacher, and colleague, and
the faculty and staff of the School of Business Administration wish him a long
and happy retirement.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Lee E. Danielson
Professor Emeritus of Human Resource Management.
Allen Menlo, professor of education, retired from active faculty status on
May 31, 1991, after 39 years of service to the University of Michigan.
Professor Menlo received his B.S. and M.A. degrees in 1947 and 1948, respectively, from Wayne State University. He came to the University of Michigan
as a research assistant in community adult education in 1950 and a teaching
fellow in educational psychology in 1951, while pursuing his Ph.D. degree. He
was appointed instructor in 1955, completed his Ph.D. degree in 1956, and was
promoted to assistant professor in 1959, associate professor in 1964, and professor in 1969. His work has been diverse, dealing with such areas as educational
psychology; interpersonal, group and organization development; group decision
making; organizational change; leadership; utilizing behavior science knowledge;
and cross-cultural comparative studies of teachers' perceptions, attitudes, and
thinking.
An exceptional teacher, Professor Menlo's concern for collegial collaboration
and his genuine positive regard for all his students have served as a model. His
teaching has been consistently student-centered and has resulted in an enduring
network of former students devoted to him for his concern and his interest in
their learning and growth. In the late 1960s, Professor Menlo developed the Interpersonal Process Program, which became the largest graduate program area in
educational psychology at the University of Michigan.
Professor Menlo has been involved in a number of professional organizations, and has held leadership posts in the American Educational Research Association and the Society for Cross-Cultural Research. He has also served on the
editorial boards of Behavior Science Research, Journal of Worldwide Comparative
Studies, and The Adult Educational Quarterly: A Journal of Research and Theory.
A major theme in Professor Menlo's work has been his commitment to collaborative participation, and he has consulted broadly, both nationally and internationally, on organizational change. In recognition of his excellence in teaching, his
creative approaches in human relations, and his research on the social perceptions of teachers, Professor Menlo has received awards from the Danforth Foundation, the Phi Delta Kappa International Education Organization, the Adult


-13 -



July Meeting, 1991


Education Associations of both Michigan and the United States, the Michigan
Corrections Department, the World Health Organization, and the German Academic Exchange Office. In 1981, Professor Menlo founded the Consortium for
Cross-Cultural Research in Education, which has grown into a partnership of university research teams in 12 countries that collaborate in the planning and conducting of comparative studies of teachers and teaching. He will contue to coordinate the consortium and direct the Michigan research team after his retirement.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Allen
Menlo Professor Emeritus of Education.
Alfred C. Raphelson, professor of psychology at the University of MichiganFlint, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1991, after a a legendary career
as a teacher, mentor, and scholar.
Professor Raphelson received his aB. de e i 1950, his AM. degree in
1951, and his Ph.D. degree in 1956, all from the University of Michigan. He
joined the faculty at what was then known as Flint College in 1956 as an assistant
professor. He was promoted to associate professor in 1960 and professor in 1965.
As one   thfounding members of the Flint faculty, Professor Raphelson
has defined the institutional standard of teaching excellence with his superb
teaching and personal concern for each student. In the 34 years since the founding of UM-Fhnt, no single faculty member has exerted so much influence on the
teaching goals and instructional philosophy of the institution. For hundreds of
former students, the high point of their undergraduate life was their interaction
with Professor Raphelson.
Professor Raphelson's broad interests as a scholar and researcher are reflected in his numerous publications on human motivation, animal behavior, and
the history of psychology. Of special significance to him was his two-volume
work, Psychology at the University of Michigan, which traces the history of the University of Michigan psychology department from 1852-1950.
More than any other faculty member, Professor Raphelson has influenced
the planning and direction of the Flint campus. He served on the Haber Commission, which successfully recommended campus rather than college status for
UM-Flint. He was also a key member of the search committee for the first chancellor, and he played a central part in each campus-wide academic planning
effort. In 1989, he served as the Flint representative on the University faculty
committee for the presidential search.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his dedicated
service by naming Alfred C. Raphelson Professor Emeritus of Psychology.

An Ordinance to Regulate Parking and Traffic, and to Regulate the Use and Protection of the Buildings and Property of the Regents of the University of Michigan
Vice President Womack said that the purpose of the ordinance is to establish
a comprehensive set of ordinances and to make the University's practices consistent, to the extent possible, with those of the city of Ann Arbor. He pointed out
that the Regents had previously adopted chapters 119, 126, and 127 of the city's
ordinances, and that these were included by reference in the proposed ordinance.
He said that each of the articles in the ordinance had been reviewed by the
Safety Committee and by the executive officers, except that Article VIII, having
to do with skateboards, had not been reviewed by the Safety Committee. This article had been included because of the executive officers' concern with the
damage being done by skateboards. He noted that the operation of skateboards,
rollerskates, and rollerblades was only prohibited on property that was posted to
prohibit it; the intent was not to ban them from campus.
Regent Nielsen suggested that the text of Ann Arbor ordinances referred to
as being adopted in the Regents' ordinance be included as part of the language of
the Regents' ordinance, rather than incorporated by reference. He also expressed reservations about the proposed language that refers to the Ann Arbor
ordinance "as amended from time to time". Vice President Womack responded
that the phrase "as amended from time to time" could be struck whenever it
occurs. Thus, whenever the University wished to adopt amendments passed by
the city of Ann Arbor, it would propose the amendments to the Regents for
adoption.


-15 -



July Meeting, 1991


In response to other questions raised by Regent Nielsen, Vice President
Womack suggested that Regent Nielsen confer with Mr. John Ketelhut, deputy
general counsel, who is familiar with the legal issues involved.
Regent Baker arrived at the meeting at 1:55 P.M. He commented on the
damage that has been done by skateboards on the Ingalls Mall. Regent Baker
also commented that provisions against yelling on University buses might impinge on free speech rights.
President Duderstadt reiterated that the regulations pertaining to skateboards, rollerblades, and rollerskates only applied to areas that would be posted;
there would not be a campus-wide ban of those items. Because people had
signed up to speak during the public comments session about this action, the vote
would be delayed until the next day.
FY1991-92 Ann Arbor General Fund Operating Budget and Student Fee Rates
President Duderstadt called on Provost Whitaker to present the FY1991-92
General Fund Operating Budget for the Ann Arbor campus. Provost Whitaker
began by reviewing the budget preparation timeline. He noted that because the
legislature had not yet acted on its 1991-92 budget, assumptions have been used
in planning the general fund budget.
Provost Whitaker noted that last October the University had requested an
8.5 percent increase ($21.6 million) in state appropriation as part of a multi-year
plan to bring the state back into the top one-third of states in terms of support of
higher education. Since then, the state had reduced the 1990-91 appropriation by
1.0 percent, $3.4 million in special maintenance funding had been rolled back,
the remaiing FY1990-91 payments ($25 million) had been deferred, and the
projected net increase in state appropriation for FY1991-92 had been determined
to be only 3.7 percent over the previous year, or $12.3 million less than the request.
To deal with this situation, Provost Whitaker reported that the following actions would be undertaken: Cost containment measures (reduced salary program, cancellation or deferral of all but essential expenditures, implementation
of a total quality management program); internal reallocation measures ($5.7
million off the top for the University Initiative Fund, additional internal reallocation at the unit level, following recommendations of the PACE committee); and
revenue measures (tuition increase). With the proposed 7 percent tuition increase, the net shortfall from the original October proposal would be $9.4 million.
Provost Whitaker announced that because of the elimination of "special
maintenance" funding by the state over the past several years, an infrastructure
maintenance fee of $50 per term was also being proposed to address the highest
priority equipment and facility renovation needs. For the fifth year, an allocation
will be taken "off the top" of the general fund budget for the University Initiative
Fund. For 1991-92, this will amount to $5.7 million ($2.3 million for critical academic needs, $1.0 million for minority faculty recruitment and retention; $0.9
million for research support; $0.7 million for additional financial aid; and $0.8
million for University Library acquisitions).


-16 -



July Meeting, 1991


The recommended FY1991-92 general fund revenue budget of $606.2 million
is $37.7 million higher than the 1990-91 budget. Planned new expenditures include a net general base budget increase of $10.9 million, $4.5 million for staff
benefit increases; $6.0 million for financial aid, $0.9 million for facility opening
costs (renovated facilities with increased operating costs); $2.3 million for critical
academic needs (for schools and colleges); $1.0 million for minority faculty recruitment and retention; $2.4 million for academic program underfunding; $1.0
million for new program initiatives; $3.4 million for "pass through" revenue (tuition passed through to units with special tuition programs due to higher costs or
enrolment changes); $4.6 million for other costs (primarily fixed); a decrease of
$2.7 million as a base budget reallocation (1 percent rollback); and $3.4 million
for infrastructure maintenance.
Provost Whitaker reiterated that it is the University's policy to meet the demonstrated financial need of all regularly enrolled Michigan resident undergraduate students. He then reviewed  e proposed new tuition and fee schedules and
displayed charts and graphs showing how the University's increase compared with
those at other Michigan public uiversities, as well as cost comparisons for a
Michigan undergraduate student to attend the University of Michigan versus its
national eer institutions. Provost Whitaker concluded his presentation by illustrating the continuing decline in state appropriation adjusted for inflation in
recent years; the annual percentage change i general fund revenue; and the continuing decrease in the proportion of general fund revenue derived from state appropriation and concomitant increase in the proportion derived from tuition and
fees.
1991-92 UM-Dearborn General Fund Budget and Student Fee Rates
President Duderstadt then called on Chancellor Wilson to present the UMDearborn General Fund Budget. Chancellor Wilson stated that the priorities in
the UM-Dearborn budget were to upgrade faculty salary levels to a more competitive level, to provide additional student financial aid, support for instruction,
research, and the library, and improving information technology capabilities.
Chancellor Wilson distributed a handout with charts and graphs comparing
UM-Dearborn's financial situation (state appropriation, faculty salaries, and
amount of debt service) with that of its Michigan HA peer institutions. She also
noted that the budget provides for a staff equity salary program which would increment the salaries of staff members making less than $35,000 in addition to the
proposed salary program. She also said that reallocations had been made to
target the highest budget priorities. Chancellor Wilson described the information
technology program, a new inititiative that will provide updated computer laboratories, local area networks, a library computer system, multimedia classrooms, a
management information system, and touchtone registration. $500,000 has been
budgeted to initiate this program.
The UM-Dearborn proposed student fee rates for 1991-92 call for an increase of 7.9 percent for lower-division undergraduate and graduate students and
9.9 percent for upper-division undergraduate students. The proposed 1991-92
general fund budget increase is $3,024,000. This is made up of $850,000 in state


-17 -



July Meeting, 1991


appropriations, $1,931,000 in student fees, $233,000 in other revenue, and
$20,000 from indirect cost reimbursement.
1991-92 UM-Flint General Fund Budget and Student Fee Rates
Chancellor Jones reviewed the process of budget development on the Flint
campus, noting that budget development includes input from the Chancellor's
Cabinet, which includes student, faculty, and staff representatives, and the
Budget Priorities Committee, a faculty body.
The proposed incremental budget increase of 5.3 percent, coupled with a tuition increase of 6.4 percent for resident undergraduates and 8.5 percent for all
other students, will yield an increase of $2,062,300 over the 1990-91 budget. The
Flint campus is also proposing a $40 registration fee, effective fall, 1991. The incremental revenue increase is comprised of $632,165 in state appropriations,
$800,000 in tuition, $530,000 from registration fees, and $100,135 from other
sources. He pointed out that spending priorities are aimed at improving faculty
and staff salaries ($1,455,232 total) and increasing student financial aid to offset
the tuition increase ($225,000). He said that a special program would be instituted to lesson the impact of the registration fee on part-time students. The expenditure budget also calls for programmatic initiatives of $327,068 (including library acquisitions and minority recruitment).
Comments by President Duderstadt
President Duderstadt pointed out that the state legislature would be unlikely
to act on the budget request until September, and that there is a great deal of uncertainty about the state's financial health and its ability to meet the University's
needs. He said that great restraints had been used in preparing the budgets for
all three campuses, including a salary program less than inflation and budget cuts.
He noted that the University of Michigan is 24th of the top 25 universities in the
United States in cost, and that the 7 percent tuition increase on the Ann Arbor
campus is less than that at most other public institutions across the country. He
pointed out that tuition increases have lagged personal income and inflationary
increases over the past eight years, despite state appropriation increases that
have been below the rate of inflation.
He observed that two-thirds of all students receive some form of financial
aid, which means that the more affluent families who don't receive financial aid
are actually providing assistance to less affluent families. In effect, he said that
tuition is a progressive tax that allows people with higher incomes to pay more of
their fair share, while the less fortunate are provided opportunity for access.
President Duderstadt said that he was encouraged by the governor's attitude
that education must be protected and remain a high priority for state government. But he recognized the uncertainties that will remain while the budget process is still underway. He then opened up the floor to comments from the Regents.
Regent Baker asked for a further explanation of the relationship between a
student whose tuition is highly subsidized and one who pays the full instate fee.


-18 -



July Meeting, 1991


The president noted that all students are subsidized in some form. The estimated cost of a year of education at the University of Michigan is about $18,000;
the full tuition charged to a Michigan resident represents from 15 to 20 percent
of the true cost of tat education. In response to another question from Regent
Baker, the president stated that nonresident students receive subsidies not from
state appropriation, but from private and federal sources.
Regent Baker said that the special maintenance fee bothered him philosophically, because various fees have been added over the years and that this base
continues to grow. He asked whether money to be raised by the building maintenance fee might be found elsewhere by reducing costs rather than instituting a
fee.
Provost Whitaker responded to a question from Regent McFee about how
student financial aid is divided between grants and loans. He noted that individual family circumstances are considered for each loan package.
Regent Power pointed out that given the uncertainty of the state's financial
situation, there is a possibility of an executive order that would reduce the
amount of the University's appropriation once it is finally approved, and that the
state could defer other payments besides the $25 million of the 1990-91 appropriation that has already been deferred. He was concerned that the state might
never meet its obligation.
In the discussion that followed, President Duderstadt pointed out that what
the state was really doing was borrowing from higher education. Vice President
Womack stated that the carrying cost of borrowing the $25 million payment that
the state had already deferred was about $1.3 million, and that there were other
costs associated with the deferral as well. Provost Whitaker observed that these
costs had been accounted for in drawing up the budget, and that the University
intended to manage against the known budget contingencies.
In response to a question from Regent Smith about the $50 special maintenance fee, President Duderstadt explained that the loss of state support for deferred maintenance represented a 1.5 percent reduction in the base budget. He
said that this fee would remain in place until the state restores funding for deferred building maintenance.
Regent Smith asked if any financial assistance was being provided for middle
income students. Provost Whitaker noted that an additional $700,000 had been
put into the financial aid budget in an effort to increase the amount of the proportion of aid designated for grants as opposed to loans. He noted that the constraint for middle income students is that they do not qualify for federal aid.
President Duderstadt noted that University personnel were hopeful that the
reauthorization of the Higher Education Act would contain a direct student loan
program without a needs test, which would assist middle income students.
Regent Varner commented that separating the infrastructure maintenance
fee from tuition highlights one of the most critcal funding problems the University has faced for a number of years: that the state has not been carrying out its
responsibility for funding either maintenance of existing facilities or new facilities


-19 -



July Meeting, 1991


construction. Regarding the proposed tuition increase at the Dearborn campus,
she expressed concern about how this would affect that campus' competitiveness
with other institutions in its service area, particularly Wayne State Umversity.
Chancellor Wilson replied that she and her colleagues shared this concern
and monitor this situation closely. She reported that UM-Dearborn had surveyed
students who had decided not to attend UM-Dearborn. From this it had been
determined that cost per se was not the deciding factor in this decision; rather it
was whether the student could afford to attend with the financial aid package offered by UM-Dearborn
Vice President Womack responded to a question from Regent Baker about
how the $25 million payment deferred by the state would be treated in the budget
by stating that it is being considered a deferred revenue item. If the state does
not repay the $25 million, the books would show a $25 million shortfall, which,
Regent Baker noted, would mean that the budget was not balanced. Regent
Power pointed out that the real cost of this deferral included an additional $1.7
million in lost interest income.
President Duderstadt stated that the vote on this item would take place the
following day.

1991-92 Revenue Budgets
UM-Ann Arbor Student Fee Rates for 1991-92
UM-Dearborn Student Fee Rates for 1991-92
UM-Flint Student Fee Rates for 1991-92
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and asked Provost
Whitaker to explain the tuition and fee proposals. Provost Whitaker stated that
the action request for the Ann Arbor campus is for a tuition increase of 7.0
percent for all students except for those in programs in Law, Business Administration MBA, Engineering, Kinesiology, and Pharmacy, which would have special
increases as described in the Regents Communication. There is also a $50 per
term fee for all students, which is devoted to infrastructure maintenance and
equipment replacement. This fee will always be separately identified in the
budget, and there would be the option of dropping the fee if the state reinstituted
its funding for this.
Regent Brown moved approval of the recommended student fee rates for all
three campuses. Regent Varner seconded the motion. Regent Smith asked that
the minutes reflect the statement that at no time will the maintenance fee be absorbed in the tuition fee. Regent Brown restated his motion as approval of the
recommended student fee rates for all three campuses, and that the special maintenance fee is to remain separate unless it is otherwise approved by the Regents.
Regent McFee commented on the difficulty of keeping tuition as low as possible in the face of the increasing discrepancy between the proportion of the general fund budget funded by the state and that funded by tuition. She expressed
the hope that in the future this trend will be reversed, and that public support for
this public university will return to what it should be.
There being no further comments, the vote was taken, and the motion carried, with Regents Brown, Power, McFee, Smith, Varner, and Waters in favor
and Regent Baker abstaining.


-21 -



July Meeting, 1991


An Ordinance to Regulate Parking and Traffic, and to Regulate the Use and Protection of the Buildings and Property of the Regents of the University of Michigan
President Duderstadt stated that after listening to public comments and to
the concerns raised by students on campus, the officers have gained a better understanding about the issue of banning rollerskates and rollerblades as well as
skateboards on campus. Therefore, the ordinance will be rephrased so as to ban
skateboards, rollerskates, and rollerblades from parking structures and University
buildings, but that the remainder of the ordinance will apply only to skateboards,
which will be banned campus-wide (not only in posted areas). Thus, there would
be no constraints on rollerblades or rollerskates outside of parking structures and
campus buildings.
Vice President Womack stated that in response to suggestions from Regent
Nielsen, the phrases on pages 8 and 14, "as amended from time to time", would
be struck from the ordinance. Also, throughout the University's ordinance, all
references to the incorporation of the Ann Arbor ordinances into the University's
ordinances would be removed; instead, in each instance, the University's
ordinance would include the specific language of the relevant Ann Arbor ordinances when the ordinance is published. Vice President Womack also noted that
in Article XIII, Section 1, Paragraph 2 ("Fines and Imprisonment"), specific existing fines for violations of Article II (Traffic and Parking) would be spelled out,
and penalties for violations of other articles will be as provided in the University's ordinance.
Regent Brown moved adoption of the ordinance as amended by Vice President Womack. Regent Power seconded the motion.
Regent Baker stated that he supported the ordinance, but noted that rollerskates and rollerblades should not be used in a manner so as to threaten public
safety. In response to a question about fraternity houses, Vice President Womack
stated that the ordinance would not apply to them. Regent Baker also asked that
counsel review certain other provisions of the ordinance to ensure that they do
not restrict free assembly or free speech.
Regent Baker also expressed concern that Article XII, Section 1, paragraph
5, which identifies as disorderly conduct "fail[ure] to identify oneself accurately
when requested to do so by a police officer or Department of Public Safety security officer after the officer observes the person commit[ting] a civil infraction,
misdemeanor or felony, or when the officer has probable cause to believe the
person has committed a misdemeanor or felony outside of the officer's presence",
may be an inhibition of free speech. Regents Brown and Waters responded that
this is standard criminal law language in Michigan. Regent Waters noted that if
the officer has no reason to believe a crime has been committed, a person has no
obligation to produce identification. Vice President Womack pointed out that
this language parallels the existing Ann Arbor ordinance. Regent Baker asked
that the minutes reflect that police power ought not to be used for intimidation
on campus.
In response to a question from Regent Power about the effective date of the
ordinance, Vice President Womack stated it would be effective immediately


-22 -



July Meeting, 1991


upon approval, and that it, along with all other University ordinances, would be
published regularly. Regent Power observed that it was important to communicate what the ordinance says to members of the University community.
Regent Brown noted that the University's ordinances are subject to state law.
Mr. William Krumm, associate vice president for business operations, who was
present at the meeting, stated that state law requires that all regental ordinances
be posted in three prominent places on campus. However, it would be effective
immediately.
Regent McFee suggested that the portions of the ordinance pertaining to
skateboards, rollerskates, and rollerblades be posted prominently in places currently being used for these activities. Regent Baker responded that he felt the
usual procedure for posting should be followed.
Regent McFee requested that the Regents receive copies of the ordinances
once the changes are made. There being no further discussion, the vote was
taken, and the motion to approve the ordinance as amended was adopted unanimously. The text of the ordinance as amended is included in the appendix.

RESOLUTION OF THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
AUTHORIZING THE ISSUANCE AND DELIVERY OF
MEDICAL SERVICE PLAN REVENUE BONDS SERIES 1991
AND PROVIDING FOR OTHER MATTERS RELATING THERETO
WHEREAS the Regents of the University of Michigan (the "Issuer") constitutes a
constitutional body corporate established pursuant to ArticleVII, Section 5 of the Michigan
-23 -



July Meeting, 1991


Constitution of 1963, as amended with the general supervision of the University of Michigan (the
"University") and the control and direction of all expenditures from the University's funds; and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has determined it is necessary and desirable to ac1uire construct,
furnish, and equip a medical research building and related facilities (the "Project), all for use by
the Medical School of the University (the "School"); and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has previously established its Medical Service Plan (the "Medical
Service Plan") as the mechanism for the managing of, and billing and collecting charges for, the
clinical practice activities of the faculty of the clinical departments of the School; and
WHEREAS, in the exercise of its constitutional duties, and in order to prudently control and
direct expenditures from the University's funds, the Issuer determines it is necessary and desirable
to authorize the issuance of revenue obligations to be designated "Medical Service Plan Revenue
Bonds Series 1991" (the "Bonds"), in the orginal aggregate principal amount of not to exceed Fifty
Eight Million Dollars ($58,000,000) to provide funds to pay part of the costs of the Project, and to
pay certain costs incurred in connection with the issuance and sale of the Bonds; and
WHEREAS, a form of a trust indenture (the "Indenture") to be entered into by and between
the Issuer and a trustee to be designated by the Authorized Officers (hereinafter defined), pursuant
to which the Bonds will be issued and secured, has been presented to the Issuer; and
WHEREAS, Morgan Stanley & Co. Incorporated and Cain Brothers, Shattuck & Company
Incorporated (the "Underwriters") have been engaged to undertake preliminary market analysis
with respect to the sale of the Bonds and to present to the Authorized Officer an offer to purchase
the Bonds pursuant to a bond purchase agreement (the "Bond Purchase Agreement") setting forth
the terms and conditions on which the Underwriters will purchase the Bonds and the interest rates
and agree purchase price thereof; and
WHEREAS in order to be able to market the Bonds at the most opportune time, it is
necessary for the Issuer to authorize the Vice President and Chief Financial Officer or the
Associate Vice President for Finance of the University, or either one of them, (the "Authorized
Officers") to negotiate, execute and deliver on behalf of the Issuer the Indenture, establish the
specific terms of the Bonds and to accept the offer of the Underwriters to purchase the Bonds, all
within the limitations set forth herein; and
andWHEREAS, the financing of the Project will service proper and appropriate public purposes;
WHEREAS, the issuer has full power under its constitutional authority for supervision of the
University and control and expenditures from the University funds to acquire the Project, to pay
the cost of acquisition, construction, furnishing and equipping of the Project by issuance of the
bonds, and to pledge Medical Service Plan Revenues for payment of the Bond.
NOW   THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY
OF MICAIGAN, AS FOLLOWS:
1. The Issuer hereby authorizes the issuance, execution and delivery of the Bonds of the
Issuer to be designated MEDICAL SERVICE PLAN REVENUE BONDS, SERIES 1991 in the
original aggregate principal amount to be determined by an Authorized Officer, but not to exceed
$58,00,000, to be dated as of a date to be determined by an Authorized Officer for the purpose of
providing funds to pay part of the cost of the Project, and to pay costs incidental to the issuance of
the Bonds, including, as an Authorized Officer may determine, capitalized interest, if appropriate.
The Bonds ma be serial bonds or term bonds subject to redemption reuirements, or both as
shall be established by an Authorized Officer, but the first maturity shall be not earlier than
December 1,1992 and the last maturity shall be no later than December 1, 2022. The Bonds shall
be issued as interest bearing bonds or capital appreciation bonds, or a combination thereof and
shall bear interest or appreciate at the rates for the respective maturities thereof as shall be
established by an Authorized Officer, but the highest rate of interest or appreciation for any
maturity shal not exceed 8.00% per annum. The Bonds may be noncallable or subject to
redemption prior to maturity at the times and price and in the manner as shall be established by an
Authorized Officer, but the maximum redemption remium shall not exceed 5% of the principal
being redeemed. Interest on the Bonds, if any, shallbe payable semiannually on December 1 and
June 1 of each year. The maximum annual principal and interest requirements on the Bonds shall
not exceed $5,000,000. The Bonds shall be issued in fully registered form in denominations, shall
be subject to transfer and exchange, and shall be executed and authenticated, all as shall be
provided in the Indenture. The Bonds shall be sold to Underwriters pursuant to the Bond
Purchase Agreement for a price to be established by an Authorized Officer (but the Underwriter's


-24 -



July Meeting, 1991


discount, exclusive of original issue discount shall not exceed 1.50% of the original principal
amount thereof) plus accrued interest, if any, from the dated date of the Bonds to the date of
delivery thereof.

equally and ratably secured by an irrevocable pledge of the Medical Service Plan Revenues (as shall
be defined in the Indenture) and funds from time to time on deposit in the Bond Fund created
pursuant to the Indenture.

Regent Baker moved approval of the recommended 1991-92 fee assessments
of $6.27 per student per term for Michigan Student Assembly (MSA), $0.35 per
student per term for Michigan Collegiate Coalition (MCC), and $1.00 per student
per term for school/college governments. Regent Baker commented that the
MSA officers had been elected by substantial margins, appear to have a broad
degree of support among the student body, and have been willing to cooperate
with the executive officers, and he felt they deserved support from the Regents.
Regent McFee observed that several speakers at Public Comments had objected to the cuts being proposed by MSA to the budgets of the Ann Arbor Tenants Union (AATU) as well as how these cuts would affect Student Legal Services (SLS). Other speakers had claimed that a significant portion of the activities carried on by AATU are political and not directly related to students.
Regent McFee asked that the Regents be provided with some documentation of
the activities and finances of these organizations to guide them in future budget
decisions.
Regent Smith seconded Regent Baker's motion.
Regent Power noted that although Regents are regularly lobbied to influence
how MSA handles it budget, it is not the Regents' business how MSA chooses to
allocate the money it receives from student fees.
Following further discussion, the vote was taken, and the motion to approve
the 1991-92 fee assessments for Michigan Student Assembly, Michigan Collegiate
Coalition, and school/college governments was adopted unanimously.
1991-92 University Health Service Fee
Vice President Swain said that authorization was being sought to increase the
University Health Service fee by $4.00 per student per term (5.11 percent) for
1991-92, which will raise the fee to $82.25 per student per term. She noted that
health service fee increases consistently have been less than those of the general
health care sector, indicating prudent management by health service staff.
Regent Smith moved to increase the University Health Service fee by $4.00
per term. Regent Power seconded the motion.
Regent Baker observed that although the argument is always made that it is
more efficient to assess a health service fee for all students, it is unfair for parents
who pay for private health insurance to also have to- pay an additional fee for
University Health Service. Because health care costs have been rising so rapidly,
Regent Baker suggested that this issue be examined again.
Regent McFee noted that often families or employers are paying double premiums for health care coverage, but are not receiving double reimbursement.
She suggested this issue be looked at so that parents and employers can help contain rapidly rising health care costs by eliminating double premiums where possible.


-26 -



July Meeting, 1991


Regent Power commended Dr. Cesar Briefer, director of University Health
Service, for having held the rate of increase in health care coverage to below
national levels.
Dr. Briefer noted that University Health Service was going to begin collecting for reimbursable services from students' private health insurance companies,
although he emphasized that the majority of the care provided by health service
is in the form of office visits, which generally are not covered by private health
insurance. He also pointed out that the health service fee is not really an insurance program; it covers all co-pays and deductibles from insurance so that students and parents are never billed directly for its services. Only insurance companies will be billed, and this will only occur if a student signs an informed release of information to be sent to the insurance company.
There being no further discussion, the vote was taken and the motion to increase the University Health Service fee for 1991-92 by $4.00 per student per
term was approved unanimously.
Michigan Collegiate Coalition
Regent Baker stated that when he made his motion to approve the MSA fee
assessments, he had not understood that the motion included the fee for the student lobbying organization (Michigan Collegiate Coalition). He stated his opinion that the MCC fee should be voluntary, because it has to do with political
action, and people should not have to pay for political representation which they
might not want.
Regent Waters left the meeting at this point (10:30 A.M.).
Regent Power observed that there is a big gap between the $75,000 in student fees that goes to Michigan Collegiate Coalition and what they claim to have
accomplished. Regent Smith agreed. Regent McFee suggested that consideration be given to making the MCC fee a checkoff item in the future.
Reports
Regent Baker thanked Vice President Womack for including the report on
mortgages in the investment report.
Regarding the litigation report, Regent Baker noted a case involving a medical center employee who had tested HIV positive. He said that this raises the
issue of what the University policy is regarding employees who are HIV positive,
and what latitude such employees are given to practice their professions. He said
that this issue is analogous to what occurred when the University first undertook
studies of DNA, when people were uncertain of the effect of this material on the
general population. At that time experts were invited to discuss the issue and
ultimately guidelines were adopted regarding the study of DNA. He stated that a
policy ought to be developed to deal with the issues raised by this lawsuit as well.
Regent Power stated his hope that medical professionals would be invited to
submit their views to the Board, rather than having the Board impose its views on
them.

Proposed License Agreement between the University of Michigan and Michigan
Critical Care Consultants
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Power, all six Regents
present unanimously approved the University's entering into a license agreement
with Michigan Critical Care Consultants, Inc. The proposed agreement falls
under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute, since the owners of
Michigan Critical Care Consultants and developers of the technology to be
commercialized (a self-regulating-blood pump and a Venturi-type flow meter),
Robert H. Bartlett, Scott I. Merz, and J. Patrick Montoya (the "Developers"), are
also University employees. The following information is provided in compliance
with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the contract will be the Regents of the University of
Michigan and Michigan Critical Care Consultants, a corporation
owned by the Developers.
2.  Terms of the contract include: a duration for ten years or the term
of the last to expire of the licensed patents, and consideration to
the University consisting of payment of royalties, including minimum royalties, on sales of the technology and on sublicense rights
granted in the technology. Royalties will be paid at a rate of 5
percent for revenues from the sale or use of patented technology,
2.5 percent for revenues from the sale or use of unpatented technology, and 25 percent of revenues generated by sublicenses in the
technology. Minimum royalties shall commence on the agreement's third full year at $1,000 -each year. The University retains
ownership of all technology, and will be assigned joint ownership
of any inventions relating to the technology which are created
jointly by University employees and Michigan Critical Care Consultants employees, and will also be assigned sole ownership of any


-29 -



July Meeting, 1991


inventions relating to the technology which are created by University employees who are concurrently employed by Michigan Critical Care Consultants. The University retains the right to use the
technology for research and educationally-related purposes, and
for its own clinical use. Michigan Critical Care Consultants shall
diligently pursue the commercial development and exploitation of
the technology. There is no use of facilities or services of the
University included in the contract and no assignment of University employees for fulfillment of the contract.
3.  The Developers' pecuniary interest in the contract arises from
their ownership of Michigan Critical Care Consultants. This corporation will receive revenues from the sale, use, and sublicensing
of the technology, and the University will receive a share of those
revenues. The developers' interest in that corporation will be in
lieu of participation in the sharing of royalties received by the
University in accordance with University policy.

University of Michigan Policy on Sexual Harassment by Faculty and Staff
Regent McFee noted that a speaker at the public comments session had
commented on the impression conveyed by the media about the Regents' discussion regarding the sexual harassment policy at the last meeting. She stated that
the Regents had addressed the policy with serious concern, not with the levity


-30 -



July Meeting, 1991


that had been conveyed by the media. She felt the Regents had two areas of concern regarding the policy: 1) whether or not the policy would intrude on areas it
is not intended to regulate, that is, matters which are and should remain private;
and 2) concern that the language of the policy did not provide opportunity to address capricious and malicious sexual harassment matters.
Regent McFee noted that in trying to develop a policy which will both create
an element of trust where people feel they can come forth with sexual harassment complaints, one needs to be cognizant of the rights of individuals to be protected against capricious and malicious accusations. Her impression of the
Board's discussion was that serious attention was paid to those matters, and that
legal counsel had been requested to make corrections in those areas and return it
to the Regents for review. The intent was to ensure that the final policy would
have those safeguards in it, as well as those pro-active issues it was intended to
address. She regretted if a contrary impression had been conveyed to the community.
Regents Baker and Brown supported Regent McFee's observation.
City of Ann Arbor Blue Ribbon Committee
Regent Baker noted that the mayor had recently appointed a blue ribbon
committee, consisting of several University faculty and other residents, to study
major issues confronting the city. He asked whether the committee was an "official" University/city committee.
Mr. Walter Harrison, executive director of university relations, responded
that certain members of the University faculty with expertise in taxation and
other financial matters had been asked to serve on this committee. These faculty
had agreed to serve on the committee as individuals, and not in their official
University capacity. In addition, the Institute of Public Policy Studies would be
offering a class in which students would be able to earn credit by helping with the
work of the committee.
There being no further discussion, the meeting was adjourned. The next
meeting is scheduled for September 19-20, 1991. Regents' transportation, accommodation, telephone, and miscellaneous expenses for the month of June 1991
totalled $1,576.18.

THE COST OF ACOUISITION CONSTRUCTION AND EQUIPPING OF

University of Michigan (the Issuer") has authorized the acquisition, construcion and equippng of a
new Aerospace Engmeer   Building and an addition to the Space Research Building, each on the
Ann Arbor Campus of the university (collectively, the "Project"; and
WHEREAS in the exercise of their constitutional duties and in order to properly serve the
interests of students attending the University, and to prudently control and direct expenditures of
the Universitys funds the Issuer deems it necessary and advisable to issue Engineering College
Projects Student Fee Bonds, Series 991 (hereinafter defined as the "Bonds") in the principal
amount of Eight Million One Hundred Thousand Dollars ($8,100000) for the purpose of paying
part of the cost of acqurn  constructing and equipping the Project, and paying the epenses related
thereto and incidental to the issuance othe Bonds; an

lien against Student Fees, subject to the ringht to incur additional obligations simiarly secured, upon
conditions specified in the resolutions authorizing said previously incurred obligations, essentially as

preceding complete Fiscal Years prior to the issuance of such additional Parity Obligations
are equal to at least 200% percent of the maximum annual principal and interest requirements of the then outstanding Parity Obligations and the proposed additional Parity Obligations during any future Fiscal Year the proposed additional Parity Obligations are
scheduled to be outstanding."
WHEREAS, the Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of the University shall certify in
connection with the issuance of the Bonds, that all conditions and requirements precedent to the
issuance of the Bonds shall have been met, as shown by audit reports of the University for each of its
last two preceding fiscal years, 1988-89 and 1989-90; and
WHEREAS the Issuer has been created as a constitutional body corporate under the provisions
of Article VIII, Section 5 of the Michigan Constitution of 1963, and has full power under its
constitutional authority and supervision ofthe University, and control and direction of expenditures
from the University funds, to construct the Project, to pay the cost of the acquisition construction
and equippg of the Project and by issuance of the Bonds, and to pledge Student Fees for payment
of the Bonds;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF

enacted, in lieu of and in substitution for the Bond so lost, destroyed or stolen. If any such Bond shall
have matured or shall be about to mature, instead of issuing a substitute bond the Transfer Agent
may pay the same without surrender thereof

ARTICLE V
FLOW AND USE OF FUNDS
Section 501. ApDlication of Bond Proceeds. Immediately upon the receipt thereof, the proceeds
of the sale of the Bond shall be apportioned among and deposited in the following funds and
accounts in the following manner:
1.   Any accrued interest received on sale of the Bonds shall be deposited in the Bond Fund;
2.   The balance of the proceeds of the Bonds shall be deposited in the Project Fund.
Section 502. Use of and Disbursements from Project Fund. Moneys in the Project Fund shall be
used pursuant to the following purposes:
1.   Payment of accounting, financial consulting, legal, printing and other expenses of the Issuer
in connection with the preparation, issuance, sae and delivery of the Bonds;
2.   Payments necessary to finance the cost of the acquisition, construction, installation,
furnishing and equipping of the Project or to reimburse the Issuer for general funds
expended m connection with the foregoing.
Any amount remaining in the Project Fund after satisfaction of the foregoing priorities shall, as
directed by the Issuer, be promptly transferred to the Bond Fund or used by the Issuer for payment
of any other lawful capital costs ofthe University as determined by the Issuer. The depository for the
Project Fund shall make disbursements from the Project Fund upon the order of the Issuer, and shall
have no duty or liability with respect to the manner or method in which moneys are withdrawn by the
Issuer from the Project Fund or min fact are used or applied by the Issuer.
Section 503. Use of and Disbursements from Bond Fund. On each Bond Payment Date the
Transfer Agent shall use moneys in the Bond Fund to pay principal of and interest on the Bonds as
the same become due and, in the case of principal payments, as the Bonds are presented and
surrendered. The Transfer Agent may use moneys in the Bond Fund not required to pay maturing

at the written direction of the Issuer. Any amount remaning in the Bond Fund after the Bonds have

Section 602. Student Fees as Source of Payment of Bonds. To the extent that on the fifth day
preceding any Bond Payment Date the moneys then on deposit in the Bond Fund are not sufficient to
meet the interest, or principal and interest, payment coming due on such Bond Payment Date the
Issuer shall, commencing September 26, 1991, and on each subsequent fifth day preceding each Aond
Payment Date while the Bonds remain outstanding, pay to the Transfer Agent for deposit into the
Bond Fund all Student Fees thereafter received until the amount on deposit in the Bond Fund is
sufficient to pay the interest, and principal, if any, coming due on the Bonds by maturity on such
Bond Payment Date; provided, however, that in making the payment over to the Transfer Agent,
Student ees shall be divided pro rata between the Bond Fund and any similar fund for the payment
of other obligations of the Issuer secured by a first lien on Student Fees, to the extent necessary to
effect the pan passu basis of the lien on Student Fees. Subject to the above requirements, the Issuer
shall have and retain the full right and ability to receive collect, expend, invest, use or otherwise hold
or dispose of Student Fees as the Issuer deems appropriate.
Section 603. Funds Legally Available Therefor as Source of Payment for the Bonds. The Issuer
reserves the riht, utshall not be required, to use any Legally Available Funds for the purpose of
paying principal or interest on the Bonds.
Section 604. Covenant re: Student Fees. The Issuer covenants and agrees that as long as any of
the Bonds remain outstanding and unpaid, as to either principal or interest, it will establish and
maintain Student Fees to be collected from the students attending the University in an amount
sufficient to provide annually sums equal to at least two hundred percent (200%) of the maximum
future annual debt service requirements on all outstanding bonds or obligations payable on a first lien
basis from said Student Fees or allocations therefrom. Such collections shall be sufficient together
with other available funds, to provide such sums as are necessary for the operation, administration
and maintenance of the University and its facilities and programs.
Section 605. Limitations of Obligations. No recourse under any obligation, covenant stipulation
or indenture contained in this Resolution or in any Bond issued hereunder or caused by tie creation
of any indebtedness hereby authorized, shall be had against the State of Michigan, or the Issuer or
any member or officer of the Issuer or any officer of the University, nor shall any such obligation ever
be or become a charge against the State of Michigan, nor shall the same become a lien on or secured
by any property, real, personal or mixed, of the State of Michigan or the Issuer, it being expressly
understood and agreed that the Bonds and the obligations created hereunder are secured by and
payable only from Student Fees and moneys in the Bond Fund, and that no other liability whatsoever
shall attach to or be incurred by the State of Michigan, the Issuer2 or any member or officer of the
Issuer or any officer of the University, or its successors; all other liability, except as herein provided,
being expressly waived.
ARTICLE VII
ADDITIONAL PARTY OBLIGATIONS AND DEFEASANCE
Section, 701. Additional Parity Obligations. The Issuer reserves the right to issue additional
Parity Obligations for any authorized purpose having equal standing and pority of lien against
Student Fees with the Bonds and other then existing Parity Obligations of the Issuer, provided:
(a) the Issuer by its Associate Vice President for Finance certifies that the total amount of
Student Fees collected by the Issuer in each of its last two preceding complete Fiscal Years pnor
to the issuance of such proposed additional Parity Obligations are equal to at least 200% of the
maximum annual principal and interest requirements of the then outstanding Parity Obligations
and the proposed additional Parity Obligations during any future Fiscal ear the Bonds are
scheduled to be outstanding, and
(b) the proposed additional Parity Obligations shall be payable as to principal only on
April 1 of the year or years of maturity and payable as to interest either annually or
semiannually on April 1 or October 1 of such years.
Section 702. Defeasance. If all the Bonds shall have become due and payable in accordance
with their terms or are to be paid at their maturity or maturities and the whole amount of the
principal and the interest so due and payable upon all of the Bonds then outstanding shall be paid or
sufficient cash, or cash and noncallable Government Obligations the principal of and the interest on
which without reinvestment, when due and payable, will provide sufficient moneys for such payment,

shall be held by the Transfer Agent in the Bond Fund or by any other escrow aentn trust for the

ARTICLE X
SALE OF BONDS AND PREPARATION OF OFFICIAL STATEMENT
Section 1001. Sale of Bonds. The Bonds shall be sold on behalf of the Issuer at the purchase
price specified in the winning bid attached hereto as Exhibit A, plus accrued interest on the Bonds
from July 15,1991, to the date of delivery.
Section 1002. Authorization of Official Statement Preliminary Official Statement and Official
Notice of Sale. The Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, or the Associate Vice President
for Finance, or either of them are hereby authorized to execute and deliver on behalf of the Issuer
an Official Statement substantially in the form of the previously prepared Preliminary Official
Statement, relating to the Bonds. The distribution and use of the Preliminary Official Statement
in accordance with applicable laws, in connection with the sale of the Bonds, in hereby ratified and
confirmed, and the distribution and use of the Official Statement in accordance with applicable
laws by the successful bidder, in connection with the marketing of the Bonds, is hereby authorized
and approved. The form and substance of the Official Notice of Sale, previously published, is
ratified and approved.
Section 1003. Resolution Constitutes Contract. The provisions of the Resolution shall
constitute a contract between the Issuer and Bondholders to the equal and ratable benefit and
protection of each Bondholder, and after delivery of the Bonds, no change, variation, or alteration
of the provisions of the Resolution may be made except in accordance with its terms.
Section 1004. Enforcement of Contract The contract constituted by the Resolution shall be
enforceable by appropriate proceedings taken by the Bondholder(s) under the law.
Section 1005. Other Documentation. The Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of the
University, the Secretary of the University, the Associate Vice President for Finance of the
University, the Investment Officer/Treasurer of the University, and any other appropriate officers
or representatives of the Issuer or the University, and each of them, are authorized to perform all
acts and deeds and execute and deliver all instruments and documents for and on behalf of the
Issuer required by this Resolution, or necessary, expedient and proper in connection with the
issuance, sale and delivery of the Bonds, and the acquisition, construction and equipping of the
Project all as contemplated hereby.
Subsequent to the issuance of the Bonds, all actions permitted or re uired by the Issuer may
be made or undertaken by the Vice President and Chief Financial Officer or Associate Vice
President for Finance, or any other duly authorized officer of the Issuer or the University. All
determination of Bond terms required to be made by the Vice President and Chief Financial
Officer or Associate Vice President for Finance shall be made by him within the ranges or other
limitations set forth herein.
