ARTICLE XI
MISCELLANEOUS
Section 1101. Severability. If any one or more sections, clauses or provisions of the
Resolution shall be determined by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or ineffective for
any reason, such determination shall in no way affect the validity and effectiveness of the
remaining sections, clauses and provisions of the Resolution.
Section 1102. Headings. Any headings shall be solely for convenience of reference and shall
not constitute a part of th Resolution, nor shall they affect its meaning, construction or effect.
Section 1103. Conflict. All resolutions or parts of resolutions or other proceedings of the
Issuer in conflict herewith be and the same are repealed insofar as such conflict exists.
Section 1104. Effective Date, The Resolution shall take effect immediately upon its adoption.


-44 -



SEPTEMBER MEETING, 1991


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, September 19, 1991
The Regents met at 1:00 P.M. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Smith, Varner,
and Waters. Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, and Vice
Presidents Cosovich, Johnson, Kelly, and Womack were also present, as were
Chancellors Jones and Wilson. Vice President Swain was absent.
University Annual Financial Statements for 1990-91
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and called on Vice President Womack to present the annual financial statements for 1990-91. Vice President Womack turned to the report of the independent auditors, Ernst and
Young, and read the following paragraph, which he described as a clean opinion:
In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all
material respects, the financial position of the University of Michigan at June 30,
1991, and the changes in fund balances and the current funds revenues, expenditures, and transfers for the year then ended in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles.
Following further comments, Vice President Womack announced that the report of year-end financial information would be given by Messrs. Chandler
Matthews, associate vice president for finance and controller, and Robert W.
Moenart, director of financial operations.
Year-End Financial Information for 1990-91
Mr. Matthews and Mr. Moenart gave a slide presentation on the year-end financial information for 1990-91, beginning with current funds, which include the
General, Designated, and Expendable-Restricted Funds and are sometimes referred to as the Educational and General Funds. Both funds were compared
with the same funds for the fiscal year 1981-82. In 1990-91, total educational and
general current fund revenues were $1.011 billion, compared with $450 million
for 1981-82. Mr. Matthews noted that in 1990-91, the proportion of the current
funds derived from state appropriations had declined from 33.7 percent to 26.7
percent over a ten-year period, while the proportion derived from student fees
had risen from 25.4 percent to 29.2 percent during that time. Private gifts and
sponsored programs had also increased during that time, from 7.9 percent of the
total to 10.3 percent (ten-year compound growth rate of 12.7 percent). The total
compound growth rate for the current funds over the ten-year period was 9.4 percent.
Regent Baker pointed out that student fees had increased proportionately as
state appropriations had decreased. In response to a comment from Regent
Brown, President Duderstadt noted that funds for student financial aid over the
ten-year period had increased at a greater rate than student fees, thus lessening
the impact of tuition increases for many students. The increased financial aid


-45 -



September Meeting, 1991


was required because of the federal and state governments' withdrawal of support for higher education.
With regard to current funds expenditures, Mr. Matthews reported that the
largest category of expenditure is total compensation (salaries and wages plus
staff benefits), which accounted for 66.1 percent of expenditures in 1981-82 and
58.6 percent in 1990-91, for a compound annual growth rate of 8.5 percent.
Schoarships and fellowships rose fom 7.5 percent of the expenditue budget in
1981-82 to 8.5 percent in 1990-91, for an 11 percent i, for growth rate, confirming the
president's previous comment. Although the proportion of expenditures devoted
to supplies remained virtually the same (about 21.0 percent), that category experienced a compound annual growth rate of 10.5 percent. The other major expenditure category, equipment and plant, grew from 5.4 percent of the total to 11.1
percent, for a growth rate of 19.1 percent. Revenues and expenditures for auxillary activities are driven largely by hospital and medical activities, so were displayed separately from the Educational and General Funds.
Mr. Matthews concluded by stating that the University had received a clean
opinion from its auditors, and that the University was solvent and well positioned
to meet challenges that it will face in the coming year. Mr. Matthews and Vice
President Womack then responded to questions from the Regents about the
audit report and the financial information that had been presented so far. Then,
there being no further discussion, Regent Baker moved adoption of the University Annual Financial Statements for 1990-91. Regent Varner seconded the
motion, and it was adopted unanimously.
1991-92 Revenue and Expenditure Budgets
President Duderstadt called on Vice President Womack to present the
1991-92 current funds budgets. Vice President Womack noted that the current
funds include the General Fund, Designated Fund, Auxiliary Activities Fund, and
Expendable Restricted Fund. Total 1991-92 revenues for all three campuses are
projected to be $1,889,386,722 (a 7.2 percent increase over 1990-91); expenditures will be $1,867,575,278 (7.8 percent increase). State appropriations are
budgeted at $307,339,554; student tuition and fees are $319,637,226. The
General Fund makes up 36.0 percent of the revenue budget ($675.1 million), the
Expendable Restricted Fund 18.0 percent ($333.6 million), the Designated Fund
3.0 percent ($59.7 million), the medical component of the Auxiliary Activities
Fund, 39.0 percent (almost $729 million); and the other auxiliary activities about
4.0 percent (about $80 million). The compound growth rate from fiscal year 1983
is 10.1 percent.
Vice President Womack then called on Provost Whitaker to present details
of the General Fund budget. Provost Whitaker reported that the total General
Fund revenue budget of $675.1 million is derived fom tuition and fees (47 percent), state appropriations (43 percent), indirect cost recovery (8 percent), and
other sources (mostly interest income â€”2 percent). General Fund expenditures by
function are devoted to instruction (44 percent), academic support (17 percent),
plant operations (13 percent), scholarships (7 percent), research (4 percent), and
'other" (public service, student service, institutional support, mandatory transfers,
and enforced savings) (15 percent). Considered by object of expenditure, 67 percent of General Fund expenditures are for salaries and benefits, 26 percent for
nonsalaries, and 7 percent for financial aid. Provost Whitaker also displayed a


-46 -



September Meeting, 1991


bar chart illustrating budgeted General Fund expenditures for the vice presidential areas; these total $232.4 million.
Provost Whitaker then presented details of expenditure budgets for the vice
president for academic affairs and vice president and chief financial officer and
for some of the schools and colleges, responding to questions and comments from
the Regents. Noting the $800,000 increase in the University Library budget for
library acquisitions, Regent Power asked to receive a report on why the costs for
periodicals have risen so dramatically over the past several years, and what could
be done about it. Provost Whitaker pointed out that the 1991-92 undergraduate
student aid budget had been increased by 12.1 percent, greater than the student
fee increase, in an effort to be responsive to student needs in this area. Regarding the utilities budget, Provost Whitaker noted that utility costs were beginning
to rise after remaining somewhat flat for several years. Regent Baker expressed
an interest in knowing how the cogeneration facility and other energy saving
measures had effected the cost increases.
Following Provost Whitaker's presentation about the General Fund budget
for the Ann Arbor campus, Chancellor Jones commented about the Flint
campus' operating budget. He noted the increasing pattern of reliance on tuition
as a revenue source. Whereas as in 1990-91, state appropriation accounted for 56
percent of the revenue source base, in 1991-92, that figure will drop to 54 percent. He explained that a negative change in the government sponsored programs category was due to the expiration of the bilingual education program, a
arge federal program on the Flint campus. Chancellor Jones pointed out several
other features of the revenue and expenditure budget, after which the provost
called on Chancellor Wilson to present the Dearborn budget.
Chancellor Wilson observed that the Dearborn campus had seen a more significant shift than had the Flint campus in dependence on tuition income for revenues. She then enumerated some of the policy changes that have driven some
of the budget changes: having the PACE rogram become more self-supporting;
the elimination of the UM-Dearborn pubications office and turning those funds
over to the new Office of Institutional Advancement; and moving the programs
that had been housed in the Division of Interdisciplinary Studies into the faculty
units throughout the University, thus eliminating the centralized interdisciplinary
studies division. Following Chancellor Wilson's remarks, she responded to questions about the UM-Dearborn budget.
Vice President Womack then continued the presentation with a description
of the Designated, Auxiliary Activities, and Expendable Restricted Funds. In the
discussion that followed, Regent Power asked what contingency plans were being
made, given the uncertain state budget situation.
President Duderstadt described the budgetary risk factors as being a) the uncertain nature of the state appropriation process, which is expected to be resolved much as the University had expected; b) the deferred payments of state
appropriations for the months of July, August, and September, 1991, which
amount to over $25 million, and the risk that these will never be paid; and c) the
uncertainties in the federal arena, including research activities budgets and policies on overhead reimbursement. He stated that the budget had been assembled
with contingencies in mind, but that most of the contingency factors are in the expenditure area.


-47 -



September Meeting, 1991
Provost Whitaker reported that enough money had been sequestered in the
budget to make up for a possible shortfall in the actual amount of state appropriations versus what planners had predicted. But the more serious potential difficulty is the state revenue projections, which could lead to potential executive
order budget reductions. He said that the vice presidents had been cautioned to
be very careful in expenditures and in managing personnel turnover. The belief
is that centrally managed budget planning, i.e., freezes, are ill-advised, as individual units are in better positions to judge their own unique situations. Provost
Whitaker reported that the deans and vice presidents are formulating contingency plans to deal with potential budget shortfalls.
Regent Baker pointed out that all of the factors causing the budget uncertainties constitute a serious matter for the administration, making this a difficult
time for the University. President Duderstadt noted that this was a difficult time
for public higher education across the United States, and that in several years,
this situation would extend to private institutions as well.
Regent Power noted that much prudence and care had been put into preparation of this budget in light of these financial uncertainties. Then, there being
no further discussion, Regent Power moved approval of the 1991-92 revenue and
expenditure budgets. Regent Brown seconded the motion, and it was adopted
unanimously. There followed a ten minute recess.
The meeting resumed following the recess, at 2:55 PM.
Minutes
On a motion by Regent Baker, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved the minutes of the meeting of July 18-19, 1991.
Reports
Vice President Womack submitted reports on Investment Transactions, Plant
Extension, Endowment Fund Quarterly Inventory (included in the Report of Investments for Year-Ended 6/30/91), Litigation, and Personnel-Labor Relations,
and responded to comments and questions from the Regents. Regarding the Litigation Report, Regent Baker noted that for the first time, nine other state public
universities had joined together in filing amicus briefs on behalf of the University
in a lawsuit.
There being no further discussion, Regent Brown moved that the Regents receive the reports. Regent Varner seconded the motion, and it was approved
unanimously.
Gifts and Grants
Vice President Cosovich submitted the gift report for fiscal year 1990-91, and
for the month of July 1991. President Duderstadt noted that in the coming year,
the University would embark on a new capital campaign, and that he was very encouraged by the early support and enthusiasm shown by a group of volunteers at
a meeting that had been held the previous week.

schools and colleges for their efforts.

Retirement Memoirs
On a motion by Regent Varner, seconded by Regent Nielsen, the Regents
unanimously adopted the following retirement memoirs:
James K. Avery, D.D.S., professor of dentistry in the School of Dentistry and
professor of anatomy in the Medical School, retired from active faculty status on
August 31, 1991.
A native of Colorado, Dr. Avery received his D.D.S. degree at the University
of Kansas City in 1945. After a tour of active service as a lieutenant in the U.S.


-69 -



September Meeting 1991


Navy, he completed his AB. degree in 1948 and his Ph.D. degree in anatomy in
1952 at the University of Rochester. Dr. Avery joined the faculty of the University of Michigan as an assistant professor of dentistry in 1954; he was promoted to
associate professor in 1959 and to professor in 1963. In 1961, he was also ap
pointed associate professor of anatomy in the Medical School, and promoted to
professor in 1971.
Dr. Avery served on the executive committee at the School of Dentistry from
1962-65, was program director of the school's Multi-Basic Science Training Program from 1970-82, and was chair of the Department of Oral Biology from
1977-86. He has served as a consultant to the Public Health Service, the American Dental Association, and the Ann Arbor Veterans Administration Hospital,
and is a past president of the International Association for Dental Research and
past chair of the American Association of Dental Schools' anatomical sciences
section. He was a member of the Scientific Advisory Committee from 1968-70
and the executive committee of the Dental Research Institute from 1968-73. In
1970, he was appointed associate director of the institute; he was subsequently
promoted to director and served in this capacity until 1987.
Dr. Avery's research interests are in growth and development, an area in
which he has written over 130 publications and 3 textbooks. He is currently
funded by the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation and will continue research in this area. Dr. Avery received the Pulp Biology Award from the International Association for Dental Research in 1986. He also received the Academy
of Dental Medicine Award, and was elected a fellow of the American College of
Dentistry and the American Association for the Advancement of Science. He is
a member of Omicron Kappa Upsilon and was president of the University of
Michigan chapter of Sigma Xi. He has been active in research and has been
funded by the National Institutes of Health and other agencies throughout his
career at the University of Michigan.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health sciences educator by
naming James K Avery Professor Emeritus of Dentistry and Professor Emeritus
of Anatomy.
Ernest Harburg, research scientist in the Department of Epidemiology,
School of Public Health, and in the Department of Psychology, College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, retired from active faculty status on September 10,
1991, after a most productive research career.
Dr. Harburg received his B.S. degree in history from the College of the City
of New York in 1951, his M.A. degree in anthropology from the University of
Wisconsin in 1956, and his Ph.D. degree in social psychology from the University
of Michigan in 1962. Beginning with his service as assistant study director at the
Institute for Social Research from 1957-61 and study director from 1962-64, Dr.
Harburg has served multiple roles at the University of Michigan. From 1964-70,
he served as an assistant professor (1964-65) and associate professor (1965-70) of
psychology and researcher in the School of Nursing. In 1965, he was also appointed research associate in the Department of Psychology. His long association with the School of Public Health began with his appointment as research scientist in the Department of Epidemiology in 1973.
Dr. Harburg's research interests and scholarly publications with a host of collaborators have covered a wide range of topics, including interpersonal conflict,
urban life and mental health, rheumatoid arthritis, residential mobility, and correlates of smoking. But he is best known for his long-term programmatic empirical studies of various correlates and determinants of blood pressure -- a series of
biological variables, racial, ethnic, and heredity variables, work status and
-70 -



September Meeting, 1991


satisfaction, age, personality traits, modes of coping, behavioral patterns -- and
for his more recent work on intra-familial transmission of patterns of alcohol
usage.
The Regents now salute this distinguished scientist for his dedicated service
by naming Ernest Harburg Research Scientist Emeritus.
Robert M. Howe, professor of aerospace engineering, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1991.
Professor Howe received his B.S. degree (electrical engineering) from the
California Institute of Technology in 1945, his A.B. degree (physics) from
Oberlin College in 1947, his M.S. degree (physics) from the University of Michigan in 1948, and his Ph.D. degree (physics) from the Massachusetts Institute of
Technology in 1950. He joined the faculty of the University of Michigan in 1950
as an instructor in aerospace technology; he was promoted to assistant professor
in 1951, associate professor in 1954, and professor in 1957. Professor Howe
served as chair of the Information and Control Engineering Program from
1963-68, and as chair of the Department of Aerospace Engineering from 1968-83.
Professor Howe has enjoyed a most varied and productive career. He played
a major role in establishing the Information and Control Engineering Program,
the program in computer, information and control engineering, and in fostering
the development of a strong flight dynamics and control activity within the department. His students have benefited immensely from his ability to illuminate
complex topics by simple explanations and his insistence that practical engineering issues be kept in full view, and he has provided imaginative and excellent
guidance for numerous graduate students. His professional interests have included computer simulation of dynamic systems, control systems, flight simulation, design optimization techniques, and real-time simulation. He has published
more than 75 journal articles, many conference proceedings, and a book on the
design of analog computers. In addition to his teaching and research, in 1957,
Professor Howe was one of the founders of Applied Dynamics International, an
Ann Arbor company which is currently a leading supplier of high-speed digital
computers for simulation.
Among his many honors, Professor Howe has been elected a fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers and an associate fellow of the
American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics. In 1978, as a result of his
service as a member of the U. S. Air Force Scientific Advisory Board, he received
an award for meritorious civilian service from the U.S. Air Force chief of staff for
his leadership and contribution in guidance, control, and flight simulation. In
1983, he received the DeFlorez Training Award from the American Institute of
Aeronautics and Astronautics for outstanding achievement in the application of
flight simulation to aerospace training and research. In 1988, Professor Howe received the Society for Computer Simulation International Technical Award.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Robert
M. Howe Professor Emeritus of Aerospace Engineering.
Edward E. Hucke, professor of materials and metallurgical engineering, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1991.
Professor Hucke received his S.B.; S.M., and Sc.D. degrees from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1951, 1952, and 1954, respectively. After a
two-year tenure as director of research and development at the Locomotive
Finished Materials Company in Atchison, Kansas, he joined the faculty of the
Department of Chemical and Metallurgical Engineering in the College of Engineering as an assistant professor in 1955. He was promoted to associate


-71 -



September Meeting, 1991


professor in 1958 and to professor in 1961.
During his career at the University of Michigan, Professor Hucke developed
a world-recognized reputation in research on carbon-based materials, including
glassy carbon and carbide compounds. He utilized elegant thermodynamic analysis in much of his research and taught the subject of thermodynamics in rigorous
fashion to students of materials engineering for several decades.
Professor Hucke has received prestigious awards for his teaching and research accomplishments, including the Gustav Lilliequist Award of the Steel
Founders Society in 1956, the Outstanding Young Engineer Award of the Engineering Society of Detroit in 1961, and the Bradley Stoughton Award of the
American Society of Metals in 1963. He is a fellow of the American Institute of
Chemists and ASM International.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his dedicated service by
naming Edward E. Hucke Professor Emeritus of Materials and Metallurgical Engineenng.
Marion E. Jackson, associate dean for external relations and associate professor of art, retired from active faculty status on June 30, 1991, after a productive career as an administrator, art historian, teacher, and researcher.
Professor Jackson received her A.B. degree in English in 1963, her M.
degree in guidance and counseling in 1964, her M.A. degree in history of art in
1980, and her Ph.D. degree in history of art in 1985, all from the University of
Michigan. Her service to the University of Michigan began in 1968, when she
was appointed assistant to the assistant dean for external relations in the College
of Literature, Science, and the Arts. She went on to serve as director of
freshman-sophomore advising in the college of LS&A from 1970-73, director of
academic advising from 1973-75, and assistant dean in the College of LS&A from
1973-83. In 1986, Professor Jackson was appointed associate dean for external
relations and assistant professor of art in the School of Art; she was promoted to
associate professor in 1990.
Professor Jackson has taught in the Department of History of Art (1981-82)
and in the School of Art (1986-91) at the University of Michigan, as well as in the
Department of Art at Eastern Michigan University (1983-84). She has also
served as an associate editor in the University's Office of Development, a writer
and narrator for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, and a curator for art
exhibitions.
A recipient of multiple Rackham Research Grants, Professor Jackson has
also received numerous other grants and fellowships from such organizations as
the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Michigan Council for the Arts and the Canadian Department of Indian
Affairs for field study with Inuit artists in the Northwest Territories.
Over the years, Professor Jackson has published many articles, catalogs and
narratives, including the Par exhibition catalog (1988); Ruth Weisberg: Paintings,
Drawings, Prints 1968-88 (exhibition catalog, 1988); Contemporary Inuit Drawings
(exhibition catalog, 1987, with essays by Judith Nasby and Nelson H. Graburn);
and The Vital Vision: Drawings by Ruth Annaqtuusi Tuluriak (exhibition catalog,
with David F. Pelly, 1986).
The Regents now acknowledge the contributions of this distinguished faculty
member by naming Marion E. Jackson Associate Professor Emeritus of Art.
William J. Oliver, M.D., professor of pediatrics and communicable diseases
in the Medical School, retired from active faculty status on August 31, 1991.
Bomrn in Blackshear, Georgia, Dr. Oliver attended Georgia Southwestern


-72 -



September Meeting, 1991


College and Mercer University before entering the University of Michigan
Medical School in 1944. After graduating cum laude in 1948, he served as an
intern and resident during the next two years in the Department of Pediatrics.
After serving in the U. S. Navy from 1950-52, he returned to Ann Arbor to
complete his residency training in pediatrics. In 1953, Dr. Oliver was appointed
instructor in the Department of Pediatrics; he was promoted to assistant professor in 1956, associate professor in 1961, and professor in 1965.
In the late 1950s, Dr. Oliver served simultaneously as chief of the pediatric
service at Wayne County General Hospital and director of the pediatric faboratories at the University of Michigan Hospitals. In 1967, he was appointed chair of
the Department of Pediatrics and served admirably for the next 12 years. Under
his leadership, the Department of Pediatrics gained national prominence and its
clinical and teaching programs expanded dramatically, especially after the opening of C. S. Mott Children's Hospital in 1969 and the Holden Perinatal Unit in
1972. Dr. Oliver is especially well-known for his research on salt and water metabolism; his descripton of the hormonal response to sodium chloride deprivation in isolated Indian communities will remain unique. Dr. Oliver also made important contributions toward assuring the lifelong education of pediatricians; he
was instrumental in establishing Pediatrics In Review and the process of recertification of pediatricians.
Dr. Oliver has accumulated numerous awards and has been recognized by
many local and national organizations. He is a member of Alpha Omega Alpha
and Gamma Sigma Epsilon honorary societies. He also belongs to the Society
for Pediatric Research and the American Pediatric Society, and has served as
president of the Scientific Advisory Board of the Michigan Kidney Disease Foundation. In 1979, he received the Grulee Award of the American Academy of Pediatrics for outstanding service to the academy.
At the University of Michigan Medical Center, Dr. Oliver played important
roles in the planning of the Kresge Research Buildings, the C. S. Mott Children's
Hospital, the Holden Perinatal Uit, and the James L. Wilson Laboratories for
Pediatric Research. Under his leadership, the Department of Pediatrics' postgraduate training programs expanded impressively, while his dedication to high
quality teaching and patient care set an example for all faculty and trainees.
Throughout his career, Dr. Oliver has been regarded as an especially effective
teacher of general pediatrics. After completing his tenure as chair, he continued
to function as an important member of the Divisions of Pediatric Nephrology and
General Pediatrics.
The Regents now salute this distinguished clinician, scholar, and teacher by
naming William J. Oliver Professor Emeritus of Pediatrics and Communicable
Diseases.
A. Raymond Roth, associate professor of music at the University of
Michigan-Flint, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1991, after a most
productive career as a teacher, musician, and department leader.
Professor Roth received his B.Mus.Ed. degree from James Milliken University in 1950, his M.Mus.Ed. degree from the University of Illinois in 1954, and his
Ph.D. degree from Michigan State University in 1973. Professor Roth came to
Flint in 1973 as assistant professor of music and was promoted to associate professor of music in 1976.
Professor Roth is the founder of the music department at the University of
Michigan-Flint. Already a band and orchestra conductor of high reputation in
the state, he developed a department that from the outset dedicated itself to the
preparation of first-rate music educators. His vision and leadership enabled the


-73 -



September Meeting, 1991


program to grow steadily to the high level of maturity and quality it enjoys today.
He has exchanged podiums with well-known conductors in the Midwest and m
Switzerland, and conducted United States debuts of many works for band composed in Europe and Asia. He is to be commended for 18 years of outstanding
commitment to the University of Michigan-Flint.
The Regents now salute this distinguished musician for his dedicated service
by naming A. Raymond Roth Associate Professor Emeritus of Music.
Robert W. Schmidt, M.D, professor of pathology, retired from active faculty
status on May 31, 1991.
Dr. Schmidt attended the University of Toledo from 1946-50, receiving his
B.S. degree magna cum laude. He completed his medical education at The Ohio
State University, receiving his M.D. degree, cum laude, in 1954, after which he
undertook a rotating internship (pathology major) at the University of Michigan
from 1954-55. He completed his residency training in the Department of Pathology at the University of Michigan from 1955-59.
Upon completion of his traiinig, Dr. Schmidt accepted a position as an instructor in the Department of Pathology at the University of Michigan Medical
School in 1959. He was promoted to assistant professor in 1961, associate professor in 1965, and professor of pathology in 1969. Dr. Schmidt was assigned to
duties at Wayne County General Hospital, later changed to Westland Hospital,
from 1956-85. He transferred to the Department of Pathology at the University
of Michigan Medical Center in 1985 when the University programs closed at the
Westland Hospital facility.
Dr. Schmidt is one of the Department of Pathology's experts in the field of
cytopathology and gynecologic pathology. Both he and Dr. Bernard Taylor have
played an important role in the education of residents in the pathology clinical
program.
Dr. Schmidt has distinguished himself by his dedication to diagnostic and
consultative services in the Department of Pathology. His long years of
dedicated teaching of medical students and residents, as well as his highly effective role in clinical activities of the Department of Pathology, represent enduring
contributions that will have impacts for years to come.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his dedicated
service by naming Robert W. Schmidt Professor Emeritus of Pathology.
Jules A. Shafer, professor of biological chemistry, retired from active faculty
status on August 31, 1991, after a highly productive career as a teacher and scientific investigator.
A native of New York, Professor Shafer took undergraduate studies at the
City College of New York, where he received his B.Eng. degree in chemical engineering in 1959. He received his Ph.D. degree in chemistry from the Polytechnic
Institute of New York in Brooklyn in 1963.
After completing his doctoral studies, Professor Shafer accepted a position as
a postdoctoral fellow and tutor in the Department of Chemistry at Harvard University. He held that title until 1964, when he was named assistant professor of
biological chemistry at the University of Michigan. He was promoted to associate professor in 1969, and to full professor in 1977. He has been vigorous in
research and in teaching, has contributed significantly to the present strength of
the Department of Biological Chemistry, and is known internationally for his innovative research contributions in the areas of reaction mechanisms for enzymes
and protein-protein interactions.
The Regents now salute this distinguished scientist and health educator for
-74 -



September Meeting, 1991


his dedicated service by naming Jules A. Shafer Professor Emeritus of Biological
Chemistry.
Peter 0. Steiner, professor of economics and dean emeritus of the College of
Literature, Science, and the Arts, and professor of law in the Law School, retired
from active faculty status on August 31, 1991, after a remarkably productive
career as a scholar, teacher, researcher, and administrator.
Born in New York City, Professor Steiner received his A.B. degree, magna
cum laude, from Oberlin College in 1943. After serving in the U.S. Navy during
World War II, Professor Steiner received his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from
Harvard University in 1949 and 1950, respectively. He taught at the University of
California at Berkeley from 1949-57, and at the University of Wisconsin from
1957-68. In 1968, he joined the University of Michigan faculty as professor of
economics and professor of law.
At Michigan, Professor Steiner was instrumental, both in the classroom and
as chair of the Department of Economics, in revising the core graduate and undergraduate economics courses. He also taught industrial organization at the
graduate and undergraduate levels. In the Law School, he was instrumental in
developing the law and economics program and the joint degree program in law
and economics. He also taught antitrust law, including detailed analysis of legal
procedures.
Professor Steiner's research in economics has spanned a number of fields.
His early work was largely on theory and method; his latest on law and economics. In between, and throughout his career, his work has generally been concerned with connections between economic analysis and public policy, broadly
construed. His most famous theoretical work, on the problem of peak-load pricing of public utilities, addresses a very practical problem, and has affected the
way in which public utility pricing is undertaken. Virtually all of his published
work is of both academic and more practical interest. In this, and in his lively
interest and engagement in his colleagues' and his students' work, he has
exemplified the best traditions of the economics department and the Law School.
Professor Steiner chaired the economics department from 1971-74, and
served as dean of the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts from 1981-89.
He was president of the American Association of University Professors from
1976-78, and has held numerous other distinguished posts, both within and without the University. He brought to the administration the same combination of
intellectual power and appreciation of practical necessity that typify his academic
work.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his many contributions to the University of Michigan by naming Peter 0. Steiner Professor
Emeritus of Law, Professor Emeritus of Economics, and Dean Emeritus.
Memorials
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously adopted the following memorial statement:
The Regents of the University acknowledge with profound sadness the death
of Gary N. Davidoff, M.D., director of research and assistant professor of physical
medicine and rehabilitation.
Dr. Davidoff died at his home in Ann Arbor on August 29, 1991, after a long
illness. A 1981 graduate of Wayne State University School of Medicine, he
completed his residency in physical medicine and rehabilitation at Northwestern


-75 -



September Meeting, 1991


University and the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago in 1984. In 1986, he
received his M.S. degree in clinical research design and statistical analysis from
the University of Michigan School of Public Health.
Dr. Davidoff had a spectacular, although brief career in physiatry. He joined
the University of Michigan faculty as an instructor of physical medicine and rehabilitation in 1985, and rapidly progressed through the academic ranks. In May
1991, the Regents approved Dr. Davidoffs promotion to associate professor of
physical medicine and rehabilitation, with tenure. In his shortened career, he
published over 30 papers on chronic pain, spinal cord injury, and traumatic brain
injury; was principal investigator on many externally funded scientific investigations; and received a National Institutes of Health Clinical Investigator Development Award. His strengths as a researcher in medical rehabilitation were
marked not only by his accomplishments in the Department of Physical Medicine
and Rehabilitation at the University of Michigan, where he served as director of
research, but also at the Ann Arbor Veterans Administration Medical Center,
where he was chief of rehabilitation medicine until 1990. His expertise was further recognized through his collaborative studies with colleagues at the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago, the Rehabilitation Institute of Michigan, Ben Gurian
University of the Negev, and the Sackler School of Medicine, Tel Aviv University, Israel. Shortly before his death, Dr. Davidoff was honored by receiving a
Fulbright Lectureship Award to pursue his research in Israel.
A tireless worker on behalf of academic goals in the field of medical rehabilitation, Dr. Davidoff was associate editor of Rehabilitation of Neurologic
Disabilities and NeuroRehabilitation: An Interdisciplinary Journal As a teacher, he
was sought out and praised by residents and medical students, and as a mentor,
he was an advocate and advisor to many faculty, trainees, and students. As a clinician, Dr. Davidoff demonstrated his versatility with patients in the full range of
physiatric settings â€”inpatients, outpatients, consultations, and in the electrodiagnostic laboratory.
Dr. Davidoff will be sorely missed by those who knew and loved him. The
communities of medical rehabilitation and academic medicine are lessened by his
departure. Our condolences go to his wife Karen, their children, Shira, Zvi, and
Noam; his parents, Ronald and Rita Davidoff of Oak Park, Michigan; and his
brother, Mark Davidoff of West Bloomfield, Michigan.

coverage of the University's outstanding obligation secured by a pledge of
student fees. This report was submitted in response to a request by the Regents
at their July 1991 meeting.


-76 -



September Meeting, 1991


Water Street Renovation Project
Chancellor Jones informed the Regents that the State Building Authority had
not yet sold the bonds intended to provide $1.9 million of the cost of the Water
Street Pavilion Renovation Project. This $1.9 million was to be used to pay off
the Mott Foundation mortgage on the pavilion and serve as the source of the
grant money from the Mott Foundation to the University to finish the renovation
of the pavilion.
Due to the need for access to the capital outlay during the renovation of the
pavilion, the Mott Foundation has agreed to extend its $1.9 million grant to the
University prior to receiving payment from the State Building Authority. Because of restrictions concerning Mott's grant process, the University has agreed
to repay this grant to Mott, if State Building Authority financing is not available
by December 15, 1991. Should that occur, Chancellor Jones reported that funds
had been identified to cover this repayment. However, it is not anticipated that
this will be necessary, since the State Building Authority expects funding to be in
place before that deadline.

unanimously approved purchase of the property at 1055 Wall Street, Ann Arbor,
at a price of $95,000.

Veterans Administration Hospital Easement
In conjunction with a project to install a North Campus duct bank for the
telecommunications department, the Veterans Administration Hospital has requested a 12-foot easement for installing and servicing the cable that will be located in a 4-inch duct that is part of this project.
Regent McFee moved approval of the easement as described; Regent Power
seconded the motion. Regent Nielsen asked why the University was not giving a

Proposed Research Subcontract between the University of Michigan and EP
Systems
On a motion by Regent Nielsen, seconded by Regent McFee, all six regents
present unanimously approved a subcontract between the University of Michigan
and EP Systems (Regents Baker and Brown were away from the table when the
vote was taken). Because the owner of EP Systems, Janice Jenkins, is also an
employee of the University, this contract falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance
with statutory requirements:


-79 -



September Meeting, 1991


1.  Parties to the agreement will be EP Systems and the Regents of
the University of Michigan.
2.  The proposed agreement is a standard University research contract. There are no restrictions on publication or openness of the
research. The project involves the evaluation by the GSRA of
software previously developed by EP Systems. Testing of the software will be done using clinical data already stored by Dr. Jenkins
in the Medical School Computing Laboratory of the electrical engineering and computer science department or to be obtained by
EP Systems during its conduct of the Phase II study.
The subcontract will provide 25 percent research assistant
support, related fringe benefits, supplies, and indirect cost (on
campus research rate of 57 percent) over a twelve-month period.
Dr. Jenkins will supervise the project and act as project director.
The total amount of the subcontract is $13,500.
3.  During the academic year, Dr. Jenkins will be reimbursed for her
time on the project as an employee of the company. This salary
will not exceed 20 percent of Dr. Jenkins' University salary. Dr.
Jenkins owns one-half of the company. EP Systems will retain all
rights to the software which it previously developed and which is
being tested in this project.

Definition of Family for Housing Eligibility
Regent Nielsen observed that several of the speakers at the previous day's
Public Comments session had expressed concern about a possible change in the
definition of "family" for purposes of eligibility for family housing. He said he
was concerned that an orgamnzation had misrepresented a report as having been
University-sponsored. He also expressed concern that such a report had emanated from the Affirmative Action Office, and said that more control might have


-80 -



September Meeting, 1991


been exerted over that office to prevent it from having purveyed the misleading
information.
Regent Nielsen stated that he did not think it appropriate to change the definition of what constitutes a family unit, and that the Regents ought to send a
message that it should remain the same. He then offered the following resolution:
'The University of Michigan Board of Regents reaffirms the existing eligibility
requirements for family housing."
Regent Smith stated that she wholeheartedly supported Regent Nielsen's
resolution and seconded the motion.
Regent Power questioned whether adoption of this resolution would cut off
the ordinary managerial and administrative processes that the Housing Division
uses to set rules and eligibility requirements for various kinds of University housing.
Regent Waters observed that it might be preferable for the Board to state
that the Housing Division could not make any changes without coming to the
Board for approval. The policy would stay as it is unless the Regents approve a
change.
Regent Nielsen stated that he thought it was necessary to make this statement now because of the disruption this issue is causing in family housing units.
He reiterated that a report had come from the Affirmative Action Office that
gave the impression it was University-sponsored, when it was not. It was clarified
that there were two reports, one that had come from the Affirmative Action
Office, and a second that had come from Student Legal Services, the latter of
which had been the subject of public comments.
Regent Nielsen then noted that Student Legal Services was funded from student fees, and that perhaps there ought to be a negative budget proration to
reduce student fees going to pay for this type of lobbying by Student Legal Services.
Regent Waters moved to table this issue until the next meeting, so that
more information could be obtained. Regent Baker stated that he did not think
more information was needed. The motion to table e died for lack of a second.
Regent Nielsen reiterated that he felt it was important for the Regents to
send a message that the study by the Affirmative Action Office had not been authorized by the Board, and that his resolution merely reaffirmed the policies already in place.
Regent Brown stated his view that unless someone made a motion to
change the currently existing guidelines, it would be inappropriate procedurally
to do anything. Regent McFee said that she did feel a statement from the Board
was necessary, and that regardless of the source, the implication was that this is
something the University is contemplating, and this has created a great deal of
concern. She felt it appropriate that it be stated that no change is pending.


-81 -



September Meeting, 1991


Regent Varner questioned how the housing office had been responding.
Regent Baker stated his understanding that housing is backing a similar motion
to that offered by Student Legal Services. He observed that this is part of a frontal attack on changing the definition of a family, and thought it is important that
the University be on record to state that it does support the traditional family.
Regent Brown pointed out that such an action might lead to procedural
problems, where the Regents would be called upon monthly to reaffirm actions
they have already taken. He felt it should be clear to the public that no Regents
were proposing that the policy be changed in any way. Regent Baker observed
that he felt the effect would be just the opposite; not passing a resolution would
be encouragement to go forward with the change.
Regent Power noted that the institution of public comments is becoming an
institution in which issues are raised which cause the Board to put itself in a position where it has to respond instantly to issues that are raised at Public Comments sessions. People who are skilled in political theater are going to raise various policy issues at Public Comments sessions repeatedly, each time triggering an
immediate Board response to the problems that are raised in that manner. So
the question is how the Board can make its policy judgments clear and at the
same time not engage in micromanagement.
Regent Nielsen pointed out that this issue did not arise from public comments, but rather, from a study issued by the Affirmative Action Office which was
not officially authorized by the institution. This leaves the impression that the
proposal under question was proposed by the University, and that is why he felt it
is important to address the issue now.
Regent Power suggested holding any action for a month to give the Regents
a chance to read the report. Regent Brown reiterated his opinion that even
though he agreed with the intent ofRegent Nielsen's motion, it was not necessary
procedurally to reaffirm an existing policy. As to whether or not the affirmative
action report was sanctioned by the University, that was a matter for the president and administration to deal with.
Regent McFee stated that she felt it would be appropriate for the Regents
to assert that changing family housing eligibility rules was not under
consideration by the Regents. Regent Varner stated her agreement with Regent
Brown that as a procedural matter, it was not necessary to reaffirm an existing
policy, although she would support a statement that until some other action is
taken the definition would stay the same.
Regent Baker pointed out that in the past, issues have been raised at Public
Comments that were later acted on by the Board, including investment in South
Africa and SDI. Regarding the affirmative action report on the status of lesbians
and gay men, Regent Baker commented that he had been criticized in the report
because of his personal religious beliefs. He stated that he was offended by this
and did not think it appropriate for a University publication to attack a Regent
for his religious beliefs. He also noted that Regent Power had been mentioned
in this report in a more favorable light, as somewhat of a folk hero, and that perhaps other Regents had as well. Regent Baker concluded that to have public
money used for specific narrow-focus issues constitutes inappropriate expenditure of public funds.


-82 -



September Meeting, 1991


Regents Brown and Power reiterated their belief that even though the Regents might agree with the substance of the motion, as a procedural matter, it was
inappropriate for the Regents to take action reaffirming an existing policy.
Regent Power also pointed out that the Regents had not seen the reports that are
the subject of the discussion.
It was decided to take a short recess.
Following the recess, Regent McFee introduced the following substitute
motion:
The Regents have considered the question of the eligibility policy concerning

Regent Power commented that although this motion was superior to the original

sad he would therefore abstain from voting.

Regents' Statement Concerning Indirect and Direct Overhead Costs for Federally Funded Research Projects
The Regents of the University of Michigan are deeply concerned over the allegations of improper research overhead cost allocation recently disclosed in the media.


-83 -



September Meeting, 1991


The Regents and the administration constantly work, on behalf of the people of
Michigan, to protect the integrity of the University. Even a '.perceived" compromise
of that integrity is a matter of serious concern to the Regents. But everyone should be
clear that at no time does the HHS audit report allege or suggest that any funds were
misspent by the University. The proper expenditure of the people's money has the
Regents' highest priority.
All University expenditures including research overhead charges, undergo multiple levels of audit, both internal and external In addition, the Department of
Health and Human Services (HHS) has annually audited the University research
allocations since 1956 Some costs are allowed, some are not allowed. The final
allocation of costs has always been a matter of good faith and arms length
negotiation.
The real issue is to make sure that the legitimate overhead costs of running the
University are allocated fairly and within government guidelines between a cost pool
that relates to research and a cost pool that relates to instruction. It is important for
the people of Michigan to realize that if the federal government is going to change the
rules which govern how costs are allocated between research and instruction cost
pools or arbitrarily to put a cap on the percent of indirect cost overhead charged for
research, it is Michigan taxpayers and students and families who pay tuition who will
pick up the bill It may or may not be legitimate for the federal government to try to
shift the costs of doing contract research from Washington to the state universities.
But it needs to be made quite clear who will pay if costs are shifted.
The Michigan congressional delegation should be advised by the University administration of the importance of clearly defining educational costs and research
costs in the research overhead equation.
The Regents, of course, strongly believe that universities are accountable and
should properly and appropriately expend federal and state research dollars. The
University will now turn its attention to resolving those differences, clarifying the relevant federal guidelines and modifying its own procedures where appropriate We are
confident that the University's integrity will be maintained throughout this process.
Whatever the outcome of this current and important national debate on
funding federal research, the Congress must recognize that the public research
universities of this country are one of the great engines of the American economy and
vast contributors to the public good
There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned. The next
meeting is scheduled for October 17 and 18, 1991. Regents' transportation, accommodation, telephone, and miscellaneous expenses for the months of July and
August, 1991, totalled $4,455.50 and $142.59, respectively.

AN ORDINANCE TO REGULATE PARKING AND TRAFFIC,
AND TO REGULATE THE USE AND PROTECTION OF THE BUILDINGS
AND PROPERTY OF THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
WHEREAS, Article VIII Section 5 of the Michigan Constitution of 1963 provides that The
Regents of The University of Michigan and their successors in office shall constitute a body
corporate and vests therein the generalsupervision of said University; and
WHEREAS, Section 5 of Public Act 151 of 1851, a as amended (Michigan Compiled Laws Annotated, Section 3905) provides that tahe said Regents shall have power to enact orinances, by-laws,
and regulations for the government of said University; and
WHEREAS, Section 3 of Public Act 151 of 1851 as amended (Michigan Compiled Laws Annotated, Section 3903), provides that the government of the University is vested in said Regents; and
WHEREAS, Section 1 of Public Act 80 of 1905, as amended (Michigan Compiled Laws Annotated, Section 19.141), provides that the said Regents shall have authority to make and prescribe
rules and regulations for the care, preservation, and rotection of buildings and proper  dedicated
and appropriated to the public use, over which te said Regents have jurisdiction or power of
control and the conduct of those coming upon the property thereof, which may be necessary for the
maintenance of ood order and the protection of said state property, and further provides that the
said Regents shall have authority to enforce such rules and regulations; and
WHEREAS, Section 1 of Public Act 291 of 11967 (Michigan Compiled Laws Annotated, Section
390.891), authorizes said Regents to enact parking traffic and pedestrian ordinances for the
government and control of its campuses, and to i  fines for vioations of such ordinances; and
Section 3 of that Act permits said Regents to establish a Parking Violations Bureau as an exclusive
agency to accept admissions of responsibility in cases of cvil infraction violations of any parking
ordinance and to collect and retaines and costs as prescribed in the ordinance for such violations;
and
WHEREAS, pursuant to the above-designated authority and in discharge of the responsibility
imposed thereby The Regents of The University of Michigan deem it necessary to adopt an
ordinance and rules and regulations for the care, preservation, protection, and government of
University property, for the conduct of persons coming upon said property, for the regulation of the
driving and parking of motor vehicles vecle les and bicycles upon sd property for the removal and
impoundment of motor vehicles, vehicles and bicycles abandoned thereon; for the maintenance of
good order; and for the promotion of public health, safety, and general welfare in and upon said
property;
NOW THEREFORE, THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN HEREBY
ORDAIN'AS FOLLOWS:
ARTICLE I
GEOGRAPHIC SCOPE
Section 1.  Geographic Scope of Ordinance. This Ordinance shall apply solely to the Ann Arbor
campus of The University of Michigan which, for the purposes of this Ordinance, is
deemed to include all Ann Arbor campus property owned or leased by The Regents
of The University of Michigan.
ARTICLE II
TRAFFIC AND PARKING
Section 1.  Definitions. Words and phrases used in this Article shall have their usual and
customary meaning provided, however, that all words defined in the Michigan
Uniform Traffic Code (1981 AACS, R.28.1101 et seq.) as amended, and used in this
Article, shall have the meaning specified therein; provided, further, that the following
words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this
section:
(1) Alley. Any minor thoroughfare, opened to public use, for purposes of ingress and
egress to service adjacent buildings.


-85 -



September Meeting, 1991 - Appendix A


(2) Bicycle. Every device having two (2) tandem wheels, either of which is over twenty
(20) inches in diameter, propelled by human power upon which any person may ride.
(3) Bus. Every public motor vehicle designed for carrying more than seven (7)
passengers and used for the transportation of persons; and every motor vehicle, other
than a taxicab, designed and used or the transportation of persons for compensation.
(4) Bus stand. A fixed area in the roadway parallel and adjacent to the curb to be
occupied exclusively by buses for layover in operating schedules or waiting for
passengers.
(5) Center or centerline. A continuous or broken line marked upon the surface of a
roaway by paint or otherwise to indicate each portion of the roadway allocated to
traffic proceeding in the two (2) opposite directions, and if the line is not so painted
or otherwise marked, it is an imaginary line in the roadway equally distant from the
edges or curbs of the roadway.
(6) Crosswalk. That portion of street ordinarily included within the prolonging or
connection of the lateral lines of sidewalks at intersections.
(7) Curb loading zone. A space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles
licensed as commercial vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight.
(8) Holiday. Where used in this Ordinance or on official signs erected pursuant to this
Ordinaice shall in addition to Sundays mean the following legal holidays, to wit: New
Year's Day Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Dav, Thanksgiving Day,
Christmas Day and any other holiday excluding Saturdays, when the University is
officially dosed.
(9) Intersection. The area embraced within the prolongation of the lateral lines or, if
none, then the lateral boundary lines of two (2) or more roadways which join one
another at an angle whether or not such roadway crosses the other.
(10) Motor vehicles. Every vehicle which is self propelled.
(11)Parking meter zone. An area adjacent to a parking meter set aside for the exclusive
use of vehicles upon the deposit of a coin of United States currency in said parking
meter as specified thereon.
(12) Right-of-way. The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway.
(13) Stop. When required, means complete cessation of movement.
(14) Sto. stoing or standin. When prohibited, means any stopping or standing of a
vehicle whether occupied or not, other than the temporary stopping of a passenger
vehicle for the purpose of and while actually engaged  pickingup and dischargmg
passengers, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance
with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal.
(15) Taxicab. A motor vehicle licensed under the City of Ann Arbor Ordinance Code.
(16) Taxicab stand. A fixed area in the roadway parallel and adjacent to the curb set aside
for taxicabs to stand or wait for passengers.
(17) Time.
(a) Official time standard. Whenever certain hours are named herein, they shall
mean standard time or daylight saving time, as may be in current use at the
University.
(b) Day time. Time between thirty (30) minutes before sunrise and thirty (30)
minutes after sunset.
(c) Night time. Time between thirty (30) minutes after sunset and thirty (30)
minutes before sunrise.


-86 -



September Meeting, 1991 - Appendix A


Section 2.  Parking Areas.
(1) Designation of Parking Areas. The Vice President and Chief Financial Officer or the
Vice President's written designee shall designate the available parking lots and
parking structures on property of The Regents of The University of Michigan as
'Restricted Parking Areas" and Open Parking Areas" and shall identify the same by
appropriate signs at the respective entrances thereto.
(2) Restricted Parking Areas. Restricted Parking Areas shall be limited to permit
holders and shall hve the following classifications:
(a) Staff Paid Lots and Structures
(b) Staff Metered Lots and Structures
(c) Tenant Parking Lots and Structures
(d) Student Paid Lots and Structures
(e) Staff-Student Lots and Structures
(3) Open ParkingAreas. Open Parking Areas shall be open to the public and shall have
two classiications:
(a) Unrestricted Metered, Lots and Structures
(b) Unrestricted Free Lots and Structures
(4) Limited-Purpose Parking Areas. Limited-Purpose Parking Areas shall be used solely
as follows:
(a) for the parking of University-owned vehicles
(b) for the parking of such other vehicles as shall display a Loading and Unloading
permit and which shall remain in said Areas no longer than one-half (1/2) hour
or as otherwise designated by the permit.
Section 3.  University Parking Permits.
(1) Rulesand Reulations. University parking permits shall be issued to all faculty and
full-time staff members pursuant to rules and regulations prescribed by the Vice
President and Chief Financial Officer upon payment of the fees prescribed therefor
by said rules and regulations.
(2) Permit Required.
(a) No person shall park a motor vehicle in a Staff Paid Lot or Structure or Tenant
Parking Lot or Structure unless such vehicle shall have affixed thereto (in
accordance with the prescribed rules and regulations) the type of parking permit
required for said Lot or Structure, which has been validly issued to such person
for such vehicle by the Office of Parking Services.
(b) No person shall park a motor vehicle in a Student Paid Lot unless such vehicle
shal have affixed thereto (in accordance with the prescribed rules and
regulations) a Student Paid Permit, which has been validly issued to such person
for such vehicle by the Office of Parking Services.
(c) No person shall park a motor vehicle in a Staff Metered Lot or Structure unless
such vehicle shall have affixed thereto (in accordance with the prescribed rules
and regulations) a University Staff Parking Permit, a University Staff Metered
Permit, or a Guest Parking Permit, which has been validly issued to such person
for such vehicle by the Office of Parking Services.
Section 4.  Rates. The rates for parking in lots and structures operated by The University of
Michigan shall be established by rules and regulations prescribed by the Vice
President and Chief Financial Officer except that the base rate for Staff Paid Lots
and Structures shall be prescribed by the Regents.


-87 -



September Meeting, 1991 - Appendix A


Section 5.  General Prohibitions.
(1) Prohibited Parking. No person shall park a motor vehicle on The University of
Michigan campus except in a duly-designated parking area or except while engaged in
a service, delivery or similar function permitted by the prescribed rules and
regulations. Such person must at all times obey University of Michigan signs
regulating and prohibiting parking in fire lanes and elsewhere.
(2) Prohibited Drivin. No person shall operate a motor vehicle over or upon The
University o Michigan campus except in an area designated as a street, publi drive,
or parking area; or except while engaged in a service, delivery, or similar function
permitted by the prescrnbed rules and regulations.
Section 6.  Obstructing Drive. No person shall park a motor vehicle on The University of
Michian campus n such manner as to obstruct, block, or project into any entrance,
exit, riveway, or aisleway of any parking lot or structure.
Section 7.  Parking Spaces  No person shall park any motor vehicle in any parking lot or arkin
structure other than within the boundaries of the space designated as alocated for the
parkin of a single motor vehicle, by appropriate lies or other markings. Where a
space has been designated for the parking of compact automobiles or other small
vehicles only, and appropriate signs erected, it shall' e unlawful to park a larger or
other type of vehicle thereon so as to extend beyond the designated boundaries of
such space.
Section 8.  Payment of Charges for Nnmetered Parkin. Every person who parks a motor
vehicle in a nonmetered parking lot or parkin structure operated by The University
of Michigan for which a parking charge is made, shall prepay upon entry or shall pay
such charge prior to removing said vehicle from said lot or structure.
Section 9.  Payment of Charges for Metered Parking. In a University of Michigan parking lot or
parking structure where parking charges are collected by means of meters installed
adjacent to the parking spaces in said lot or structure, no person shall:
(1) park a motor vehicle in any metered space without placing a United States coin of
proper denomination in the meter in accordance with the regulations posted on said
meter during the hours the said regulations require the payment of parking charges;
or
(2) permit a motor vehicle in his/her custody, or owned by him/her, to remain in any
metered zone except while lawful parking time appears on the meter regulating the
space occupied by such motor vehicle; or
(3) deface, injure, or tamper with any parking meter installed in any such parking lot or
structure, or open such parking meter.
Section 10.  Prima Fade Evidence - Parkin Violations. In any proceeding for violation of the
parkng provisions of this Ordinance, the registration plate displayed on a motor
vehicle shall constitute in evidence a prima fade presumption that the owner of such
motor vehicle was the person who parked or placed such motor vehicle at the point
where such violation occurred.
Section 11.  Following. Overtaking and Passing.
(1) Drive to Right. Upon all streets of sufficient width a vehicle shall be driven upon the
right half ofthe roadway, and on streets with four or more lanes, within the extreme
riht hand lane, except as follows:
(a) When overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction
under the rules governing such movement;
(b) When the right half of a street is closed to traffic while under construction or
repair;
(c) Upon a street divided into three lanes for traffic under the rules applicable
thereon; or


-88 -



September Meeting, 1991 - Appendix A


(d) Upon a street designated and sign posted for one-way traffic.
(2) Following Too Closely. The driver of a motor vehicle shall not follow another vehicle
more  os     than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard for the speed of such
vehicle, and the traffic upon and the condition of the street.
(3) Passing Vehicles Prceedin in Opposite Directions. Drivers of vehicles proceeding
in opposite directions shall pass each other to the right and upon streets having wdth
for not more than one line of traffic in each direction each driver shall give to the
other at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the roadway as nearly as
possible.
(4) Passing on Left. The following rules shall govern the overtaking and passing of
vehicles proceeding in the same direction, subject to those limitations, exceptions, and
special rules hereinafter stated:
(a) The driver of any vehicle overtaking another vehicle proceeding in the same
direction shall pass at a safe distance to the left thereof, and when safely clear of
such overtaken vehicle shall take up a position as near the right-hand edge of the
main traveled portion of the street as is practicable.
(b) Except when overtaking and passing on the right is permitted, the driver of an
overtaken vehicle shall gve way to te rigt infavor of the overtaking vehicle on
audible signal and shall not increase the speed of his or her vehicle until
completely passed by the overtaking vehicle.
(5) Passing on Riht. The driver of a vehicle may over-take and pass upon the right of
another vehicle only under conditions permitting such movement to be made safely
and in no event by driving off the pavement or main traveled portion of the road-way
and further only when one or more of the following conditions exists.
(a) When the vehicle overtaken is making or about to make a left turn,
(b) Upon a street with unobstructed pavement not occupied by parked vehicles of
sufficient width for two or more fines of moving vehicles in each direction and
when such vehicles are moving in substantially continuous lanes of traffic;
(c) Upon a one-way street, or upon any street on which traffic is restricted to one
direction of movement, where the street is free from obstructions and of
sufficient width for two or more lines of moving vehicles and when such vehicles
are moving in substantially continuous lanes of traffic.
(6) Limitations on Passing. No vehicle shall be driven to the left side of the center of a
two-lane street or in the center lane of a three-lane street in overtaking and passing
another vehicle proceeding in the same direction unless such left side or center lane is
dearly visible and is free of oncoming traffic for a sufficient distance ahead to permit
such overtaking and passing to be completely made without interfering with tie safe
operation of any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction or any vehicle being
overtaken.
(7) No-Passing Zone. No driver of any vehicle shall overtake or pass any vehicle in a
designated no passing zone. There shall be no overtaking or passing on the left at
street intersections.
(8) Three-Lane Streets. Upon a street which is divided into three lanes a vehicle shall
not be driven to the left of the center lane except when making a left turn and shall
not be driven in the center lane except when overtaking and passing another vehicle
where the roadway is clearly visible and such center lane is clear of traffic within a
safe distance or in preparation for a left turn or where such center lane is at the time
allocated exclusively to traffic moving in the direction the vehicle is proceeding and is
signposted to give notice of such allocation
(9) One-Wav Streets. Vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction upon
those streets and parts of streets and in those alleys where signs have been erected
indicating that traffic shall move in only one direction.


-89 -



September Meeting, 1991 - Appendix A


(10) Passin School Bus Stoooed to Receive or Discharge Passengers: Stop in on Streets;
Meeting Bus on DividedHighwaXv Bus Sigmal Lamps and Markings. - -
(a) The driver of a vehicle shall not overtake and pass, or meet and pass, any school
bus which has stopped for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers
and which is displaying 2 alternately flashing red lights s provide herein. All
school buses shall be equipped with such signs and/or lights on the back and
front thereof, with respect thereto, as shall be approved by the State Highway
Commissioner.
(b) The driver of a vehicle overtaking or meeting any school bus which has stopped
and is displaying two alternately lashing red lights located at the same level,
shall bring such overtaking or meeting vehicle to a full stop at least 10 feet from
the school bus and shal not proceed until the visual signals are no longer
actuated. The driver of the school bus, before resuming motion, shall sial
stopped traffic to proceed and shall, when resuming motion, proceed in such a
manner as to allow congested traffic to disperse by keeping the bus as near to
the right side of the road as can be done with safety. Passengers crossing the
road upon being discharged from a school bus shall cross in front of the stopped
schoolbus. At an intersection where traffic is controlled by an officer or a traffic
stop-and-go signal, the school bus driver shall not display the two alternately
flashing red lights, and a vehicle need not be brought to a full stop before passing
any such school bus, but may proceed past such school bus at a speed not greater
than is reasonable and proper and in no event greater than 10 miles per hour,
with due caution for the satety of passengers being received or discharged from
such school bus.
(c) All locations at which school buses propose to stop for the purpose of receiving
or discharging passengers on a University street shall be approved in writing by
the Director of Public Safety or the Director's written designee, prior to the
inclusion of such stop in the route of any school bus.
(d) No school bus driver shall stop the bus for the purpose of receiving or
discharging passengers, knowing such location not to have een approved by the
Director of Public Safety or the Director's written designee, as provided in
subsection (c) unless such stop shall be as the result of an emergency and
necessary for the safety of persons or property.
(e) A school bus driver shall not stop the bus for the purpose of receiving or
discharging passengers, unless the bus is completely visible in its stopped
lsifion to approaching or overtaking drivers of vehicles for a distance of at least
400 feet.
(f) The driver of a vehicle upon any street which has been divided into two roadways
by leaving an intervening space, or by a physical barrier, or clearly indicated
dividing sections so constructed as to impede vehicular traffic, need not stop
upon meeting a school bus which has stopped across the dividing space, barrier
or section.
(g) Every school bus shall, in addition to any other equipment and any distinctive
marking required by law, be equipped with signal lamps mounted as high and
widely spaced laterally as practicable, which shall be capable of displaying to the
front two alternately flashing red lights located at the same level and to the rear
two alternately flashing red lights located at the same level. Said light shall have
sufficient intensity tobe visle from a distance of at least 500 feet in normal
sunlight and may be actuated by the driver of said school bus whenever but only
whenever, such vehicle is stopped or is about to stop for the purpose of'receiving
or discharging school children, but need not be actuated at an intersection where
traffic is controlled by an officer or by a traffic stop- and-go signal.
(h) In any proceeding for a violation of subsection (b) of this section, proof that the
particular vehicle described in the citation, complaint or warrant was in violation
of subsection (b), together with proof that the defendant named in the citation1
complaint or warrant was, at the time of the violation, the registered owner of
the vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a presumption that the registered owner
of the vehicle was the driver of the vehicle at the time of the violation.
