Section 1.  Prohibitions. No person shall while on University roperty or in University buildings
or in University buses, passenger vans or other University vehicles, engage in the
following disorderly conduct:
(1) Urinate or defecate in any building or on any publc street or sidewalk or any place in
view of the public not specifically designated for that purpose.
(2) Summon, without any good reason, by telephone or otherwise, the police security or
fire department, any public or private amblance, or an other service of any kind to
go to any address where the service called is not needed.
(3) Repeatedly initiating a telephone call, and without seaking deliberatel hanging up
or breaking the telephone connection after the telephone call is answered.
(4) Initiate a telephone call, without any good reason, from a telephone connected directly to the University Department of Public Safety, which is commonly known as an
emergency phone.
(5) Fail to identify oneself accurately when requested to do so by a police officer or Department of Public Safety security officer after the officer observes the person commit
a civil infraction, misdemeanor or felony, or when the officer has probable cause to
believe the person has committed a misdemeanor or felony outside of the officer's
presence.
(6) Set any fire upon University property or University buildings except in approved
stoves and grils or as otherwise permitted by University officials by a prior wntmgo
(7) Urinate, defecate, vomit, fight, or engage in any behavior in a University bus, passenger van or other vehicle, such as yell   jumping or throwing objects, which interferes
with the safe operation of the vehicle or the quiet enjoyment of the other passengers
in the vehicle, or commit any other act of disorderly conduct under this Article on a
University bus, passenger van or other vehicle.
Section 2.  Violation Penalty. A person who violates this Article XII is guilty of a misdemeanor
an upon conviction, punishable by imprisonment for not less than ten (10) days and
no more than sixty (60) days, or by a tine of not more than fifty dollars (50.00) or
both.
ARTICLE XIII
NOISE CONTROL: NON-VEHICULAR NOISE
Section 1.  Applicabilitv. The provisions of this Article XIII apply to all sources of sound except:
) motor vehicles; 2) aircraft in flight or in operation at an airport; 3) railroad
equipment in operation on railroad rights of way.
Section 2.  Definitions. As used in this Article XII:
(1) "dB(A)" means the intensity of a sound expressed in decibels read from a calibrated
sound level meter utilizin the A-level weighing scale and the fast meter response, as
specified in American National Standards Institute standards S 1.4-1971.
(2) "Commercial" means a use of the property for purposes other than residential.
(3) "Property line" means the imaginar line which represents the legal limits of propert
(including an apartment, condominium r, room, or other dwelling unit) owned leased
or otherwse occupied by a person, business, corporation or institution. In cases
involving sound from an activity on a public street or other public right of way, the
"property line" shall be the nearest boundary of the public right-of-way.
(4) "Residential" means a legal use of property for temporary or permanent dwelling
purposes.


-119 -



September Meeting 1991 - Appendix A


Section 3.   General Prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to create, assist in creating,
permit, continue or permit the continuance of any unreasonably loud, disturbing,
unusual or unnecessary noise which annoys, disturbs, injures, or endangers the
comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others on University property.
Section 4.   Specific Prohibitions. The following activities are prohibited if they produce clearly
audible sound beyond the property ine of the property on which they are conducted:
(1) The operation, between 10 P.M. and 7 AKM., of power tools or equipment.
(2) The operation, between 10 P.M. and 7 A.M., of any device for killing, trapping, attracting, or repelling insects or other pests.
(3) The sounding, between 10 PAM. and 7 AoM., of any bell, chime, siren, whistle or
similar device, except:
(a) To alert persons to the existence of an emergency, danger or attempted crime;
or
(b) As provided in section 6(5) of this Article.
(4) The operation or playing between 10 P.M. and 7 A.M., of any radio, television, phonograph, drum or musical instrument.
(5) Construction, repair, remodeling, demolition, drilling or excavation work at any time
on Sunday and between 8 P.M. and 7 A.M. Monday - Saturday, except as permitted
by section 6(5) of this Article.
(6) The operation or use between 10 P.M. and 7 A.M. of any loudspeaker, sound amplifier, public address system or similar device used to amplify sounds.
(7) The creation of a loud, unnecessary noise in connection with the loading or unloading
of any vehicle or the opening and  osing or destruction of bales, boxes, crates, or
other containers.
(8) The use of any drums, loud-speakers, musical devices or other instruments or devices
for the purpose of attracting attention by the creation of noise to any performance
show or sale or display of merchandise. The.prohibitions of this section apply even if
the sound level produced by a prohibited activity does not exceed the applicable level
specified in section 5 of this Aricle.
Section 5.  Maximum Permissible Sound Levels. No person shall conduct or permit any activity
that produces a dB(A) beyond his/her property line exceeding the levels specified in
Table I. Where property is used or both residential and commercial purposes, the
residential soundlevels hall be used only for measurements made on the portion of
the property used solely for residential purposes.
TABLE I


USE OF PROPERTY    7 AM. TO    10 P.M. TO
RECEIVING THE SOUND 10 P.M.    7 A.M.
Residential        61 dB(A)    55 dB(A)
Commercial         71 dB(A)    61 dB(A)


Section 6.  Limited Exemptions. The following limited activities are exempted from the sound level
limitations of section 5:
(1) Operation, between 7 A.M. and 10 PM., of power equipment that does not produce a
sound level exceeding 90 dB(A) beyond the property line of the property on which the
equipment is operated.


-120 -



September Meeting, 1991 - Appendix A


(2)  Construction, repair, remodeling, demolition, drilling wood cutting or excavation
work conducted between 7 AM. and 8 P.M. Mondays tough Saturdays, except legal
holidays, which does not produce a sound level exceeding 105 dB(A) beyond he
property line of the property on which the work is being conducted. Also, a person
may engage in such activities at his/her residence between 9 A.M. and 6 P.M. on
Sundays.
(3)  Operation or use, for an noncommercial purpose, of any loud-speaker, sound amplifier public address system, or similar device to amplify spoken words between 7 AM.
and 10 P.M. This exemption applies to the use or operation of mechanical loudspeakers on or from motor vehicles only if a specifc permit for the activit has been
granted by the Vice President and Chief Financial Oficer or the Vice President's
written designee. The Vice President and Chief Financial Officer or the Vice President's written designee shall cause such a permit to issue when it finds the following:
(a)   The applicant has a noncommercial message that cannot be effectively communicated to the public by the other means of communication available.
(b)   The applicant will limit the use of the loud-speakers to times, locations and
sound levels which will not unreasonably disturb the public peace.
(c)   The applicant will not use the equipment in residential areas between 10 P.M.
and 7.M.
(4)  The operation between 7 A.M. and 10 P.M. of any device for killng, trapping, attractng, or repellin insecs or other pests which does not produce a sound level exceeding 83 dB(A) beyond the property line of the property on which the device is operated
(5)  The use for noncommercial purposes or one or more bells or chimes which does not
exceed 90 seconds in duration in an hour.
(6)  Carillon playing between 7 A.M. and 10 P.M.
(7)  Playing or practicing with a single musical instrument between 7 A.M. and 10 P.M.
without electric amplification for not more than one hour a day that does not produce
a sound level in excess of 67 dB(A) beyond the property line of the property on which
the instrument is used.
Section 7.  General Exemptions. The following activities are exempted from the sound level limitations of Section 5:
(1)  Emergency work necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a fire,
accident or natural disaster, or to restore public utilities, or to protect persons or
property from an imminent danger.
(2)  Sound made to alert persons to the existence of an emergency, danger, or attempted
crime.
(3)  Activities or operations of University personnel in the course of their prescribed duties or the activities or operations of other governmental units or agencies.
(4)  Parades, concerts, festivals, fairs or similar activities subject to any sound limits in the
approval by the University.
(5)  Athletic, musical, or cultural activities or events (including practices and rehearsals)
conducted by or under the auspices of the University.
Section 8.  Temporary Exemptions.
(1)  The Vice President and Chief Financial Officer or the Vice President's written designee is authorized to grant a temporary exemption from the maximum permissible
sound levels established by this Article if such temporary exemption would be in the
public interest and there is no feasible and prudent alternative to the activity, or the
method of conducting the activity, for which the temporary exemption is sought.


-121 -



September Meeting, 1991 - Appendix A


(2)  The following factors shall be considered in determning whether to grant a temporary exemption:
(a)   The balance of the hardship to the applicant, the community and other persons
in not grantin  the variantheagainst the averse impact on the health, safety
and welfare ofpersons adversely affected and any other adverse effects of the
granting of the variance.
(b)   The nearness of any residence or residences, or any other use which would be
adversely affected by sound in excess of the limits prescribed by this Article.
(c)   The level of the sound to be generated by the event or activity.
(d)   Whether the type of sound to be produced by the event or activity is usual or
unusual for the ocation or area for which the variance is requested
(e)   The density of population of the area in which the event or activity is to take
place.
(f)   The time of day or night which the activity or event will take place.
(g)   The nature of the sound to be produced, including but not limited to, whether
the sound will be steady, intermittent, impulsive, or repetitive.
(3)  A temporary exemption must be in writing and signed by the Vice President and
Chief Fimancial Officr or the Vice President's written designee and must set forth
the name of the party granted the exemption, the location of the property for which it
is authoredthe dates) and time(s) for which it is effective ana the dB(A) level(s)
authorized. The written exemption must be promptly exhibited to a requesting University representative.
(4)  A temporary exemption may be granted only for the period of time that is reasonably
necessary to conduct the activity, which in no case may exceed 30 days.
Section 9.  Liability of owner. lessee or occupant. If the person responsible for an activity which
violates this Article cannot  determined, the owner lessee or occupant of the property on
which the activity is located shall be deemed responsible for the violation.
Section 10. Violation Penalty. Aperson who violates this Article XIII is guilty of a misdemeanor, and
upon conviction, punishable by imprisonment for not less than ten (10) days and no more
than sixty (60) days, or by a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) or both.

Section 3.  Other Applicable Laws. Nothing contained in this Ordinance is intended to limit the power
of any governmental unit or law enforcement agency to enforce on University of Michigan
property any laws, ordinances, or regulations which otherwise would be enforceable on such
property.
Section 4.  Rules and Regulations. The various articles and sections of this Ordinance shall also be
deemed to be rules and regulations of The Regents of The University of Michigan, within
the meaning of Public Act 80 of 1905 as amended.
Section 5.  Separability. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this Ordinanceis for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such provision shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and
such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining provisions.
Section 6.  Posting. A certified copy of this Ordinance and any amendments thereto, shall be kept for
inspection in the office of the Secretary of the University and shall be posted in at least
three conspicuous places on The University of Michigan campus, and at least one copy shall
be delivered to the Chief of Police of the City of Ann Arbor, one copy to the Sheriff of
Washtenaw County, one copy to each of the District Court Judges of the Fourteenth and
Fifteenth Judicial District Courts, and one copy each shall be delivered for filing at the office of the City Clerk at the City of Ann Arbor and the County Clerk for the County of
Washtenaw.

hereby.

OCTOBER MEETING, 1991


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, October 17, 1991
The Regents met at 2:00 P.M. in the Michigan Room of the Harding Mott
University Center at the University of Michigan-Flint. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Smith, and
Varner. Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, and Vice
Presidents Cosovich, Kelly, Swain, and Womack were also present, as were Chancellors Jones and Wilson. Regent Waters and Vice President Johnson were absent.
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and called on Provost
Whitaker to present the 1992-93 state budget request for the Ann Arbor campus.
1992-93 State Budget Request, Ann Arbor Campus
Provost Whitaker began with a slide presentation that illustrated some of the
public service activities associated with the Ann Arbor campus. He noted that
because these service activities emerge from and are closely connected to instructional and research programs, the strength of these programs is essential, not only
for their direct benefits, but also as a foundation for the programs of service to
the people of Michigan.
There are three components to the University's budget request for 1992-93.
The first is based on the expected inflationary increase of 5 percent in the Higher
Education Price Index (HEPI). Based on the 1991-92 base appropriation, this
would equal $12.9 million.
The second component is related to the operation and maintenance of physical facilities and totals $6.8 million. Operating costs for facilities openings m FY
1993 are projected to be $.9 million, and there is a carry-forward from previously
underfunded operating costs of $2.5 million, for a total request for facilities openings of $3.4 million. The remainder of the physical facilities request, $3.4 million,
is for special maintenance funding to make up for some of the capital outlay
funds that in past years have been appropriated and subsequently rescinded.
The third component of the request consists of $2.1 million for critical academic needs. These include multidisciplinary problem-based studies; expansion
of programs designed to increase the numbers of under-represented minorities
among students and faculty and to encourage the hiring of senior women faculty;
additional resources for financial aid to offset reduced federal support; and improving the international component of all educational programs. A substantial
portion of the funds required or critical academic needs will come from internal
reallocations or from growth in other revenue.
Altogether, the proposed incremental increase in state appropriation for
1992-93 totals $21.8 million. Provost Whitaker noted that the University recognizes that it will be difficult for the state to grant this request, but pointed out


-127 -



October Meeting, 1991


that the University continues to increase the quality and efficiency of its operations through reallocation, cost containment, and Total Quality Management efforts. As evidence of its success in these areas, he pointed out that U.S. News and
World Report had recently ranked the University 37th in resources, but 11th in
overall academic reputation, indicating the University makes prudent use of the
funding available to it.
The president then called on Chancellor Wilson to present the state budget
request for the Dearborn campus.
1992-93 State Budget Request, Dearborn Campus
Chancellor Wilson noted that the UM-Dearbom budget request was heavily
influenced by the strategic planning process of the past 1Y2 years, and thus reflects
three priorities: continuing to provide the highest quality education, insuring that
its facilities are adequately serviced and maintained, and expanding external
partnerships to insure the future economic and educational competitiveness of
metropolitan Detroit and the state of Michigan.
The incremental budget request for UM-Dearborn totals $1,893,000. It includes the following components: inflation estimate of 5 percent ($927,000); new
space operating costs ($348,000); a portion of the $1.7 million backlog in deferred maintenance funding ($340,000); and community service endeavors for expanding partnerships with business, industry, public schools, and other areas
($278,000).
1992-93 State Budget Request, Flint Campus
Chancellor Jones reported that the 1992-93 incremental budget request, like
that of the other campuses, is very modest in deference to the tight state revenue
situation. It includes an inflationary component based on the expected HEPI of 5
percent ($830,300); the remainder of the new facilities operating costs necessary
for the operation of the renovated University Pavilion ($392,000); and 5 program
initiatives. The program initiatives include minority recruitment and retention
($100,000); information technology services ($100,000); academic program enhancements ($250,000); library acquisitions ($100,000); and science building
equipment maintenance ($50,000). The total incremental budget request for the
Flint campus is $1,822,300.
Chancellor Jones distributed a handout of statistical information about
Flint's student population and funding history. With 72 percent of its students residing in Genesee County, he noted that UM-Flint is the most regional of all of
Michigan's public universities, and that the University enjoys a very close relationship with the city of Flint. Because of the significant growth in its enrollment
over the past 10 years, UM-Flint has gone from one of the better funded institutions in terms of FYES to one of the poorest funded.
In the discussion that followed, Regent Baker pointed out the heavy emphasis on all three campuses on public service activities that benefit the communities
in which they exist.


-128 -



October Meeting, 1991


In response to a question from Regent Nielsen, Chancellor Jones stated that
state appropriation and tuition are the major sources of funding for the Flint
campus operating budget. If the state appropriation is decreased, either tuition
would have to be increased or programs would have to be cut. Regent Nielsen
suggested investigating other sources of revenue, such as service activities, that
might be used in the future to enhance the operating budget.
Regent Power asked Provost Whitaker how the budget proposal affects the
quality of the institution's programs, as well as its infrastructure and activities
necessary to sustain the quality of the faculty and the student body. Provost
Whitaker responded that the budget is basically at a standstill. Cost increase
avoidance measures, such as Total Quality Management, are being undertaken.
Rather than being designed to save costs, the goal of these programs is to improve quality using the existing levels of resources, thereby avoiding increased
costs.
President Duderstadt noted that over the past year, public higher education
has experienced a serious erosion in tax dollar support, so that it is increasingly
being supported through a combination of tuition and private support, much like
private higher education.
Following further comments, Regent Nielsen moved approval of the 1992-93
state budget requests for all three campuses. Regent Brown seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.

University of Michigan Policy on Sexual Harassment by Faculty and Staff
President Duderstadt stated that University staff had been reworking the
proposed policy on sexual harassment by faculty and staff in response to comments and suggestions that had been made when it had first been presented to
the Regents in June. He called on Provost Whitaker to present the revised draft
of the policy for information purposes.
Provost Whitaker called to the table Ms. E. Kay Dawson, assistant to the provost and primary author of the policy, and Ms. Elsa Cole, general counsel. The
provost observed that sexual harassment is a serious problem at the University of
Michigan. The proposed policy would provide an internal mechanism for resolving complaints as an alternative to the legal system and the courts, thereby limiting the University's exposure to damages in court. He noted that sexual harassment cases do not involve romance or mutual affection; the common element is
an abuse of power, trust, and authority.
Provost Whitaker noted that the U.S. Supreme Court has unanimously
agreed that sexual harassment is an unlawful form of sex discrimination, and
cited other laws that prohibit sexual harassment. The University's initial policy
was issued in 1980; since that time, members of the University community have
been able to pursue harassment complaints within the University structure, instead of going through the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC)
or the courts. He cited two forms of sexual harassment recognized by the law:
quid pro quo harassment (e.g. conditioning employment or educational benefits
on sexual favors), and hostile environment harassment, which negatively affects
the emotional or psychological stability of workers or students. He then described in legal and monetary terms why and how the University can be held
liable for the conduct of employees who sexually harass their colleagues or students.
Provost Whitaker then enumerated the revisions that had been made in the
current draft of the policy in response to concerns that had been expressed by the
Regents. Regarding false accusations, he said that the data shows that the possibility of this is remote. He noted that most complaints are made informally and
that the complainants want only for the behavior to stop. When complaints warrant investigation, the process is managed with scrupulous confidentiality. If
cases cannot be substantiated, no action is taken against the accused, and under
existing Regental bylaws and Standard Practice Guide provisions, action can be
taken against people who make intentionally false accusations. He emphasized
that the major issue is to make sure that there is an environment that encourages
people who have complaints to come forward to get help, because the University's liability would increase if this is not the case.
Regarding the language on intention and effects, the wording had been
changed per Regent Waters' suggestion. He then addressed the issue of consensual relationships, where the concern is what happens when a relationship that
had appeared consensual at some point in time breaks apart. In this instance, the
policy directs that if a romantic relationship develops between a supervisor and


-131 -



October Meeting, 1991


an employee or student and faculty member, a way be found to remove the person in the supervisory or evaluative position from the decision-making role. He
noted that complaints are seldom raised unless such a relationship is terminated.
The Regents had also raised the question of due process. Provost Whitaker
noted that the policy contains the fundamental due process the law requires, and
he stated what the Supreme Court had determined to be required in the case of
employment relationships. The policy contains the same amount of due process
protection that is afforded University employees in other investigations that precede disciplinary action. In cases which result in a recommendation of dismissal
of a tenured faculty member or faculty member on a term contract in advance of
the expiration date, there is a substantial property interest in continued employment and more elaborate due process is provided by Bylaw 5.09.
Provost Whitaker concluded that the deans are very anxious to have a policy
in place, as a sense of uncertainty exists among faculty about this issue. He said it
was important to get a policy in place, so that we can prevent the public disclosure of these matters that would occur if they were to be litigated in federal
courts. He believed the policy would provide the informal mechanism that would
resolve the concerns of most people.
Regent Baker stated that he believed there ought to be a policy, but he was
not persuaded that due process protections provided to accused individuals were
strong enough. He then read from an article that had appeared in the Michigan
Daily and the Ann Arbor News, "Anita Hill Deserves Thanks for Speaking Out on
Harassment", written by Julie Steiner, coordinator of the University's Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center (SAPAC). Regent Baker observed that
Steiner had alleged that the Board of Regents was similar to the United States
Senate, in that the power structure consisted largely of white men. Regent Baker
pointed out that the Board in fact is made up of a Black man, a Black woman,
two white women, and only four white men, and that a person in Steiner's position should have been aware of this.
Regent Baker then detailed his interpretation of how the matter of the allegation of sexual harassment against Supreme Court nominee Clarence Thomas
would have been handled under the proposed University of Michigan policy.
Thomas initially would not have known the identity of the complainant and an informal hearing would have been held. If a formal hearing becomes necessary,
there is a greater degree of due process, but not as much as there would be in a
court of law. Also, the University of Michigan, with its considerable resources,
can be substituted for the complainant. In the event of a false claim, Mr. Thomas
would have had no relief except to bring a legal action against the complainant,
in which case the University would probably defend the complainant.
Regent Baker noted that tenured faculty members, under the doctrine of
property rights, do have extensive rights of due process, but that employees and
students do not. Regent Baker stated that he applies two tests to every issue that
comes before the Board: 1) the integrity of the process; and 2) the basic fairness
of the process itself. He noted that he would be happy to support a policy that
would protect women against sexual harassment, but that rather than taking the
minimal requirements of the law with respect to due process, the University


-132 -



October Meeting, 1991


should break new ground and add more due process protections in the interest of
fairness.
Provost Whitaker responded that there are several steps that could be taken.
These include a simple inquiry about what constitutes sexual harassment or just
reporting an incident in order to have someone to talk to about it (informal process), similar to the manner in which an employee might bring up any job-related
concern. In the latter case, advice would be given to the complainant as to how
to resolve the problem. If formal action becomes necessary, the accused person
is notified and an investigation takes place to ascertain the facts. Provost
Whitaker emphasized that most victims just want the behavior to stop. He noted
that the goal is to get a policy in place and then to do extensive training both for
the intake workers who would be receiving the complaints and for the University
at large. In the event that a penalty is imposed against the accused as a result of
the investigation, a more judicial-type process can be invoked or the accused
could choose to go to court. But the goal is to stay out of court and to get the behavior stopped.
Regent Varner stated her support for the policy, but expressed concerns
about units that have been moving forward with their own policies. Specifically,
she inquired whether these units have been receiving counsel and guidance from
the Office of the General Counsel. Counsel Cole responded that the units had
been receiving such guidance. She also noted that if the proposed policy were
adopted, the individual units' policies would have to be made consistent with that
policy on any points in which they might differ.
In response to a question from Regent Varner about the training to be provided to the intake workers, Provost Whitaker indicated that there would be extensive training and education for intake workers and others on campus once the
policy is instituted.
The meeting then recessed to hear public comments.
Public Comments
The Regents then heard comments from Carrie Brie, about the definition of
family for family housing purposes.
University of Michigan Policy on Sexual Harassment by Faculty and Staff
Following public comments, the meeting returned to a discussion of the proposed sexual harassment policy, with the provost, Ms. Dawson, and Ms. Cole responding to questions about specific provisions in the policy.
In response to a question from Regent Nielsen, Ms. Dawson stated that the
policy is not geographically specific; it addresses conduct that may occur within
the employment relationship regardless of site (such as on a field trip, professional conference, etc.). Location is one factor to be assessed in evaluating a
claim of sexual harassment.
Regent Nielsen also expressed concern about which offices would be charged
with administering the policy, and with the discretion that those offices would


-133 -



October Meeting 1991


have. Ms. Cole, Ms. Dawson, and Provost Whitaker also responded to Regent
Nielsen's comments about the definition of sexual harassment as stated in the
policy; the treatment of consensual relationships in the policy vis-a-vis the incorporation of the 1986 Senate Assembly statement of principle concerning relationships between faculty and students; the monitoring of external business relationships as provided for in the existing nepotism policy; the consequences of romantic relationships between students and teaching assistants; and the complainthandling procedure.
Regent Smith expressed her support of the need for a policy. However, she
noted tat the policy seems t favor the complainant over the person being accused of harassment, which she believes is a orm of discrimination because the
person being accused would ou not be told of the accusation unless a formal complaint is pursued. In response to a suggestion by Regent Smith that the draft
policy be reviewed by Law School faculty, Ms. Cole responded that many Law
School faculty, including the dean, had already reviewed the policy. Regent
Smith said that she would feel more comfortable if the Law School would state in
writing that they had reviewed the policy.
Ms. Dawson observed that unlike what happened with the student disciminatory harassment policy, the sexual harassment policy is not breaking new
ground. Institutions all over the country have similar policies that address their
roles as employers. Provost Whitaker pointed out that the procedures set forth in
the policy have been tested in case law and in the Supreme Court, and Regent
Brown concurred.
Regent Baker reiterated that it was important that due process procedures
be spelled out in the policy at the outset.
Regent McFee observed that although it was important to respond to the
suggestions that had been made, it was also important to institute the policy as
soon as possible so that employees can seek relief from sexual harassment via a
confidential, internal system. She pointed out that not having any policy at all
put the University at greater risk than having a policy that may have some imperRegent Power stated that at the point where complaints change from informal to formal, a qualitative change occurs. He believed that the Office of the
General Counsel, rather than the Affirmative Action Office, should oversee the
process at that point. He also suggested that it be stated in the policy that
remedy for false accusations is covered through the University's internal grievance procedures.
Following further discussion, it was decided to recess the meeting until the
following day, with the hope that the policy could be revised sufficiently by that
time to be responsive to the Regents' concerns.

October Meeting, 1991
Retirement Memoirs
On a motion by Regent Nielsen, seconded by Regent Waters, the Regents
voted unanimously to adopt the following retirement memoir:
Richard M. Courtney, D.D.S., professor of dentistry in the School of Dentistry and assistant professor of pathology in the Medical School, retired from
active faculty status on August 31, 1991.
Dr. Courtney received his D.D.S. degree in 1959 and his M.S. degree (oral
pathology) in 1967, both from the University of Michigan. After serving in the
t.S. Navy from 1959-62, he had a private dental practice in Franklin Village,
Michigan, from 1962-64. Dr. Courtney served as an assistant professor in the Department of Oral Pathology at the University of North Carolina School of Dentistry from 1967-70. From 1969-70, he also served as a consultant to the Veterans
Administration Hospital in Durham, North Carolina. In 1969, he became director of the section of oral pathology in the Department of Oral Diagnosis at the
University of North Carolina School of Dentistry.
Dr. Courtney came to the University of Michigan in 1970 as an associate professor in the Department of Oral Pathology in the School of Dentistry and an instructor in the Department of Pathology at the Medical School. He was
promoted to professor of dentistry in 1975 and assistant professor of pathology in
1976, and has served in those capacities since then. He served as chair of the
Department of Oral Pathology from 1977-87.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Richard M. Courtney
Professor Emeritus of Dentistry and Assistant Professor Emeritus of Pathology.

Amendment to License Agreement between the University of Michigan and
Chromatofast, Inc.
Regent Smith moved, Regent Varner seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved, modification of a license agreement (originally approved in
May 1991) between the University of Michigan and Chromatofast, Inc. Because
the owners of Chromatofast, Richard D. Sacks, Mark A. Klemp, Christine L.


-148 -



October Meeting, 1991


Rankin, Anita J. Peters, and Ketan M. Trivedi ("Professor Sacks and Employees") are also employees of the University of Michigan, this agreement falls
under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1. Parties to the contract will be the University of Michigan and
Chromatofast, a corporation in which Professor Richard D. Sacks,
Mark A. Klemp, Christine L Rankin, Anita J. Peters, and Ketan
M. Trivedi own stock.
2. Terms of the contract include: a duration for the term of the last
to expire of the licensed patents, and consideration to the University consisting of: a $2,000 license issue fee; payment of royalties,
including minimum royalties, on products utzing the technology;
a share of sublicensing revenues received by Chromatofast; and reimbursement of past and future University patent filing and prosecution costs for the technology. Royalties will be paid to the University at a rate of 4 percent for products sold by Chromatofast
which are covered by one or more patents, and 2 percent for products sold which are covered by know-how. Chromatofast will pay
the University 30 percent of its sublicensing revenues but will not
be required to pay the University a share of revenue received for
continuing research and development by Chromatofast. Minimum
royalties shall commence during the third year of the agreement at
$10,000 and progress each year thereafter to $50,000 in the seventh
and each subsequent year. The University retains ownership of all
technology. The University retains the right to use such technology for research, teaching, and other educationally-related purposes. Chromatofast shall diligently pursue the commercial development and exploitation of the technology covered by the proposed license agreement. There is no use of facilities or services of
the University included in the contract and no assignment of University employees for fulfillment of the contract.
These terms are the same as originally approved, with the exception that the non-exclusively licensed patent is now licensed exclusively, and the reduced royalty rate for that patent has been deleted.
3. Professor Sacks and Employees' pecuniary interest in the contract
arises from their stock ownership, currently consisting of 100 percent of Chromatofast's total authorized shares, which total 5,000
shares of common voting stock. Professor Sacks and Employees'
equity interest will be in lieu of participation in the sharing of royalties received by the University in accordance with University
policy.

Closure of the Division of Interdisciplinary Studies at UM-Dearborn
Chancellor Wilson reported that the propsed closure of the Division of Interdisciplinary Studies and the two items which follow represent an attempt by
the Dearborn campus to ty to clarify its priorities and achieve cost efficiencies,
while at the same time enhancing the quality of its academic programs. She
noted that with the exception of the undergraduat degree in public administration, no programs would be eliminated by this action. The existing programs are
being relocated into the appropriate schools and colleges, where they will be administered by the existing deans and executive committees.
Following some discussion, Regent Varner moved, Regent Brown seconded,
and the Regents unanimously approved, closure of the Division of Interdisciplinary Studies at the University of Michigan-Dearborn and transfer of the degree
programs developed within that division to the appropriate schools and colleges.
Transfer of the Public Administration Program at UM-Dearborn to the School of
Education
Chancellor Wilson informed the Regents that in conjunction with the closure
of the Division of Interdisciplinary Studies, responsibility for administering the
Public Administration Program has been transferred to the School of Education.
Establishment of the Computer and Information Science Department in the
UM-Dearborn School of Engineering
Chancellor Wilson informed the Regents that with the closing of the Division
of Interdisciplinary Studies at UM-Dearborn, responsibility for administering the
Computer and Information Science Program had been transferred to the School
of Engineering. Accordingly, a Computer and Information Science Department
will be created within the School of Engineering.

unanimously approved changes in the dates of the Honors Convocation from
March 29, 1992, to March 22, 1992, and from March 28, 1993, to March 21, 1993.

October Meeting, 1991


University of Michigan Policy on Sexual Harassment by Faculty and Staff
President Duderstadt reported that modifications had been made to the
policy draft in response to Regents' comments the previous day.
Provost Whitaker reviewed the changes that had been made. These include
a statement referring to disciplinary procedures that already exist to address the
filing of false complaints; shortening the section on consensual relationships so
that other documents are not incorporated by reference; explicitly referring to
the involvement of the Office of the General Counsel in the formal investigation
stage; the addition of a sentence stating that steps would be taken to restore the
reputation of an accused person if allegations are not substantiated; clarification
of the section describing the circumstances under which the University would
assume the role of complainant; change in the language regarding who might accompany a person to an investigation; and addition of a statement that the
complaint-handling guidelines will be approved by the Office of the Provost and
the Office of the General Counsel.
Regent Nielsen stated that it was important to have a policy, and suggested
that an interim policy be adopted that would include a sunset clause stating the
policy would terminate in six months, providing this policy incorporate his recommendations for further revision. Regent Nielsen stated he disagreed with several
aspects of the consensual relationships section, and suggested corrections that he
would find acceptable. He asked for several clarifications about the existing disciplinary systems and grievance procedures. In the section about reporting requirements, Regent Nielsen objected to the Office of Affirmative Action being
designated to monitor repeated complaints within the same unit or against the
same individual. Regent Nielsen also commented about the language in the
"General" section that states who may accompany a person to a proceeding and
what that person's role should be. Finally, Regent Nielsen stated that besides
being approved by the Offices of the Provost and the General Counsel, he felt
the complaint handling guidelines should also be approved by the Board of Regents.
In response to a question from Regent Baker, Ms. Cole stated that the role
of the Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center is to provide confidential
counseling; they do not receive official complaints. She also described, in response to, questions from Regent Baker, how the policy is applied with respect to
faculty members as opposed to other University employees, and noted that students are covered not by this policy, but by the Interim Policy on Discrimination
and Discriminatory Conduct by Students in a University Environment.
Regarding the latter policy, Regent Baker observed that he had been critical
of it since its inception and did not think it should exist. He quoted from an article in The American Spectator, written by University of Michigan professor
Joseph Adelson, that is critical of the "political correctness" movement. Regent
Baker mentioned that in the future he may move to end the interim student
policy, and pointed out that policies such as this have become highly controversial. Because of this, Regent Baker stated that he would like the Sexual Harassment Policy to include students, rather than have them covered by the interim
policy on discrimination and discriminatory conduct. He also observed that there
are various levels of due process for the various levels of University staff, and


-151 -



October Meeting, 1991


that he believed that every level of employee should have extensive due process
rights. Regent Baker expressed support for Regent Nielsen's suggestion that the
sexual harassment policy be terminated in six months and reviewed, and reiterated his belief that student conduct should be covered by this policy, rather than
by the interim policy.
Ms. Cole responded that the faculty and staff policy is supported by a welldeveloped body of case law covering the employment relationship. But there is
no equivalent body of case law to provide guidance in the student-to-student situation. This policy is intended to address what is known today, without question,
to be in violation of the law; to include the student arena, in which law is still developing, would complicate the issue. While it is certain that the faculty and staff
policy would stand up in court, there are more uncertainties in the other area, so
that a policy covering students will take longer to develop. Regent Baker stated
that he does not accept the inclusion of sexual harassment policy within the interim student policy on discrimination and discriminatory conduct.
Regent Brown commented that there could never be a policy addressing student conduct that would be acceptable to students. However, the policy under
question addresses an entirely separate issue: sexual harassment by faculty and
staff. He observed that this policy is sensible and needed, and he felt they ought
to move ahead with it.
In response to a question from Regent Brown, Ms. Dawson explained that
the statement in the Consensual Relationships section that "sexual relations...
are a basic violation of professional ethics and responsibility when the faculty
member has any professional responsibility for the students' academic performance..." is a statement of principle by the University faculty on this issue. Ms.
Dawson stated that this langage had een included in every version of the policy
with no objections from the faculty. Regent Brown stated he did not disagree
with this language being included in the policy. Regent Brown also stated he
would be hesitant to change other language in this section that Regent Nielsen
had objected to, since it had been approved by the Senate Assembly.
Regent Brown also stated that the mere fact that a professor becomes romantically involved with a student, whether or not they have any academic relationship, is a legitimate matter of concern for the policy to address. Regents
Nielsen and Brown then exchanged points of view on the consensual relationships portion of the policy. Regarding the reporting requirements section,
Regent Brown stated he did have some concerns that he may address at some
future time.
With respect to Regent Nielsen's suggestion that this policy be approved as
an interim policy, Regent Brown noted that any policy adopted by the Board
could be revised at any time; thus he did not think this was necessary. He concluded that it was important for the Board to adopt the policy soon to send a
message to the University community that the Regents recognize the need for it.
Regent McFee agreed with Regent Brown that it was important to move forward with the policy now, and that the policy as revised provides a climate for
bringing forth sexual harassment concerns in an accessible and confidential
manner. She stated she felt having a policy was important for both the victims


-152 -



October Meeting, 1991


and perpetrators of sexual harassment. She stated her intention to move adoption of the policy, but offered a change in last sentence of the "Reporting Requirements" section, removing the Office of Affirmative Action from having the
responsibility for monitoring repeated complaints. She moved adoption of the
polcy with the inclusion of Regent Nielsen's suggestion that it be adopted for six
months, at which time the policy would be reviewed and re-adopted to reflect the
experience with it up to that time.
Regent McFee accepted a request from Regent Nielsen that her motion include a proviso that language be added to the "General" section stating that a
person could designate a representative who can participate in the proceedings
and appear in his or her absence or inability to attend.
Ms. Cole stated that such a provision would allow an attorney to take charge
of the proceeding, and that this would create an inconsistency, since this practice
is not currently permitted in any other misconduct procedures in the investigative
stage. There followed a discussion about the advisability of allowing attorneys to
represent employees in investigatory proceedings, and about how this is handled
in other grievance proceedings at the University. Ms. Cole suggested that Regent
Nielsen's concerns might be better addressed in the guidelines.
Regent McFee then withdrew from her motion the provision that language
be added allowing a representative to participate in the proceedings and appear
in the absence or inability of the accused to attend. But she requested that that
matter be addressed in the guidelines and addressed when the policy is brought
back to review. In response to a question from President Duderstadt, Regent
McFee clarified that the intent of her motion was that the policy not be labeled
"interim", but that it have a sunset of six months.
Regent Baker seconded the motion.
Regent Varner stated her agreement that a policy needs to be put in place.
Regarding Regent Baker's concerns about due process, she noted that there is a
body of case law supporting the procedures laid out in the policy. She concurred
that it was important for the University community to know that the Regents consider sexual harassment to be a very serious problem that must be addressed.
Regent Varner suggested that the Office of the General Counsel, rather than the
Office of Affirmative Action, be charged with monitoring the policy. She also
stated that because implementation of the policy is an administrative responsibility, she did not think it was necessary for the guidelines to be approved by the
Regents. Regent Varner expressed that the Board should adopt the policy as a
permanent policy, not an interim policy.
President Duderstadt suggested that Regent McFee's motion might be
amended to state that the policy be adopted with the proviso that it be brought
back to the Board for review in six months. This would replace the six-month termination "sunset" clause.
Regent Varner offered an amendment that the policy be adopted and returned to the board in six months, without a sunset provision. Regent Waters
seconded the motion.


-153 -



October Meeting, 1991


Provost Whitaker observed that the policy had been written because there
has been considerable concern among women faculty and staff that a permanent
policy be put in place; that the officers are concerned that a policy exist that reduces the University's legal liability for not having such a policy, and that these
matters be handled in the informal settlement method as much as possible.
Noting that individuals are always free to go to court, he reiterated that the goals
are to keep the matters from escalating to formal legal proceedings, and to stop
the offensive behavior.
Regent Nielsen stated that he had suggested the six-month sunset clause to
give the Regents an opportunity to thoroughly review all aspects of the policy, because they hadn't yet had sufficient time to do so.
Regent Baker spoke in support of Regent Nielsen and against Regent
Varners amendment, and noted that he had substantial objections to the policy,
as he had previously stated. He stated that a sunset clause would give the administration an incentive to address the issues that had been raised by the Regents.
Regent Baker also observed that in light of the hearings for the nomination of
Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court, he expected that federal legislation
would soon be developed that would address these issues, and that this legislation
would include the concept of innocent until proven guilty. Regent Baker also reiterated that student conduct should be included in the sexual harassment policy.
Provost Whitaker pointed out that student-to-student sexual harassment does
not involve the power relationships that are addressed in this policy, and that the
women employees on campus are very concerned about having a comfortable
working environment.
Regent Power spoke in favor of the amendment and in favor of adopting the
policy not as an interim policy. He also noted that sexual harassment is a separate issue from political correctness; sexual harassment has to do with what happens when people in authority relationships over others misuse that authority.
He noted that this policy has been a matter of discussion among faculty for a
number of years, and that the document had undergone considerable review by
the Board and others that had greatly improved it.
Regent Smith suggested that after the policy is revised, experts at the Law
School review it. Counsel Cole responded that leading experts at the Law School
had been consulted during the drafting of this policy, and that their expertise
would continue to be utilized. She also pointed out that she herself had a national reputation in this area, and she was confident that the policy was appropriate.
Regent Baker asked why it was necessary for the language to make any reference to the Interim Policy on Discrimination and Discriminatory Conduct by Students. Ms. Cole and Provost Whitaker responded that the sentence is there to
point out in what areas the policy does not apply.
Regent Brown called the question on Regent Varner's amendment that the
policy be adopted and be brought back to the board for review in six months.
The intent is that in six months the administration would submit a report on implementation of the policy. At the suggestion of Regent Nielsen, the six-month


-154 -



October Meeting, 1991


time period was changed to one year in Regent Varner's amendment. The vote
was then taken on the amendment, and it carried, with Regents Brown, Power,
McFee, Varner, and Waters in favor and Regents Baker, Nielsen, and Smith opposed.
Regent Power then moved to amend Regent McFee's original motion to include the proviso that the Office of the General Counsel, rather than the Office
of Affirmative Action, would be designated to monitor repeated complaints. In
response to a comment by Regent Nielsen about representation at proceedings
for people who could not be present, Provost Whitaker stated he would be willing
to include language addressing that issue in the final version of the policy.
Regent McFee agreed to accept Regent Power's amendment that the statistics would be developed generically by the Office of Affirmative Action, but that
the Office of the General Counsel would monitor repeated complaints.
The vote was then taken on Regent McFee's amended motion; it was approved unanimously.
There being no further discussion, the meeting was adjourned. The next
meeting is scheduled for November 14 and 15, 199 1. Regents' transportation, accommodation, telephone, and miscellaneous expenses for the month of September 1991 totalled $316.33.
Richard L. ennedy, Secretary

Retirement Memoirs
On a motion by Regent Smith, seconded by Regent Nielsen, the Regents
voted unanimously to adopt the following retirement memoirs:
Ralph M. Gibson, professor of psychology in pediatrics and communicable
diseases in the Medical School, retired from active faculty status on October 31,
1991, concluding a career spanning nearly four decades of service.
A native of Cleveland, Ohio, Professor Gibson received his B.S. degree in
1945, his M.S. degree in 1947, and his Ph.D. degree in 1959, all from the University of Michigan. He was appointed an instructor in psychology in the Department of Pediatrics in 1956; he was promoted to assistant professor in 1963, associate professor in 1966, and professor in 1970. He established and became the


-166 -



November Meeting, 1991


head of the Pediatric Psychology Unit in 1965; under his direction, pediatric psychology services began to have a major impact on patient care.
Professor Gibson was one of the early pioneers in the expansion of the child
psychologist's role in pediatrics to include assessment of and intervention for the
effects of illness on the child's psychosocial and developmental status. His clinical and research interests include the effects of trauma in early infancy on later
personality development; he also became a nationally known authority on developmental issues in blind infants through his work with Selma Fraiberg. Large
numbers of clinical psychology interns have benefited from his vast experience
and clinical expertise.
A life fellow of the American Orthopsychiatric Association, Professor Gibson
has also been a member of numerous other professional societies, including the
American Psychology Association, the Michigan Psychological Association, and
the American Association for the Advancement of Science. His administrative
service includes positions as director of counseling services at the Medical School
from 1972-83 and assistant dean for student affairs from 1976-83. He served on
the Board in Control of Intercollegiate Athletics from 1968-74 and again from
1984-87, and has been faculty advisor for the Comprehensive Studies and Opportunity Program since 1984. Hs      d is continued empasis on the pursuit of academic
excellence and demonstrated concern for minority students, their health and welfare recently culminated in the Medical School's establishment of the Ralph M.
Gibson Award which is presented annually to the senior minority medical student
who has best demonstrated these qualities througout his or her medical career.
Professor Gibson received the Wade McCree Distinguished Faculty Award in
1987, and in 1988 was included in an exhibit of the accomplishments of the most
distinguished Ph.D. recipients of the Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate
Studies over the past fifty years. In 1987, Professor Gibson was also honored by
his appointment to the National Advisory Child Health and Human Development Council ofr                                        the National nstitutes of Health. His role  ciensures that children from all backgrounds will benefit from the care and concern
for their well-being that have characterized Professor Gibson's long and tireless
efforts throughout his career.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Ralph
M. Gibson Professor Emeritus of Psychology in Pediatrics and Communicable
Diseases.
Donald A. Jones, associate professor of mathematics, will retire from active
faculty status on December 31, 1991, after a distinguished teaching and research
career.
Professor Jones was born in Topeka, Kansas. He received his B.S. degree in
mathematics from Iowa State College in 1952 and his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees
from the State University of Iowa in 1956 and 1959, respectively. He joined the
mathematics department at the University of Michigan as assistant professor in
1959 and was promoted to associate professor in 1965.
For many years, Professor Jones headed our excellent undergraduate actuarial science program, many of whose graduates are among the leaders of the insurance industry. Professor Jones provided these students with a unique college
learning environment and also made major contributions to actuarial education
nationally. His book, Actuarial Mathematics, co-authored with N. Bowers, H.
Gerber, J. Hickman, and C. Nesbitt, is the basic text for the Actuarial Society
exams.


-167 -



November Meeting, 1991


Professor Jones was an early participant in and supporter of the annual actuarial research conferences which have been held for the past 26 years. He introduced concepts and applications of Bayesian statistics to the actuarial profession
in North America, and he was a proponent of applying statistical theory in research collaborations with Professors A Mayerson,. Bowers, and H. Gerber.
Professor Jones co-authored papers with Professor Gerber on credibility theory,
dividends for group  surance, and stop-loss insurr ance prend s. Hure remains as
a consultant for the Society of Actuaries examination on risk theory
The Regents now salute this actuarial educator and scientist for his contributions by naming Donald A. Jones Associate Professor Emeritus of Mathematics.
Harold L. Stahly, professor of education at the University of Michigan-Flint,
retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1991, after a most productive career
as a teacher, advisor, and scholar.
Professor Stahly received his BA degree rom Greensville College in 1949,
his M.S. degree from Butler University in 1954, and his Ed.D. degree from Indiana University in 1961. He came to the University of Michigan-Flint in 1965 as
associate professor of education and was promoted to professor in 1971.
Professor Stahly has distinguished himself as a teacher, advisor, and leader at
the UM-Flint, with an outstanding record of service to the University and the
community. One of the foremost experts in the state on the history and development of teaching credential requirements, Professor Stahy was for many years
UM-Flint's director of teacher education, in charge of all student teaching and
certification for the campus. He has served with distinction on every major
years ago, he initiated the  r  School Project, a cooperative school that has
continued to this day. Professor Stahly is to be commended for his twenty-six
years of commitment to the University of Michigan-Flint and the educational
community.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his dedicated
service by naming Harold L. Stahly Pro essor Emeritus of Education.
Henry H. Swain, M.D., professor of pharmacology, retired from active faculty
status on October 31, 1991, after a distinguished and productive career as a
scholar, educator, and administrator.
Born in Champaign, Illinois, Dr. Swain received his BA degree from the
University of Illinois in 1943. During World War I, he served as a commissioned
officer in the Army Signal Intelligence Service, with overseas assignments in Australia, the Philippines, and Japan. In 1947, Dr. Swain enrolled in medical school
at the University of Illinois, where he pursued a career in academic pharmacology and received his M.S. and M.D. degrees in 1951. After completing an internship at the Cook County Hospital in Chicago, Dr. Swain began his academic
career as an instructor in the Department of Pharmacology at the University of
Cincinnati in 1952. He joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1954 as an instructor in pharmacology; he was promoted to assistant professor in 1957, associate professor in 1962, and professor in 1967.
After pursuing earlier research on cardiac electrophysiology, Dr. Swain later
assumed administrative responsibility for a colony of narcotic-addicted monkeys
that had been established to measure the physical dependence liability of narcotic analgesic agents. He also worked for ten years with faculty colleagues in
the Department of Computer and Communication Sciences, where he guided the
research activities of graduate students who used computers to simulate biological systems. Three pharmacologists and five computer scientists have received


-168 -



November Meeting 1991


Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan with Dr. Swain as their thesis
chair. Highly regarded as a teacher and mentor, Dr. Swain has been involved in
the education of not only graduate students and medical students, but also of
dental, pharmacy, and nursing students. He has received several teaching
awards, including the Elizabeth C. Crosby Award, the Senior Award, the Galens
Shovel Award, and the Dental Student Teaching Award.
In the Medical School, Dr. Swain served as acting chair of the Department of
Pharmacology on two separate occasions, from 1971-74, and from 1980-81. He
was named assistant dean for faculty affairs in 1982, and ably served in that capacity until 1990. He also served on the Medical School's Executive Committee
and on the Advisory Committee on Appointments, Promotions, and Tenure. Dr.
Swain has been a member of the American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics since 1957, and has served as historian of the society since
1970. He also has been a field editor for the Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics, and has served on the editorial boards for several other scientific journals. In addition, Dr. Swain chaired the Institutional Review Board
for the Parke-Davis Community Research Clinic in Ann Arbor and has served as
president of the American Heart Association of Michigan.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health educator for his dedicated
service by naming Henry H. Swain Professor Emeritus of Pharmacology.

University Mortgage Loan Program
Vice President Womack submitted a recommendation to modify the University's mortgage loan program to offer the following two options:
Option 1: Loan-to-value ratio of up to 80 percent; Interest rate competitive
with local lending institutions for similar loans
Option 2: Loan-to-value ratio from 81 percent to 90 percent; Interest rate
will be 1/2 percent higher than the rate offered for Option 1
Regent Baker expressed concern about the risk that would be posed by Option 2 of the proposal. Vice President Womack responded that his staff did not
believe that either proposal created undue risk, and that these options were considered to be beneficial for attracting faculty and staff. Regent Baker suggested
that a maximum purchase value be placed on the University's exposure in Option
2. Vice President Womack responded that this idea had been considered by his
staff, but rejected because it would be adverse to the University's interests. This
is because of their judgement that lower priced properties have more risk of declining below the appraised value than do higher priced properties.
Regent Baker moved that option one e approved as recommended, and that
Option 2 be limited to a cap of $160,000, with review of this limit after one year.
Regent Power pointed out that the risk or the applicant's ability to repay the
debt, is evaluated at thee time that the mortgage application is made. Vice President Womack reiterated his previous explanation that the risk is reduced by not
having a cap.
President Duderstadt observed that there are two issues: the financial risk to
the University and the recognition that the 1990s will be a critical time for recruiting faculty. He noted that the University will be competing with other institutions that have more aggressive home financing programs, and cautioned the
Regents not to lose sight of the University's human resource interest in considering this action.
In response to other questions, Vice President Womack pointed out that the
University offers competitive rates, but that the advantage to faculty and staff is
that the University does not charge points for its mortgage loans. Mr. Norman
Herbert, University investment officer, pointed out that there had only been one
default, out of about 80 to 100 mortgages per year, in 25 years of the program.

Following further discussion, Regents Power and Varner stated that they did
not believe that a cap was necessary. Regent Smith seconded Regent Baker's
motion. Regent Baker reiterated that his motion limited the cap to a one-year
time period. The vote was then taken on Regent Baker's motion. It failed, with
Regents Baker and Smith in favor, and Regents Brown, Nielsen, Power, McFee,
Varner, and Waters opposed.
Regent Power moved approval of options one and two, as recommended in
the action request (and stated above). Regent Baker observed that Option 2
goes beyond the boundaries of prudent lending, and he would vote against it.

University of Michigan Medical Center North Entrance Parking Structure

Proposed Contract Between the University of Michigan and Imagine, Inc.
Regent Brown moved, Regent Power seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved a contract between the University of Michigan and Imagine,
Inc. Because the owners and employees of Imagine, Inc., (David Gregory, Henry
Flurry, and Harold Brokaw), are also University of Michigan employees, this contract falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following
information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the agreement will be Imagine, Inc., and the Regents of
the University of Michigan. Kenneth Slayton will sign the contract
as chief executive officer of Imagine, Inc.


-171 -



November Meeting, 1991


2.  The proposed contract is a joint study agreement. There are no restrictions on publication or openness of the research. Imagine and
the University would each pay one half of Henry Flurry's and
Harold Brokaw's salaries ($30,139 each). The University will be
responsible for fringe benefits (approximately $6,819). David Gregory will provide consultation to the project, from time to time, as
part of normal research activities as director of the Center for Performing Arts and Technology (CPAT). CPAT facilities will be
used by Harold Brokaw and Henry Flurry to do the software development. No portion of David Gregory's University salary will be
paid by Imagine.
The University will retain ownership of the developed software.
Imagine will receive an exclusive license to commercially market
the software. Imagine will pay a royalty to the University based on
the sales of the software under terms to be negotiated with the Intellectual Properties Office.
3.  Imagine, Inc., is owned in part by David Gregory (27 percent),
Henry Flurry (17 percent), and Harold Brokaw (17 percent).
Imagine, Inc., is expected to profit from commercialization of the
licensed software.

On the recommendation of the University of Michigan Hospitals Executive

Honorary Degrees
Regent Smith moved, Regent Power seconded, and the Regents unanimously
approved, a recommendation for an honorary degree.
Law School Involvement in Policy-Making
Regent Brown observed that at the last meeting comments were made alleging that the Law School had expressed approval of the student code ("Policy on
Discrimination and Discriminatory Harassment by Students in a University Environment") that had later been declared unconstitutional. Regent Brown noted
that Dean Bollinger had responded to these comments in a letter mailed to the
Regents. Regent Brown noted that
"It should be stated that the Law School did not draft the code. Some
members of the faculty were consulted in a general way about it, and made
some suggestions. But it should be understood by everyone that this Board
and the administration do not in any way understand that the code was
drafted by the Law School or the Law School faculty or any members
thereof. Nor was it approved by the Law School faculty in any way. As a
matter of fact, some specific objections and concerns were raised by some


-172 -



November Meeting, 1991


members of the faculty that were consulted. The public should not be confused that the code was ever approved by the Law School or the faculty in
any way."
There followed a discussion about the propriety of consulting with Law
School faculty on matters that come before the Board on which they might have
some expertise. Regent Baker suggested that if such advice is sought in the
future, it be done via a formal request and a formal written opinion. Regent
Nielsen concurred that if a statement is made that the Law Schoof has reviewed a
matter, there ought to be a letter from the school confirming that.
Regent McFee observed that there would be a potential conflict of interest in
seeking legal counsel from Law School faculty. However, Regent Nielsen stated
that in the case where certain faculty are experts in a topic, they have a public
service obligation to review it. President Duderstadt commented that he thought
that asking a faculty member to provide professional expertise about a University
function that would affect the faculty member directly would constitute a potential conflict of interest.
Regent Power noted that there is a difference between seeking informal advice while a policy is being developed and rendering a professional opinion on
something. He agreed that if a professional opinion is being sought, professionals in the field outside of the University ought to be consulted. He also observed
that it was unwise to interpose the Law School as a source of authority into discussions that come before the Board.
There followed a ten-minute recess.
The meeting reconvened at 2:45 PM.
SACUA Presentation
President Duderstadt introduced James Diana, associate professor of natural
resources and chair of the Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs
(SACUA). Professor Diana stated that he would present an overview of faculty
governance and the role of the faculty in the mission of the University. He would
also focus on current issues of concern to faculty.
Professor Diana noted that the faculty carry out the University's primary mission: teaching, research, and service. Because the faculty are the only University
personnel who regularly deal with the broad spectrum of the University's mission,
the faculty should play a significant role in setting and understanding policy. He
then described the typical scenario of how and why a person becomes a faculty
member. He noted that as the economic climate for the faculty worsens, they are
becoming more concerned with such issues as pensions, retirement benefits, and
health insurance.
Another concern is the changing role of the faculty in the University. There
has been an increase in activities designed to address questions of social norms
for the University, such as the sexual harassment policy. Although faculty believe
such a policy is necessary, there is concern about how faculty will be treated in


-173 -



November Meeting, 1991


the event that complaints are made, and whether they will be given due process.
Faculty are also troubled about the climate of political correctness that intimidates faculty and students from discussing some issues.
Professor Diana observed that as the perceived importance of research with
respect to tenure and promotion is inflated, teaching becomes de-emphasized.
Thus, the incentives for good teaching are much less than the incentives for good
research. Faculty believe that this concern, encompassing the role of the University of Michigan m the 21st century, needs more debate and discussion.
Professor Diana then described the faculty governance structure and explained the issues currently before it. These include the replacement of faculty
committees by short-term task forces, the increased role of professional administrators at the eense of faculty and students, and the perception that the Regents make formal policy with little input from faculty an students.
In response to comments from the Regents, Professor Diana acknowledged
that the Senate Assembly had approved the sexual harassment policy before it
was brought to the Regents. Regent Brown pointed out that students do have
direct input into decision-making through public comments, direct contacts with
Regents and administrators, and committee service. Professor Diana responded
that both faculty and students should be involved at the level of final discussion
of policy issues.
CESF Report
Following further discussion about the issues raised by Professor Diana, President Duderstadt called on Frederick Beutler, professor emeritus of electrical engineering and computer science, to present the report of the Committee on the
Economic Status of the Faculty.
Professor Beutler discussed the function of CESF, and described the open
issues that CESF is actively pursumg. These include retirement after age 70; the
long term disability plan; utilization of the long term care benefit; administrative
growth (increase in the proportion of nonfaculty to faculty salaries paid from the
General Fund); and the need for a written policy on defense and indemnification.
Following his presentation, Professor Beutler responded to comments from the
Regents.
Public Comments
The meeting resumed in the Anderson Room of the Michigan Union, where
the Regents heard comments from the following individuals, on the topics indicated: Rodney Myers, student, Barbara A. Vicory, student, and Tracy Ore, student and teaching assistant, in favor of expanding the definition of "family" for
purposes of family housing eligibility; Safiya Khalid, member of N.E.E.D. Service, on denial of access to the Michigan Union; Charlie B. Flowers, citizen, on
how the N.E.E.D. Service has helped his community and family; Barbara Meadows, social worker, on the value of the N.E.E.D. Service; Thomas J. Nash, citizen,
and Bren Quilter, citizen, on their opposition to changing the definition of
"family" for purposes of family housing eligibility; and Demetrius A. Bady, student, on the isolation and problems of minority students.

-175 -



DECEMBER MEETING, 1991


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, December 19, 1991
The Regents met at 1:00 P.M. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Smith, Varner, and
Waters. Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, and Vice
Presidents Cosovich, Kelly, Swain, and Womack were also present, as were Chancellors Jones and Wilson. Vice President Johnson and Regent Baker were
absent.
Executive Session Motion
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and recognized Regent
Nielsen, who made the following motion:
Pursuant to Section 8(e) of the Michigan Open Meetings Act, as amended by
1984 PA 202, I move that the Board of Regents meet in closed session on December 19, 1991, at 4:00 P.M., in the Regents' Room, for the purpose of consulting with the Board's attorney regarding trial or settlement strategy in connection
with specific pending litigation.
The motion was approved unanimously.
Annual Report on Research
President Duderstadt then called on Vice President Kelly to present the
annual report on research for 1991.
Vice President Kelly reported that in 1990-91, the University's total research
volume increased by 13.3 percent, to a record total of $324,088,970. Of this total,
64.6 percent came from federal agencies, 22.0 percent came from nonfederal
sources, and 13.4 percent came from University funds. Vice President Kelly displayed a series of charts and graphs illustrating research expenditures by sponsor
and by University unit, as well as trends in indirect cost recovery and indirect
costs as a percent of total research expenditures. He warned that the 26.0 percent cap on research administrative costs to be imposed by the federal Office of
Management and Budget on July 1, 1992, could cost the University as much as
$10 million or more per year in its indirect cost recoveries. The effect of this cap
will be to shift the burden of indirect costs from the federal government to the
universities, and will have a profound effect on the University's capacity to support and maintain its overall research activities at their current levels.
Following his presentation, Vice President Kelly responded to questions and
comments from the Regents. President Duderstadt pointed out that the remarkable level of sponsored research activity is due to the quality, talents, and ability
of the faculty. Regent Brown noted that for every dollar the University receives
from the state, more than one dollar from outside the state is injected into the
state's economy.
