Retirement Memoirs
On a motion by Regent Smith, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved adoption of the following retirement memoirs:
Edmund H. Creeth, professor of English language and literature, will retire
from active faculty status on December 31, 1991.
A native Californian, Professor Creeth received his B.A., M.A., and Ph.D.
degrees from the University of California at Berkeley in 1951, 1953, and 1956, respectively. He taught at Berkeley and at Pomona College prior to coming to the
University of Michigan as an instructor in English in 1958. He was promoted to
assistant professor in 1960, associate professor in 1965, and professor in 1974.
Professor Creeth taught also as a visiting professor at the Oregon College of Education (summer 1959) and the University of Essex, England (fall 1968), and has
lectured, chiefly on English Renaissance topics, at the University of Kentucky,
Chicago's Newberry Library, Charles University in Prague, and at the University's own English Department Colloquium. He has served on numerous committees at the departmental, college, and graduate school levels, including the department's executive committee. Of particular note is his work as a member of


-187 -



December Meeting, 1991


the University Club board of directors (1975-84) and as associate editor of the
Michigan Quarterly Review (1973 to the present).
As a scholar, Professor Creeth has devoted himself both to the Renaissance
and to the Middle Ages. His work on Shakespeare, whose roots he locates in the
medieval past, is distilled in articles, reviews, and an important book of 1976,
Mankynde in Shakespeare. For many years, his monthly column, "Landmarks of
Criticism," appeared in the Shakespeare Newsletter. Students of the Renaissance
are permanently in his debt for his scrupulously edited collections of Tudor Plays
(1966) and Tudor Prose 1513-1570 (1969). A popular teacher of Shakespeare, he
has branched out widely, having offered many times every introductory departmental course, as well as more specialized courses on Milton, Shakepeare's
rivals, and early English masters.
Perhaps what most distinguishes Professor Creeth's career is his long and devoted commitment to creative writing. At least once every year since 1973, he
has taught this extremely difficult subject, supplementing classroom instruction
with some fifty courses in independent study. His own much-praised novel,
Deerlover (1987), is now being turned into a screenplay, and he is currently at
work on a second novel, With a Human Face, telling of the Prague spring of 1968.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming
Edmund H. Creeth Professor Emeritus of English Language and Literature.
Norman S. Radin, professor of neurochemistry in the Department of Psychiatry and research scientist in the Mental Health Research Institute, will retire
from active faculty status on December 31, 1991, after a most productive career
as a researcher and teacher.
Born and raised in New York City, Professor Radin took undergraduate and
graduate studies at Columbia University receiving his B.A. degree in 1941 and his
Ph.D. degree in biochemistry in 1949. He did his postdoctoral work with H. S.
Barker at the University of California at Berkeley on enzymes of purine decomposition from 1949-50, and with Esmond Snell at the University of Texas Biochemical Institute in Austin on bacterial amino acid metabolism from 1950-52.
He then joined the faculty of Northwestern University, where he served as an instructor from 1952-55, assistant professor from 1955-57, and associate professor
from 1957-60. From 1954-57, he also worked as a principal scientist at the Veterans Administration Research Hospital in Chicago. It was during these years that
he began his life-long interest in galactolipid metabolism, particularly in relation
to the brain. His studies of the composition of cerebroside components and their
biosynthesis remain classic contributions to the neurochemical literature.
Professor Radin came to the University of Michigan in 1960 as a research
biochemist (now known as research scientist) at the Mental Health Research Institute. In 1973 he was awarded the additional title of professor of biochemistry
with tenure in the Department of Psychiatry. The latter title was changed to professor of neurochemistry in 1984.
For the last thirty years, Professor Radin's laboratory at the University of
Michigan has been a center for research on the glycolipids, and has served as a
major training site for postdoctoral fellows and students. His curriculum vita is
studded with technical notes and inventions related to modification of laboratory
techniques, particularly in relation to the counting of radioisotopes. During the
last five years, Professor Radin has dedicated himself to tumor cell metabolism.
Professor Radin has been in demand as an editor by major journals in his
field, and has served widely on study sections and committees. Among his many


-188 -



December Meeting, 1991


honors are a Javits Investigator Award from the National Institutes of Health and
the University Senior Research Scientist Lectureship for 1990.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his dedicated
service by naming Norman S. Radin Professor Emeritus of Neurochemistry and
Research Scientist Emeritus.

Improvement in the University's Long Term Disability Plans
Vice President Womack explained that employees at the Medical Center had
requested improvements in the long term disability (LTD) plans. He noted that
all of the Unversity's LTD plans are self-insured; they accumulate and set aside
funds to cover the payments. The costs of the improvements to the plans will be
covered by staff members who have coverage over a salary of $50,000, as described in the Regents communication.
In response to a comment from Regent Power, Vice President Womack clarified that this proposal would be entirely paid for by the participants. Regent
Nielsen pointed out that this type of benefit could be sought in the future by
other employee groups as a Umversity-paid benefit, which could lead to higher
fringe benefi  ts for the University. Vice President Womack acknowledged
that this possibility exists, but is unavoidable if coverage is to be extended.
On a motion by Regent Nielsen, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved changing the Expanded and Physicians LTD Plans to provide for replacement of 65 percent of salary and purchasing stop-loss coverage,
and that such changes be made effective February 1, 1992, or as soon thereafter
as possible.
Addition of Long Term Care Options
Vice President Womack introduced a request that the Regents approve the
University's offering all of the Long Term Care (LTC) options available from
TIAA, rather than the one plan approved earlier this year, noting that individual
employees pay the entire cost of the plan.
Regent Nielsen questioned whether Regental approval could be worded so
as to only rema in effect as long as this benefit is entirely employee-paid. Vice
President Womack pointed out that it would be difficult to place a condition on a
plan that would remove it as an option from the collective bargaining process.
Regent Power observed that there are two adverse consequences in making
this type of improvement in fringe benefit options: 1) actions taken by the University tend to affect the nature of expectations in the local labor market as to
what benefits will be offered; and 2) by continually improving the mix of fringe
benefits within the University community, expectations are created that fringe
benefits will continue to be improved. This raises the larger question as to where
the University is headed with respect to fringe benefits.
Vice President Womack stated that from a policy perspective, it may not be
wise to prohibit by official action the enhancement of a fringe benefit unless that
benefit is paid solely by the employee. He also doubted that there would be a
way to craft a public policy without increasing expectations that there will be increased enhancements in the future. Regent McFee pointed out that both the
LTD and LTC plans allowed employees to take the responsibility to put portions
of their salaries away for future needs, instead of relying on their employer to
provide that for them.


-190 -



December Meeting, 1991
Regent Nielsen requested that staff be urged to craft language restricting
who the payor can be when constructing future staff benefits options. Vice President Womack responded that he would seek advice of counsel on this matter.
There being no further discussion, Regent Nielsen moved, Regent Power seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved, the offering of all Long Term
Care options available from TIAA in the winter of 1992.

Cancer and Geriatrics Centers Building
Vice President Womack called on Mr. Douglas Hanna, of the University's
Plant Extension Office, to present the design of the Cancer and Geriatrics Centers Building.
Mr. Hanna used site maps, detailed diagrams of each floor, and a threedimensional scale model to illustrate his presentation of the proposed design of
the Cancer and Geriatrics Centers Building.
In    i the discussion that followed, Regent Power noted that there appears to be
an assumption that most at ients will be dropped off in front ofth building,
rather than driving themselves and entering the building from the parking structure. He believes this assumption to be erroneous, and requested that planners
re-evaluate the interchanges between this and other medical center buildings and
the medical center parking structures. Regent Power observed that the design
problems created by entering Hospitals buildings from parking structures have
not been adequately addressed.
Regent Nielsen raised the issue of how the Cancer and Geriatrics Centers
will impact the occupancy rate of the Med Inn. Dr. Zuidema noted that because
the new facility would be an ambulatory facility, it would not be expected to increase the demand for accommodations at the Med n t that this would be
investigated further.
Following further discussion, Regent Nielsen moved, Regent Brown seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved, the design of the Cancer and Geriatrics Centers Building as presented, subject to points raised during the discussion.

Revision of Regents' Bylaws Sections 11.21, 11214, 11216, and 11.217 (Board in
Control of Intercollegiate Athletics)
Vice President Kennedy noted that the Regents had previously approved
changes in the size and composition of the Board in Control of Intercollegiate
Athletics. Along with these, the Office of the General Counsel was proposing additional changes to the Regents' Bylaws to bring them into accordance with Big
Ten governance, to more accurately reflect how the Board in Control actually operates, and to make the Board in Control bylaws similar to those of other University committees and boards. On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent
Varner, the Regents unanimously approved changes to Regents' Bylaws Sections
11.21, 11.214, 11.216, and 11.217. (Regent Brown pointed out an error in paragraph 3 of Section 11.214 of the Regents communication; the correct language
appears below.)


-192 -



December Meeting, 1991


The revised bylaws read as follows:
Section 11.21: The Department of Athletics â€”General Purposes
Responsibility for the development, maintenance, and administration of
the University's programs in recreational sports and athletics on the Ann
Arbor campus shall rest in the Department of Athletics.
The department shall, subject to the ultimate authority of the president
and the Board of Regents, have responsibility for a comprehensive program of
recreation and physical development for students, faculty, and staff, and for
the necessary staff, grounds, and equipment. The term "recreational sports"
shall include intramural sports, club sports, informal drop-in and special interest recreational activities, to be offered as hereinafter provided. The term
"athletics" shall include all programs of intercollegiate competition. The department shall promote wide participation by students in the activities of the
department.
Section 11.214. The Board in Control of Intercollegiate Athletics
The Board in Control of Intercollegiate Athletics (hereinafter "the Board
in Control") shall be constituted as follows:
1. (a) Six members of the University Senate, to be appointed by the
president from a panel of senate members chosen by the Senate Advisory
Committee on University. Affairs, subject to the approval of the Board of
Regents. The six senate members shall hold office in each case for three
years, but in no event shall any member of the senate serve more than two
consecutive terms, except that if a member be appointed to fill an unexpired
term of less than half of a full term, this shall not make that member ineligible for two full terms. The terms of senate members shall be staggered so that
two terms shall expire eachyear. The panelfrom which the appointments are
made shall be unranked and shall contain twice the number of appointees.
If a vacancy in the appointive senate membership shall occur from causes
other than the completion of the appointive term, the president is authorized
to make an interim appointment from the most recent panel of names submitted by the Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs; or, if the
president so requests, from a new panel of names chosen by the Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs.
2. The University representatives in the Intercollegiate Conference of
Faculty Representatives ex officio to serve a five-year term.
3. Two alumni/ae, to be appointed by the president from a panel chosen by the Board of Directors of the University of Michigan Alumni Association, subject to approval by the Board of Regents, to hold office for three
years in each case, provided always that no alumni/ae member shall hold office more than two consecutive terms. The alumni/ae members shall serve
three-year terms, which terms shall be staggered so that they are not concurrent. The panel from which the appointments are made shall contain twice
the number of appointees.


-193 -



December Meeting, 1991


4. Two students of the University, to be appointed by the president from
a panel chosen by Michigan Student Assembly, subject to approval by the
Board of Regents. The student members shall serve two-year terms which
terms shall be staggered so that one student is appointed each year. The
panel from which the appointment is made shall be unranked and shall contain at least twice the number of appointees. If a vacancy in the appointive
student membership shall occur from causes other than the completion of the
appointive term, the president is authorized to make an interim appointment
from the most recent panel of names submitted by Michigan Student Assembly; or, if the president so requests, from a new panel of names chosen by
Michigan Student Assembly.
5. One executive officer appointed by the president to be a member ex
officio.
6. The director of athletics, ex officio, without vote.
Section 11.216 The Board in Control of Intercollegiate Athletics â€”Functions
Subject to the ultimate authority of the president and the Board of
Regents, the Board in Control shall have control of the program in intercollegiate athletics and shall act as the business and financial agency of that
program. In all its actions, it shall make every effort to coordinate the intercollegiate program with that in recreational sports.
The Board in Control shall be responsible to the president and the Board
of Regents for the care and upkeep of physical properties devoted to outdoor
athletic activities and also of the buildings and facilities assigned to the Board
in Control by the Board of Regents.
Subject to the ultimate authority of the president and the Board of
Regents, the Board in Control shall make, adopt, and enforce the necessary
rules and regulations governing all questions pertaining to the eligibility of
players, intercollegiate relations, and membership in associations of universities and colleges organized for the regulation of athletics.
The Board in Control shall appoint the University representative in the
IntercoUegiate Conference of Faculty Representatives, the appointment to be
approved by the Senate Assembly. Such representative shall be a member of
the University Senate, shall hold office for a term of five years and may serve
unlimited terms.
The Board in Control shall report all its official actions, through the president, to the Board of Regents for approval and shall report annually to the
University Senate, through the Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs. At any time, the Board in Control may consult with the University
Senate through its advisory committee; and at any time, the senate advisory
committee may request full information on matters within the province of the
Board in Control The Board in Control shall at all times receive and consider recommendations from the University Senate and petitions from the student body.


-194 -



December Meeting, 1991


Subject to the ultimate authority of the president and the Board of
Regents, the Board in Control shall be responsible for the business management of all activities under its jurisdiction; provided, however, that any
business transactions involving capital expenditures for permanent improvements or the purchase, sale, or other use of real property shall be handled
through the vice president and chief financial officer pursuant to Chapter III
of these bylaws.
Section 11.217 The Board in Control of Intercollegiate Athletics â€”Funds
Subject to the ultimate authority of the president and the Board of
Regents, all moneys received by the Board in Control from any source, shall
be deposited to the credit of the Board in Control in a bank or banks approved by the Board in Control or the President. No withdrawals shall be
made from such deposits except upon vouchers which shall bear the signature
of the director of athletics or a designee approved by the Board in Control or
the president. Any surplus funds from intercollegiate operations shall be devoted (1) to the further support of the various programs and activities carried
on within the Department of Athletics, and (2) so far as possible, to permanent University improvements, particularly to the upbuilding of facilities for
participation in all forms of physical exercise
Following a five-minute recess, the Regents returned to the table to consider
several items which had not been included with the agenda materials.
Vacant Land, State Street (approximately 34 acres)
Vice President Womack announced that a parcel of vacant land on the west
side of State Street approximately one-quarter mile south of the University golf
course was available or purchase. In response to questions from the Regents, it
was noted that the assessed value of the property is $1 million, and it is located in
Pittsfield Township, rather than within the city of Ann Arbor.
Following some discussion, Regent Nielsen moved, Regent Power seconded,
and the Regents unanimously approved, completing the purchase of this parcel at
a price of $1.35 per square foot. The final purchase price will be based upon the
square footage determined by a survey.
Vacant Land, State Street (approximately 20 acres)
Vice President Womack described this proposed transaction, which includes
purchase of 16 ~ acres of land, acceptance of a gift from the owners of the 20-acre
parcel of the remaining 4 ~ acres, and an exchange and conveyance of lots on Park
Crest, a small road off State Street located immediately to the north of the
20-acre parcel (see map on Regents Communication). The transaction also includes the University's joining in a request to vacate Park Crest. Acquisition of
the land will provide the University with a number of expansion opportunities,
and is supported by the University's planning consultant, Johnson Johnson &
Roy/inc.
In response to a comment from Regent Nielsen, Vice President Womack
stated that counsel would be asked to ensure that the transaction would not violate the Plat Act.


-195 -



December Meeting, 1991
Mr. Norman Herbert responded to a question from Regent Smith about what
would be the result of the University's vacating Park Crest. Regent Smith
pointed out that the owners of the property adjacent to the roadway would have
total control over the use of that roadway for purposes of ingress and egress. Mr.
Herbert noted that the University would have an iterest in participating in these
decisions to the extent that they would impact the University-owned lots. He further stated that the University is vacating the road because it does not have a
need for it as a form of ingress and egress to University land. Regent Brown clarified the legal implications of vacating a roadway, noting that if a road is vacated,
it does not exist. In response to a question from Regent Smith as to whether the
new landowners could construct a building on that road, Regent Brown and Mr.
Herbert responded that they could. Regent Smith pointed outhat this would effectively cut off access to University property via this road, and she would not
support this action.
Regent Nielsen moved approval ofth the transaction of the University's acquiring through gift, purchase, and exchange, the 20~ acre State Street parcel and Lot
4 on Park Crest at a total cost of $1275,000, and the University's conveying Lots
36, 37, and 38 to Nick Michos and Sam Roumanis, as described in the Regents
communication, subject to its not violating the Plat Act. Regent McFee seconded
the motion, and it was adopted, with Regents Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power,
Varner, and Waters in favor and Regent Smith opposed.
11 t Acre Parcel, Northwest Corner of Hubbard Drive and Huron Parkway
Vice President Womack reported that in order to expand its facility at the
corner of Plymouth Road and Huron Parkway, Warner Lambert/Parke Davis has
offered to purchase for $3 million an 11 acre parcel of University-owned land located at the northwest corner of Hubbard Drive and Huron Parkway, which is adjacent to the south of its property.
Vice President Womack noted that Johnson Johnson & Roy, Inc. (JJR) was
in support of the sale. He read the following comments from JJR into the record,
noting that the University would seek to include these points in the agreement
that is ultimately reached with Warner Lambert/Parke Davis:
1) A generous setback needs to be maintained along the north side of
Hubbard Road so that the potential non-University development does
not conflict with the University image.
2) Adequate screen berms and plantings should be used to screen the north
side of Hubbard Road so that primary emphasis is placed on the University of Michigan North Campus.
3) We further recommend that Hubbard Road west of Huron Parkway provides exclusive access to University facilities. It is desirable therefore
that vehicular access to the 11-acre parcel be achieved solely off of
Plymouth Road via the internal loop road and/or Huron Parkway.
4) Because the development of the proposed site would have an impact on
the campus, we recommend that the University should have an opportunity to review Warner Lambert development plans.


-196 -



December Meeting, 1991


President Duderstadt reported that although Regent Baker could not be
present at the meeting, he had raised several issues about the importance of this
site and its location adjacent to the entrance to North Campus. He said that he
believed Vice President Womack, through discussions with JJR and Warner
Lambert, had successfully addressed Regent Baker's concerns.
Regent Varner moved approval of the sale of the parcel on the northwest
corner of Hubbard Drive and Huron Parkway to Warner Lambert/Parke Davis
at a price of $3.0 million, subject to an appraisal of the value of the parcel.
Regent Waters seconded the motion.
Regent Smith expressed several concerns with the sale of this property. She
noted that the land cannot be replaced, and is a gateway to the University.
Therefore, it was important that the University maintain control over the type of
architecture that is constructed on this site. She then moved to amend the motion so as to place restrictions in the deed giving the University the right to
review and approve architectural designs, setbacks, etc. as enumerated in the
letter from JJR. There being no second to the amendment, the vote was taken
on the original motion, and it was approved, with Regents Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Varner, and Waters in favor and Regent Smith opposed.
Sports Betting Resolution
President Duderstadt noted that the Board in Control of Intercollegiate Athletics had recently approved a resolution in support of the limitation of sports
betting, as proposed m 'The Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act" being considered by the United States Congress.
Regent McFee spoke in favor of the resolution, and President Duderstadt
noted that the Big Ten presidents had also agreed that it addressed an important
issue. Following further discussion, Regent McFee moved, Regent Smith seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved, the following resolution:
RESOLUTION
Whereas, more and more states are looking to various forms of legalized gambling, including sports betting, as a revenue source, and
Whereas, sports betting threatens the integrity of, and public confidence in professional team sports, converting them from wholesome
athletic entertainment into a vehicle for gambling, and
Whereas, most law enforcement officials agree that legalization of
sports betting does not reduce illegal gambling and in fact, by breeding
a new class of bettors, actually facilitates illegal sports gambling operations, and
Whereas, state-sponsored betting on professional sports will "open
the door" to betting on amateur sports such as intercollegiate athletics,
and


-197 -



December Meeting, 1991


Whereas, sports gambling is especially harmful to our youth because of the high levels of interest and devotion that children maintain
towards their favorite teams and players, and
Whereas, teenagers are particularly susceptible to the lure of sports
betting, and
Whereas, of the estimated eight million compulsive gamblers in
America, one million are teenagers, and
Whereas, sports in the United States should not be about winning
or losing money, but about teamwork, discipline, and skilled compettion, and
Whereas, sports betting is inherently an interstate problem requiring a federal solution, and
Whereas, federal legislation entitled 'The Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act (S.474 and H.R. 74), has been introduced to
preclude additional states from instituting lotteries or other gambling
on the outcome of sports events, and
Whereas, this legislation is supported by such diverse organizations
as the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the National Association of Collegiate Directors of Athletics, the International Association
of Chiefs of Police, the Women's Sports Foundation, the National Association of Collegiate Directors of Athletics, the National Association of
Professional Baseball Leagues, Pop Warner Football, the American Association of School Administrators, the National Federation of State
High School Associations, the U.S. Baseball Federation, and the National Association of Secondary School Principals,
Now Therefore Be It Resolved that the University of Michigan
Board of Regents supports the limitation of sports betting through the
passage of The Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act" (S.474
and H.R. 74) now being considered by the United States Congress.
Resolution in Honor of Henry Johnson
Regent Brown then offered the following resolution, which was adopted by
acclamation:
RESOLUTION
The Regents of the University of Michigan wish to extend their gratitude and best wishes to Vice President Henry Johnson as he begins yet another phase of his service to the University as a senior consultant with the
Alumni Association.
Henry Johnson came to the University of Michigan in 1970 as associate director of the Program for Educational Opportunity in the School of
Education, after having pursued his professional interests as a psychiatric


-198 -



December Meeting, 1991


social worker for ten years in Indiana, Kansas, and Michigan. He was
appointed vice president for student services in 1972 In this position, he
developed his unique management style, characterized by an unusual
compassion and understanding for the students who were the primary
beneficiaries of his services. It was through this work also that he became a
member and voting delegate of the National Association of Student
Personnel Administrators and a commissioner-at-large for the North
Central Association of Colleges and Schools.
His arrival at the University also marked the start of Henry's extensive
involvement in civic, charitable, and human service organizations. These
commitments reflect his broad interests and strong convictions and provide
a model that few can equal Henry has served as an elected member of the
Ann Arbor Public School Board, and as a board member of the Michigan
Evaluation Resource Center, City of Ann Arbor Compensation
Commission, Child and Family Service of Washtenaw County, Ann Arbor
Symphony, and Kerrytown Concert House. He has also served on the
steering committee of the State of Michigan Leadership 2000 Committee,
and is a member of the Ann ArborArea 2000 Committee. Currently chairof Washtenaw County United Way, over the years he has served in numerous other leadership capacities on the University of Michigan, Washtenaw
County, and Michigan United Way organizations.
This dedication to the broader community made Henry Johnson the
logical choice for the newly created position of vice president for community affairs, to which he was appointed in 1990. In this position, as in all of
his other endeavors, Henry Johnson has demonstrated an enthusiasm, a
graciousness, and an energy that have enabled those associated with him to
aspire to and achieve high levels of accomplishment. Through the years, he
has developed untold numbers of friends and admirers, both within and
outside of the University community.
The Regents therefore extend their warm greetings and deep appreciation to Henry Johnson as he embarks on his new position with the Alumni
Association.

Resolution in Honor of 1991 Michigan Wolverines Football Team
Regent Waters offered the following resolution, which was adopted by acclamation:
RESOLUTION
The Regents of the University of Michigan commend the 1991 Michigan Wolverine football team, its coach, Gary Moeller, and HeismanTrophy-winning wide receiver Desmond Howard for providing Michigan
fans across the nation with an especially thrilling football season.
From his spectacular 93-yard idckoff return against Boston College in
the first game of the season, to his trademark diving catch in the back of
the end zone against Notre Dame in the second, to his 93-yard punt return
in the final game against Ohio State, Desmond Howard, with the help of
his teammates, thrilled the nation with his magical athletic prowess.
Through it all Desmond and his teammates never lost sight of the fundamental tenet of the Michigan football tradition: the importance of the
team over the individual player. As Desmond himself put it upon becoming the second Michigan player in history to win the Heisman Trophy, "7
never put pressure on myself to win this award or any award; I just wanted
to play consistently week in and week out and help our team win."
In demonstrating a grace and maturity beyond his years both on and
off thefield, Desmond Howard is a credit to the University of Michigan and
an inspiration to young athletes across the nation. As the
Big-Ten-champion Wolverines head to Pasadena to compete in the Rose
Bowl for the fifteenth time, the Regents echo Desmond's sentiments in dedicating the Heisman Trophy to the 1991 Michigan football team with a
hearty "Hail to the victors, and Go Blue!"

-201 -



JANUARY MEETING, 1992


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, January 16, 1992
The Regents met at 2:30 P.M. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Smith, and
Waters. Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, and Vice
Presidents Cosovich, Kelly, Swain, and Womack were also present, as were Chancellors Jones and Wilson. Regent Varner was absent.
Minutes
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order. Regent Waters moved approval of the minutes of the meeting of December, 1991; Regent Smith seconded
the motion.
Real estate transactions. Referring to the real estate transaction involving
property on State Street that had been approved the previous month, Regent
Baker observed that he had been absent from the January meeting, but he was
dismayed by the giving away of assets, in particular the access to the golf course
property on State Street, since from a construction point of view, that was one of
the best access points on State Street for that property.
Regent Baker also stated that he was saddened by the sale of the 11 acres of
University land on North Campus to Warner Lambert. He noted that that
property had been designated in the North Campus Master Plan for playing fields
on North Campus, and was to have been kept m perpetuity as an entry point to
North Campus. He said that the University had owned all four corers of the
property until the sale of that land, and when driving from North Campus toward
Hubbard Street, one could clearly see the importance of those four corers as an
entry point to the University. Regent Baker said he thinks it was a mistake to sell
that property, and that future generations would look back and wonder why a
piece of property that was so valuable to the integrity of the North Campus was
ever sold. He observed that a good price was received for the parcel, but expressed the hope that it doesn't come to the point where the University campus is
for sale.
Regent Baker noted that the minutes stated that Johnson Johnson & Roy/inc
had given an opinion on the sale. He stated he had not read the report, but that
Johnson Johnson & Roy/inc have an obligation to defend the integrity of their
own plan, and they did not do that. He concluded by saying that he was sorry the
transaction took place.
The vote was then taken, and the minutes of the meeting of December 19,
1991, were approved unanimously as corrected in the additional agenda.

Extension, Litigation, Personnel-Labor Relations, and a Report on Non-Competitive Purchases over $2,000 from October 1 through December 31, 1991.

Retirement Memoirs
The Regents voted unanimously to adopt the following Retirement Memoirs:
George R. DeMuth, M.D., professor of pediatrics and communicable diseases in the Medical School, retired from active faculty status on December 31,
1991, concluding a career which has spanned more than three decades.
Raised in Sherwood, Ohio, Dr. DeMuth received his B.S. degree from
Oberlin College in 1946 and his M.D. degree from the Medical College of the
University of Cincinnati in 1950. He served his internship at the University of
Michigan Hospitals from 1950-51 and his pediatric residency at Children's Hospital, University of Cincinnati, from 1951-53, including a year as pediatric chief resident. This was followed by a fellowship in pediatric pathology, also at Children's
Hospital of Cincinnati. After service in the U.S. Army, Dr. DeMuth returned to
the University of Michigan as a research fellow in the Department of Pediatrics
in 1956, developing his special interest in pediatric pulmonary physiology and respiratory diseases of children. Except for a traineeship at the University of Calitornia Cardiovascular Research Institute in 1959, he remained at the University
of Michigan.
In 1958, Dr. DeMuth was appointed assistant professor of pediatrics; he was
promoted to associate professor in 1963 and to professor in 1967. He established
the Pulmonary Function Laboratory at the Medical Center and conducted a study
on the growth and development of lung function in children which is still considered a major contribution. His accomplishments as scholar were recognized by
his election to membership in the Society for Pediatric Research.
Dr. DeMuth's clinical and administrative service to the University of Michigan Medical Center has been truly remarkable. In 1968, he assumed the duties
of associate dean for academic affairs in the Medical School. He developed and
served as the first director of the Integrated Premedical/Medical Program,
known as "Inteflex," which allowed the enrollment of promising high school graduates into the undergraduate school with assurance of admission into the Medical
School. He then directed his gift for developing innovative programs toward the
need for future medical school faculty trained in both the sciences and clinical
medicine. He founded, and still directs, the Medical Scientist Training Program


-212 -



January Meeting, 1992
where students pursue simultaneously Ph.D. and M.D. degrees. These programs
flourish and are lasting contributions in the best Michigan tradition.
The Regents now salute this distinguished and productive clinician, scholar,
and educator by naming George R. DeMuth Professor Emeritus of Pediatrics
and Communicable Diseases.
Richard D. Mann, professor of psychology in the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, retired from active faculty status on November 4, 1991.
Professor Mann received his AB. degree in psychology from Harvard College in 1954 and his A.M. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan in
1956 and 1958, respectively. From 1959-64, he served as an assistant professor at
Harvard College, returning to Michigan in 1964 as an associate professor. He
was promoted to professor of psychology in 1969.
Professor Mann had a special commitment to undergraduate education, especially in the area of creating experential learning opportunities. In his roles as
undergraduate chair, director of the Outreach Program and coordinator of "Introduction to Psychology as a Social Science," he had a great impact on the undergraduate experience within the psychology department. He also performed
exemplary service to the college as a member of the executive committee of the
Program on Studies in Religion, and taught courses in community studies and at
the Residential College. He was a beloved teacher who touched the lives of students not only in psychology but also across the college.
Professor Mann's long-standing interests and research were in the area of
interpersonal interaction and learning. From his early book, Interpersonal Styles
and Group Development (1968), through his later research on the nature of the
contributions of confer-like technology to learning processes, student interaction,
and teaching effectiveness, he has explored the undergraduate learning experience. More recently his work has centered on transpersonal psychology and the
integration of psychology and religion.
The Regents now salute this distinguished teacher and scholar for his dedicated service by naming Richard D. Mann Professor Emeritus of Psychology.
Phyllis M. Ocker, associate director of women's athletics and assistant professor of sports management and communication in the Division of Kinesiology,
retired from active faculty status on December 31, 1991, after a most productive
career of 30 years at the University of Michigan.
After receiving her B.A. degree from tie University of Washington in Seattle in 1948, Professor Ocker taught physical education in Snohomish, Washington. She then entered Smith College, where she received her M.S. degree in
1952 and served as an instructor of physical education. In 1955, she became
women's physical training instructor at the University of Texas and, in 1957,
joined Oregon State University as assistant professor of women's physical education. Professor Ocker came to Ann Arbor in 1961 as associate supervisor of
physical education for women and lecturer in the School of Education. She was
promoted to assistant professor in 1968, and in 1978 was named associate director of women's athletics. While teaching at the University, she continued her
studies, completing all course work toward a Ph.D. degree and collecting the data
for a dissertation.
During her tenure at the University of Michigan, Professor Ocker coached
many women's sports, including basketball, volleyball, and field hockey. She also
served as coordinator of teacher education, and, in addition to her administrative


-213 -



January Meeting 1992


duties, continued as a member of the physical education faculty, teaching courses
related to the history of human movement and physical education teaching methods for K-12 teacher certification.
Professor Ocker has served on numerous national, state, and University
committees, including the 1973 President's Committee to Study Women's Athletics. She has held many offices in the Michigan Association of Health, Physical
Education, Recreation, and Dance, including president, and has twice chaired the
Big Ten women's athletics directors. Within the University, she served on the
policy board of the Office of Student Services, the Michigan League Board of
Governors, and the Board in Control of Intercollegiate Athletics.
Professor Ocker spearheaded women's athletics during a period of unprecedented growth and advancement. Among her many achievements, she initiated
the Academic Hall of Honor to recognize four-year varsity athletes who also excelled in the classroom.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Phyllis
M. Ocker Assistant Professor Emeritus of Sports Management and Communication.

Investments
Vice President Womack announced that the University's endowment portfolio had grown from $497 million in June, 1991 to $565 million as of January 15,
1992. He said that this reinforces the importance of staying in the stock market,
noting that 11 percent of the total value of the Dow Jones Industrial Average has
occurred in the last 20 days.
Reassignment of University's Ownership Interest in Intellectual Property (Jess G.
Thoene)
On a motion by Regent Smith, seconded by Regent Brown, all seven Regents present unanimously approved reassignment of the ownership of the intelrectual property "Cysteamine Treatment for AIDS" to Jess G. Thoene. Because


-214 -



January Meeting, 1992


the inventor of the intellectual property is also a University employee, this arrangement falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the Assignment Agreement will be the Regents of the University of Michigan and Jess G. Thoene.
2.  The terms and pecuniary interests were previously disclosed to and
approved by the Regents on July 16, 1987, and are hereby incorporated by reference in this action request.
In response to a question from Regent Brown about the use of the term "reassignm  " Vice President Kelly stated that the reassi ent is by mutual consent. The inventor must reimburse the University for any costs up to that point,
and the University receives 15 percent of any royalties or equity arrangements
that the inventor subsequently receives. Regent Brown observed that the term
"reassign  t" in this context was inacurate; it is really an amendment to the
original agreement. Vice President Kelly said that he would consult with counsel
about a more appropriate way to describe these arrangements in the future.

FEBRUARY MEETING, 1992


The University of Michigan

Wednesday, February 19,1992
Public Hearing on Transfer of Police Authority
The Regents met at 4:00 PA. in the Michigan League Ballroom for the purpose
of conducting a public hearing on the transfer of police authority, as required by
Public Act 120 of 1990. Present were President Duderstadt, Vice President and
Secretary Kennedy, and Regents Baker, Brown, McFee, Power, Nielsen, Smith, and
Varner. Because there was a demonstration in the room that made it impossible to
carry out the hearing as planned, Regent Power read the following motion:
Motion to recess and remove. In accordance with the decisions of the Michigan Appellate Courts in Regents v Washtenaw County Coalition Against Apartheid
and because the breach of the peace which has been committed at this meeting has
made it impossible to conduct the business of this meeting in an orderly fashion in
this location it is hereby moved that this meeting be recessed temporarily and
removed to the Alumni Center to be reconvened there at approximately 4:20 PM.
Although those who have committed a breach of the peace at this meeting will be
excluded from the reconvened meeting, representatives of the press will be
admitted and others having business at the reconvened meeting may be admitted as
space permits. University personnel shall be stationed at the doors to this meeting
room to advise the press and the public of this recess and the location of the
reconvened meeting.
Regent Baker seconded the motion, and it was adopted unanimously.
The hearing reconvened at approximately 4:20 PM. in the Alumni Center. Secretary Kennedy called on each speaker who had signed up in advance to address
the hearing, repeating the names of the speakers who had not responded after
gong through the list the first time. The Regents heard comments from the followmg 10 people, of the 24 speakers who had signed up to speak in advance: Aaron
Nobel, David Schwartz, Cameron Henke, Lynn Haley, Michael David Warren, Jr.,
David Marabel, Robert Van Houweling, and Raphael Zicklin, students; and Jim
Yu and Todd Strauch, staff members. Two additional scheduled speakers, Jeff
Hinte and Todd Ochoa (students), were present in the hearing room but chose not
to speak and left the room voluntarily.
The hearing ended at approximately 5:20 P.M., after all of the speakers who had
chosen to do so had spoken.
Thursday, Febnruary 20, 1992
The Regents met at 1:00 P.M. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Smith, and Varner.
Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, and Vice Presidents
Hartford, Kelly, and Womack were also present, as were Chancellors Jones and
Wilson. Regent Waters and Vice President Cosovich were absent.

Comments regarding Vice President Hartford. President Duderstadt welcomed Maureen Hartford, Vice President for Student Affairs, to her first Regents'

with a roommate in South Quad. She then apologized for the student demonstrations that had occurred the previous day, noting that although she valued the students' opinions, she disapproved of the methods they had used in shutting down the
open hearing. Her challenge would be to develop some mechanisms to help students learn more appropriate methods for stating their opinions.

University of Michigan Hospitals Comparative Statistic Report
Vice President Womack introduced Mr. John Forsyth, executive director of
University of Michigan Hospitals, who noted that the purpose of this report was to
compare and contrast UM Hospitals' performance of the previous year to that of its
peers: the 22 AA-rated hospitals, the 421 other teaching hospitals, and 1,677 other
hospitals across the country. The comparisons are based on FY 1991 performance
and performance for the first six months of FY 1992, and measures used include
profitability, liquidity, capital structure, and patient activity.
Mr. Forsyth noted that in 1991 the Hospitals made $36 million, almost double
what it had made the previous year. He noted that in general the Hospitals had
made significant improvement in profitability measures relative to AA hospitals,
and had also made significant improvement over the national average of teaching
institutions. Liquidity figures had also shown marked improvement, with the
number of days in accounts receivable having decreased by 13 days from the previous year, while other institutions' days had increased.
Following some discussion about accounts receivable statistics, Mr. Forsyth discussed the capital structure and patient activity statistics. He noted that the Hospitals occupancy rate in FY 1991 was 30 percent higher than the national average and
20 percent higher than that for the average of teaching hospitals.
Mr. Forsyth then turned to a review of the Hospitals' performance during the
first six months of the current fiscal year, July 1-December 31, 1991. He noted that
patient caregivers comprise 69 percent of FTE employees, and non-caregivers comprise 31 percent. In March 1991, the number of FTE staff was frozen at the level of
6,813. By January 1992, the number of FTE employees had decreased by 208


-218 -



February Meeting, 1992


employees. However, the reduction in force process used to accomplish this has
had a net result of only 16 employees being unplaced, with only 8 of those being unemployed at the current time.
Mr. Forsyth concluded that even with no room rate increase, the cost per case
thus far in FY 1992 has been reduced both below the budgeted amount and below
the level of the previous year.
In the discussion that followed, Regents Baker and Power complimented Mr.
Forsyth and his staff for their superior performance in managing the University of
Michigan Hospitals. Regent Power asked that two questions be addressed at some
future time: 1) the national phenomenon of the rise in health care costs and how
the Hospitals would be affected by any national health care plans that might be established; and 2) the responsibility of public universities to help control steadily increasing health care costs, and specifically, what the Medical School and Hospitals
are doing to control these costs. Mr. Forsyth observed that his report had already
detailed some of the Hospitals' responses to the latter question.
1992-93 Residence Hall and Family Housing Rates
President Duderstadt called on Vice President Hartford to introduce the proposed 1992-93 residence hall and family housing rates. Vice President Hartford introduced Mr. Robert Hughes, director of housing, to present the proposal.
Mr. Hughes said that the Housing Division supports the recommendations of
the Single Student and Family Housing Rate Study Committees to increase both
residence hall and family housing rates for 1992-93 by an average of 4.9 percent, a
figure expected to closely parallel the inflation rate. The request includes no new
initiatives; however, there is a slight increase in the per capita allocation to capital
reserve accounts, and the family housing rates include an increase in the voluntary
contribution to the Ann Arbor public schools.
Mr. Hughes discussed some of the goals of the Housing Division, which include
making residence halls rates as competitive and cost-efficient as possible over the
long term. Two of the Housing Division's goals for the year 2000 are to be at the
leading edge nationally in terms of service, programs, technology, and staff support,
and to ensure the division's continued fiscal integrity while having a building mventory with a remaining useful life of 30 years by the year 2000.
He noted that the campus-wide Total Quality Management effort is particularly relevant to the Housing Division, with its wide variety of constituent groups,
and said that housing staff would be actively participating in this program as it
works toward a goal of remaining a national leader in its field into the 21st century.
He also noted the importance of housing's educational staff in enhancing the
out-of-classroom experience for students. From a competitive point of view, as
measured by other Big Ten and peer institutions, Mr. Hughes observed that the
University's package of programs, services, and facilities is one of the most comprehensive available anywhere.
Mr. Hughes concluded his presentation by pointing out the importance of
maintenance of housing's physical plant, and by noting the success of the program


-219 -



February Meeting, 1992


instituted last year that offers a number of meal plan and food service options both
to students who live in residence halls and those who live off campus.
There followed a discussion of issues raised in Mr. Hughes' pres entation, including the meal programs, the necessity of a 5 percent reserve rate, and the effect
of the rental market on residence hall occupancy In response to questions from
Regent Varner, Vice President Hartford observed that students today have different backgrounds, needs, and expectations for their residence hall experience than
did students of previous generations, and that issues such as expected advances in
technology require that future needs be planned for now. In response to a question
from Regent Baker, Mr. Hughes observed that residence hal occupancy is currently at 100 percent, with 99 percent of freshmen choosing to live in residence
halls.
Regent Smith asked why the Michigan League wasn't included in last year's
Fmerger of North Campu Commons and the Michigan Union into the Housing Division. Vice President Womack responded that it had not been discussed at that
time, but that this possibility is currently being considered.
At the end of the discussion, it was noted that the vote on the housing rate increase would be taken the following day.
Minutes
Consideration of the minutes of the January 1992 meeting was delayed until
the following month.
Reports
Vice President Womack submitted reports on Investment Transactions, Plant
Extension, Litigation, and Personnel-Labor Relations. He pointed out the effect
that low interest rates are having on the University Investment Pool.
Regent Baker observed that the University contributes to the tax base of the
city of Ann Arbor in many ways, due to the large number of its employees who own
houses in the city and its voluntary contribution to the public schools for North
Campus housing families who attend public school.
Vice President Kelly submitted reports on Summaries of a Selection of Current
Research and Sponsored Projects and Projects Established, Research and Other
Academic Activities.
On a motion by Regent Brown, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents voted
to receive the reports.
Voluntary Support
Noting that Vice President Cosovich was out of town, President Duderstadt
presented the Report of Gifts Received and Listing of Gifts of $5,000 and above for
January 1992. Regent Baker expressed his gratitude for the ongoing support of the
Ford family and Ford Motor Company for the University of Michigan- Dearborn.

Retirement Memoirs
On a motion by Regent Smith, seconded by Regent Varner, the Regents voted
unanimously to adopt the following retirement memoirs:
Eugene Arden, professor of English and former provost and vice chancellor for
academic affairs at the University of Michigan-Dearborn, retired from           active
faculty status on December 31, 1991, after 19 years of distinguished service to the
University of Michigan.
A native of New York City, Professor Arden received his BA           degree from
New York University in 1944, his M.A      degree from Columbia University in 1947,
and his Ph.D. degree from Ohio State University in 1953. After serving as
supervisor of instruction at the English Language Institute of Queens College from
1955-57, he then joined the faculty of Long Island University as an assistant
professor, rising to the ranks of associate professor in 1959 and professor in 1961.
At Long Island University, Professor Arden also served as chair of the Department
of English at C.W. Post College from 1957-62, director of the Humanities Division
from 1960-62, dean of the college at C.W. Post from 1962-64, university dean of the


-233 -



February Meeting, 1992


graduate faculties of arts and science from 1964-70, and executive dean of the
Brooklyn Center from 1970-72.
Professor Arden came to the University of Michigan-Dearborn in 1972 as
professor of English and as the campus's first vice chancellor and dean of academic
affairs. In 1989, his administrative title was changed to provost and vice chancellor
for academic affairs; he served in that position through December 31, 1990o As the
chief academic officer at UM-Dearbom, Professor Arden had a profound impact,
which extended throughout the Dearborn campus and beyond to the broader
University of Michigan community. As the principal architect of the academic
programs of the institution, his influence on the development of the campus was
pervasive.
The author of over 50 publications, Professor Arden's scholarly interests range
from the impact of urbanization on literature to curriculum development, teaching
improvement, administration and, most recently, university governance and faculty
development. He serves as a member of several national professional
organizations and has been a guest speaker at a number of commencements and
professional meetings. In November 1991, he was named editor of Academe, the
journal of the American Association of University Professors.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member and gifted administrator for his dedicated service by naming Eugene Arden Professor Emeritus of
English and Provost and Vice Chancellor for Academic Affairs Emeritus.
Guenther H. E. Elste, associate professor of astronomy, retired from active faculty status on December 31, 1991, after a long career as a teacher and researcher.
Born in Jauer, Schlesien, Germany, in 1923, Professor Elste completed both his
undergraduate and graduate studies at the University of GUttingen, starting in 1946.
He received the Ph.D. degree in astronomy at GUttingen in 1954.
Professor Elste's computing skills and knowledge of solar spectroscopy brought
him to the University of Michigan in 1954, where he served first as a research
assistant and then as a research associate until 1956. At that time, Leo Goldberg,
Edith Muller, and Lawrence Aller were working on their monumental determination of abundances in the sun, one of the most often cited astrophysical papers of
its day. While Professor Elste was too junior to be a principal author on that paper
at that time, a major portion of it made use of his computer programs and
numerical algorithms. Professor Elste returned to GUttingen in 1956, where he
served as an assistant in science at the University Observatory until 1962.
In addition to solar research, Professor Elste made pioneering calculations related to the atmospheres and abundances of stellar spectra. By the time he returned to the University of Michigan as an assistant professor, in 1962, he was established as a leader in the field of analytical astronomical spectroscopy. He was
promoted to associate professor in 1968, and was a popular doctoral dissertation
chair. Between 1962 and 1971, he directed nine doctoral students through the completion of the Ph.D.
Professor Elste's work has always been characterized by care and reliability.
For nearly a decade, his solar "Model 10" was the atmosphere of choice among
abundance workers. His interest in the structure of stellar atmospheres and their
spectra has continued throughout his career. The author of numerous publications,
his most recent paper was accepted by the Astrophysical Journal in the fall of 1991.
The Regents now salute this distinguished astronomer for his dedicated service
by naming Guenther H. E. Elste Associate Professor Emeritus of Astronomy.


-234 -



February Meeting, 1992


Ernest Fontheim, research scientist in the Space Physics Research Laboratory,
Department of Atmospheric, Oceanic, and Space Sciences, College of Engineering,
retired from active faculty status on December 31, 1991, after a productive career
as a researcher and teacher.
A native of Germany, Dr. Fontheim began his studies of physics and mathematics at the University of Berlin and the Technical University of Berlin-Charlottenburg after the end of World War II. He emigrated to the United States in 1947
and received his B.S. degree (physics) and A.B. degree (mathematics) from Southwest Missouri State College in 1950. He continued his studies and earned his M.S.
degree (hysics) in 1952 and his Ph.D. degree (physics) in 1960, both from Lehigh
University.
Dr. Fontheim joined the University of Michigan as an associate research scientist in 1960 in the Radiation Laboratory of the Department of Electrical Engineering and in 1962 accepted a position with the Space Physics Research Laboratory.
In 1963, he was promoted to research scientist.
Dr Fontheim's research activities were mainly concerned with the plasma physical aspects of ionospheric and magnetospheric phenomena. In the 1960s, he was
the first to publish calculations of the effects of the energy degradation of precipitating auroral electrons in the atmosphere. He later extended this research to predict anomalous transport effects in the upper ionosphere due to wave-partical interactions involving the precipitating auroral electrons and worked at various aspects of such transport effects. Also, he carried out research on the interaction of
the solar wind with the planet Venus.
In addition to being a productive researcher, Dr. Fontheim was active in educational and service activities. He taught a number of courses in both the Department of Electrical Engineering and the Department of Atmospheric, Oceanic, and
Space Sciences, where he introduced a new course on the solar wind and
magnetosphere. He served on a number of departmental, university, and national
committees, most recently on the University of Michigan Committee on the Economic Status of the Faculty. Dr. Fontheim held a National Academy of Sciences/National Research Council Senior Postdoctoral Research Associateship at
the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center in 1972 and again during the 1983-84 academic year. He has been appointed as a visiting scientist at the National Center for
Atmospheric Research, the Space Science Laboratory of the University of California, and the Centre de Recherches en Physique de l'Environment terrestre et
Planetaire in Paris. Dr. Fontheim also served as staff scientist, Solar System Exploration Division, NASA, and has lectured the Max Planck Institut fur Aeronomie in
Lindau, Federal Republic of Germany, the Space Research Institute of the Polish
Academy of Sciences in Warsaw, the Centre National d'Etudes des Telecommunications in Paris, and the Institut d'Aeronomie Spatiale de Belgique in Brussels.
The Regents now salute this distinguished space scientist for his long and productive service by naming Ernest G. Fontheim Research Scientist Emeritus.
Norma L Radin, professor of social work, retired on December 31, 1991, after
23 years of service to the University of Michigan.
A native of New York City, Professor Radin received her B.A. degree from
Brooklyn College in 1946, her MA degree from Columbia University in 1948, and
her M.S.W. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1965 and 1969,
respectively. She joined the faculty of the School of Social Work in 1968 as a


-235 -



February Meeting 1992


lecturer, and was promoted to assistant professor in 1969, associate professor in
1971, and professor in 1976.
Professor Radin is recognized as a leading scholar in the area of child development and parenting, with particular emphasis on the nontraditional family. Much
of her recent academic research has focused on determining the influence of
fathers and grandfathers on young children. She has writte extensively on early
childhood education interventions. Professor Radin received particular recognition
as an expert in school social work; she served for over 20 years as the School of
Social Work faculty member designated to recommend graduates for certification
as school social workers in the state of Michigan. Her retirement marks the
departure of an esteemed member of the faculty of the School of Social Work who
was devoted to identifying influential factors in early childhood development
The Regents now salute Norma L Radin by namg her Professor Emeritus of
Social Work.
Memorial
Provost Whitaker reported the death of one faculty member. Regent Power
moved, Regent Nielsen seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved, adoption of the following memorial:
The Regents of the University acknowledge with profound sadness the death
on December 4, 1991, of Betty Jean Davis, associate professor in the Registered
Nurse Studies Program in the School of Nursing.
Professor Davis was born in Decatur, Alabama on May 24, 1943. She attended
the Tuskegee Institute, receiving her B.S. degree in nursing in 1967 and staying on
to teach at the School of Nursing there from 1968-70. In June 1968, she married
Dr. George C. Davis and two years later she and her family moved to Ann Arbor.
She received her master's degree in psychiatric nursing in 1972 from the University
of Michigan. She then entered the Program in Educational Psychology, where she
earned her Ph.D. degree in 1973. Professor Davis held the position of associate
professor at Eastern Michigan University; since 1974, she has been in a similar
position at the University of Michigan.
Within the School of Nursing, Professor Davis taught graduate courses in psychiatric nursing. Her scholarly work focused on issues of advanced education, nursing education, and mental health nursing. Along with her teaching and research
responsibilities at the University, Professor Davis had a private practice in Christian psychology counseling. This practice provided an opportunity for her to minister to numerous troubled individuals and families. As the type of person that
would sacrifice her own needs to take care of those of other, she made a deep impression on those she helped.
Professor Davis died at her home after struggling for some time to overcome
the effects of her illness. She will be sorely missed by those who knew and loved
her. Our condolences go to her husband George, their children George and Erika;
her mother, Dorothy Guinn; her grandmother, Patti.Bibb of Decatur, Alabama; her
sisters, Valire Howard of Louisville, Kentucky, Carglon Nance of Oklahoma City,
Oklahoma, and Patti Camel of Decatur, Alabama; her brothers, James Eaddy of
Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, Levi Nance, Jr., of Pontiac, Michigan, and Walter
Nance of Detroit, Michigan; four aunts and seven uncles.

Semi-Annual Report for Designated Fund, Auxiliary Activities Fund, and Expendable Restricted Fund
The Regents received the Semi-Annual Report for the Designated Fund, Auxiliary Activities Fund, and Expendable Restricted Fund, and Vice President
Womack described some of its findings. He noted that there had been increased
enrollments in M-Care, and as a result, it is now doing well and is profitable. He
credited the leadership of Mr. Peter Roberts for improving the performance of
M-Care. He also observed that revenues for Intercollegiate Athletics had increased by eight percent over the previous year.
Audited Financial Reports for WUOM/WVGR/WFUM-FM and WFUM-TV for
the Fiscal Year Ended June 30, 1991; Statements of Support, Revenue, and Expenditures for WFUM-TV and WUOM/WVGR/WFUM-FM for the Years Ended June
30, 1991 and 1990
Vice President Womack submitted audited financial reports for WUOM/
WVGR/WFUM-FM and WFUM-TV for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1991. He
then called on Mr. Walter Harrison, executive director of University Relations, to
discuss the statements of support, revenue, and expenses for these operations.
Mr. Harrison noted that this had been a strong year for WFUM-TV, and he described the past year as a turn-around year for WUOM, with a surplus projected for
next year. He then responded to questions and comments from the Regents about
the possibilities for expanding coverage to the northern lower peninsula and the
upper peninsula, and about contracts for coverage of football and basketball
games. Regent Power asked that the Regents be provided with information on the

Public Hearing on Transfer of Police Authority
The Regents met at 4:00 P.M. in the Michigan Union Ballroom for the purpose
of conducting a public hearing on the transfer of police authority, as required by
Public Act 120 of 1990. Present were President Duderstadt, Vice President and
Secretary Kennedy, and Regents Baker, Brown, McFee, Power, Nielsen, Smith, and
Varner.
President Duderstadt called on the first speaker, Mr. Jon Falk. Because there
was a demonstration in the room, Mr. Falk was not able to make himself heard,
and it became impossible to carry out the hearing as planned. Therefore, Regent
Power read the following motion:
Motion to recess and remove. In accordance with the decisions of the Michigan Appellate Courts in Regents v Washtenaw County Coalition Against Apartheid
and because the breach of the peace which has been committed at this meeting has
made it impossible to conduct the business of this meeting in an orderly fashion in
this location, it is hereby moved that this meeting be recessed temporarily and removed to the Regents' Room, to be reconvened there at approximately 4:20 P.M.
Although those who have committed a breach of the peace at this meeting will be


-239 -



February Meeting, 1992


excluded from the reconvened meeting, representatives of the press will be
admitted and others having business at the reconvened meeting may be admitted as
space permits. University personnel shall be stationed at the doors to this meeting
room to advise the press and the public of this recess and the location of the
reconvened meeting. Regent Brown seconded the motion, and it was adopted.
The hearing reconvened at approximately 4:20 PM. in the Regents' Room. The
following individuals addressed the Regents: Jon Falk, staff; Joe Diederich, staff;
Karrin Kober, student; Amy Spade, student; Bill VanDoornik, staff; Susan McGee,
executive director of the Domestic Violence Project, Inc.; Brenton House, student;
Joel Strimling, student; Susan Pollay, director of the Ann Arbor Summer Festival;
Randy Frank, staff; Amy Polk, student; and Elizabeth Shaw, student.
The hearing ended at about 5:10 P.M.
Friday, February 21, 1992
The Regents met in closed session at 8:30 AM, and reconvened in public session, in the Regents' Room, at 9:30 AM. Present were President Duderstadt and
Regents Baker, Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Smith, Varner, and Waters. Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, and Vice Presidents Hartford, Kelly, and Womack were also present, as were Chancellors Jones and Wilson.
Vice President Cosovich was absent.
Colleges and Universities Public Safety Officers Act: Empowerment of Peace and
Police Officers
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order, and called on Vice President
Womack, who stated that the action request was described in the Regents communication. Regent Nielsen moved that the Regents authorize the empowerment of
peace and police officers in the Department of Public Safety and delegate the authority to grant such powers to the vice president and chief financial officer and his
written designees, as described in the Regents communication. Regent Power
seconded the motion.
Regent Brown expressed his support of the motion, and observed that safety officers under the University's jurisdiction would be much more responsive to the
needs of students and staff, and that this is one step in a program of increasing
campus safety for students.
Regent Nielsen said that the Regents are obligated to provide the most secure,
safe premises possible for students, both today and in the future. Providing a
security force that is answerable to the University community and not to some
other agency enables the Regents to carry out their obligation, and he was strongly
in support of the action.
Regent McFee pointed out that this was only a technical change in jurisdiction
of the existing deputized police force, and it would give the University an opportunity to work with concerned students to get their input on security issues.


-240 -



February Meeting, 1992


Regent Smith observed that she did not condone the behavior of the students
who had demonstrated the previous two days, but believed that some of the students she had spoken with had some valid concerns. Among these were the lack of
a democratic process, and she asked Vice President Hartford to address this.
Vice President Hartford stated that mechanisms need to be developed that get
students included earlier in processes such as appointments to committees and expressing their opinions to the Regents, and that she would work with students to
achieve these goals.
In response to other questions raised by Regent Smith on behalf of concerns
that had been expressed at the hearings, Mr. William Krumm, associate vice president for business operations, stated that the University's police force consists of
four Black officers, one Hispanic officer, and nine white officers, of which twelve
are male and two are female. Sworn supervisors include one Black and nine
whites. There are currently twenty-four police officers, including supervisors. Mr.
Krumm reported that there is not a separate police budget The Department of
Public Safety's budget was increased by $500,000 in the first year following
deputization; in the second year it was increased by $600,000.
On the issue of whether there is differential enforcement of a requirement for
producing identification to attend student-sponsored events at the Michigan Union,
Regent Baker and Vice President Hartford gave examples where white students
and staff who had no identification were denied admission. As for whether there
had been student involvement into the formulation and enforcement of this policy,
Vice President Hartford reported that a committee consisting predominantly of
students had been meeting regularly for some months and was continually
re-evaluating how to best handle security issues involving the Michigan Union.
Regent Brown emphasized that the Regents wanted to ensure that there would
not be discriminatory action taken at the Michigan Union, and noted that there is a
mechanism in place for handling individual complaints. Regent Varner observed
that historically, Black people have had generally very negative experiences with
police forces, and that this was a factor in the perceptions of many Black students
about a campus police force. She asked for assurances that the police training
would include adequate sensitivity training and understanding of this issue.
Regent Power observed that the issue was not whether to deputize campus
police, but what body should have jurisdiction over them. To achieve the desired
outcome of having the safest possible campus, it must have the best possible police
force, carefully selected and well-trained.
Regent Varner noted the concerns raised at the hearings about jurisdictional
issues between the campus and Ann Arbor police forces, and asked for more information about how the oversight board would operate. Provost Whitaker responded
that the election procedure has been worked out for faculty and staff and that the
student process was still being developed, in conjunction with MSA. The elected
board is charged with investigation of complaints against police officers, while the
already existing appointed board, which is larger and more broadly-representative
of campus constituencies, would be continued and would deal with policy questions.


-241 -



February Meeting 1992


Regent Baker recalled an incident that had occurred at a Regents' meeting a
number of years ago, during which someone had been arrested by the Ann Arbor
police. He expressed support for the motion, noting that if the University had had
its own police force at that time, the arrest might have been avoided.
There being no further discussion, the vote was then taken, and the motion was
approved, with Regents Baker, Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Varner, and Waters
in favor and Regent Smith opposed.
