Proposed Research Subcontract between the University of Michigan and Anjoy
Research, Inc.
On a motion by Regent Baker, seconded by Regent Brown, all seven Regents
present unanimously approved a proposed r research subcontract between the
University of Michigan and Anjoy Research, Inc. Because the president and
chairman of the board of Anjoy Research, Inc., Claes G. Fornell and Michael J.
Ryan, are also University employees, this arrangement falls under the State of
Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in
compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the agreement will be Anjoy Research, Inc., and the Regents of the University of Michigan. Professor Michael J. Ryan
will sign the contract on behalf of Anjoy.
2.  The proposed subcontract will be consistent with University research policies. There will be no restrictions on publication or
openness of the research. The subcontract will cover the period
July 1, 1991, through December 31, 1992, at an estimated cost of
$336,743 including 57 percent indirect cost. Fifty percent of a
graduate student's salary and related fringe benefits will be covered as well as 60 percent of Dr. Fornell's salary. The dean's office
will appoint a project director other than Fornell or Ryan.
3.  The total contract to Anjoy is approximately $940,000. Drs.
Fornell and Ryan represent that they receive no salary from Anjoy
for their efforts on the project. Fomell, Ryan, and their spouses
each own 25 percent of Anjoy.
Proposed License Agreement between the University of Michigan and Theragen,
Inc.
Regent Smith moved, Regent Power seconded, and all seven Regents present
unanimously approved, the University's entering into a license agreement with
Theragen, Inc., through which to develop and commercialize a new approach to


-243 -



March Meeting, 1992


gene therapy ("technology"). Because the principals of Theragen, Inc., are or
were at the time the technology was invented University employees, this arrangement falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following
information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the contract will be the Regents of the University of
Michigan and Theragen, Inc., a corporation owned in part by the
principals.
2.  Terms of the contract include: a duration for the term of the last
to expire of the licensed patents (or the earlier of January 1,2003,
or seven years from the date of the first commercial sale, if a
longer term would thereby arise), and consideration to the University consisting of payment of royalties, including minimum royalties, on sales of the technology and on sublicensed rights granted in
the technology. Royalties will be paid at a rate of 5 percent for
revenues from the sale or use of patented technology, 3 percent for
revenues from the sale or use of unpatented technology, and 25
percent of revenues generated by sublicenses in the technology
provided Theragen remains located within the state of Michigan,
or 30 percen of revenue generated by sublicenses in the technology if Theragen moves outside the state of Michigan. Minimum
royalties shall commence in 1996; such minimum royalties shall be
$20,000 in 1996, $30,000 in 1997, and $50,000 in 1998 and thereafter during the duration of the agreement. The University retains
ownership of the technology, and will be assigned joint ownership
of any inventions relating to the technology which are created
jointly by University employees and Theragen employees, and will
also be assigned sole ownership of any inventions relating to the
technology which are created solely by University employees who
are concurrently employed by Theragen. The University retains
the right to use the technology for research and educationallyrelated purposes. Theragen shall make reasonable efforts to
pursue the commercial development and exploitation of the technology. There is no use of facilities or services of the University
included in the contract and no assignment of University employees for fulfillment of the contract.
3.  The principals' pecuniary interest in the contract arises from their
ownership of Theragen. This corporation will receive revenues
from the sale, use, and sublicensing of the technology, and the University will receive a share of those revenues. The principals' interest in that corporation will be in lieu of participation in the
sharing of royalties received by the University in accordance with
University policy. Dr. Goins, a developer of the technology but
not a principal of Theragen, will remain eligible to participate in
an appropriate percentage portion, based on his agreed-upon contribution to the technology, of the applicable inventors' share of
royalties that may result from the proposed Theragen license
agreement.

March Meeting, 1992


Annual Report on Investments as of December 31, 1991
President Duderstadt called on Vice President Womack, who introduced Mr.
Norman Herbert, the University's investment officer, and Mr. David Thurston of
Cambridge Associates, the University's investment advisor.
Mr. Herbert reviewed the Report of Investments as of December 31, 1991.
He noted that the Donor Pooled Income fund is an investment pool for charitable remainder trusts. During 1991, the market value of this fund increased from
$3.3 million to $4.2 million. he objective of this fund is to provide income of at
least 6 percent while protecting the purchasing power of the distribution to the
beneficiaries and the fund's principal, in which the University has a charitable remainder interest. In ten years time, the income objective has been met, and the
real value of the fund has been enhanced.
Regarding the University Investment Pool, the strategy in 1991 was to stabilize returns during a period of sharp declines in short term interest rates. This
fund yielded 7.8 percent, which compares favorably with the 5.7 percent average
for money market mutual funds. The UIP is the investment fund for the University's working capital, and its objective is to provide a stable level of income consistent with the preservation of principal, while offering participants daily liquidity. During 1991, this fund provided investment income of $61 million.
The University Endowment Fund, which had a 25.8 percent return in 1991,
went from $431.6 million at December 31, 1990, to $562.5 million at December
31, 1991. Of this, $50.4 million was newly invested money, and $26 million of the
investment returns was distributed to participants. A ten-year history of this fund
shows that it had a beginning value of $110.7, contributions of $317.0, reinvested
returns of $134.8, and distributed returns of $156.1. The long term goal of the
University Endowment Fund is to maintain and enhance the purchasing power of
the principal and of the stream of distribution. In 1991, the real value of this
fund was enhanced by 17.5 percent. Over the past ten-year period, the real value
of the fund was enhanced by 3.5 percent per year.
Mr. Herbert then turned the meeting over to Mr. Thurston. Mr. Thurston reviewed the University's endowment strategies in the areas of asset allocation,
common stock management, and fixed income management. Referring to a
handout, he noted that during 1991 the University had consolidated its common
stock managers by adding one manager and deleting two managers. It had also
increased its exposure in the areas of international, real estate, oil and gas, and
venture capital investments. In fixed income investments, it had increased the alternative fixed income portfolio.
Regarding alternative asset investments, Mr. Thurston displayed a chart
showing how commitments had been increased, according to the direction of the
Regents, in the various alternative investment areas which comprise 12 percent
of the fund. He also illustrated how the common stock managers had performed
during recent cyclical variations in the stock market compared to the S&P 500
and the Russell 2000, as well as how the University's performance and allocations


-245 -



March Meeting, 1992


compared with Cambridge Associates' endowment mean, which includes 62 colleges and universities.
Common Stock Management of the University Endowment Fund: Capital
Growth Management
Mr. Thurston then introduced a request to appoint Capital Growth
Management as an investment manager of the University Endowment Fund. He
pointed out the excellent, long-term record of this company's stock portfolio
manager, G. Kenneth Heebner. In response to a question from Regent Power,
Vice President Womack noted that investment managers are chosen on the basis
of individual managers' performance, not on the reputation of the company they
work for. If there were changes in the individual personnel managing the
University's portfolio in any of investment managers, his staff would carefully
consider whether to stay with that company. Following further discussion,
Regent Power moved, Regent Varner seconded, and the Regents unanimously
approved the appointment of Capital Growth Management as an investment
manager for the University Endowment Fund.

Retirement Memoir
On a motion by Regent Baker, seconded by Regent Varner, the Regents
voted unanimously to adopt the following retirement memoir:
Betty M. Morrison, professor of education, retired from active faculty status
on January 31, 1992, after 22 years of service to the University of Michigan.
Professor Morrison received her B.S. degree from the University of Michigan
in 1952, her M.S. degree from Wayne State University in 1958, and her MA    and
Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1965 and 1966, respectively.
During the period 1952-62, Professor Morrison was a medical technologist at St.
Joseph Hospital in Mt. Clemens, Michigan, and from 1958-62, she also worked
part-time as a research psychologist at the Rehabilitation Institute in Detroit. In
1962, she joined the Jackson public schools, where she worked for a year as a
school psychologist. After serving as an assistant professor at Case Western
Reserve University from 1966-70, Professor Morrison joined the University of
Michigan School of Education as an associate professor of education in 1970; she
was promoted to professor in 1974.
During her years with the School of Education, Professor Morrison taught
courses in educational psychology, statistics, and research design. She also


-254 -



March Meeting, 1992


worked extensively on a one-to-one basis with her graduate students, assisting
them with writing and publishing research articles and reports. Her student
evaluations were consistently excellent and she received kudos from students and
colleagues on a regular basis. Professor Morrison served on a number of School
of Education and University-wide committees, including the Commission on
Women, the Committee on the Status of Women in Graduate Education, and the
Research Advisory Board of the Center for Afroamerican Studies.
During her career, Professor Morrison has been very active with various professional organizations, including the American Educational Research Association, for which she regularly presented papers at its annual meetings. She was
honored by that organization in 1985 as a "Distinguished Researcher and
Scholar." Professor Morrison's "Joint Hampton-Michigan Project" (with Professor Wilbert McKeachie), funded by NIE in the late seventies, was held in high
regard as an exemplary educational training project
The Regents now salute this distinguished educator by naming Betty M.
Morrison Professor Emeritus of Education.

University Endowment Fund
Vice President Womack commented that $317 million had been donated to
the University over the past ten years by individuals and coorations, largely
from the state of Michigan. He pointed out that the life blood of an endowment
is giving, and that it is a tribute to the people and corporations in the state and
nation that they have been willing to give to the University. A lot of the credit
for the growth m the endowment should be given to Vice President Cosovich and
the deans and others in the University who work hard to maintain the level of
contributions.

Resolution Authorizing the Issuance of Declarations of Intent to Reimburse the
Regents for Project Expenditures from the Proceeds of Bonds
Vice President Womack and Mr. Herbert explained that passage of this resolution is required to meet regulations issued by the Internal Revenue Service on
January 27, 1992. These regulations list three general requirements which must
be met by a tax-exempt bond issuer (see Regents communication for details).
Following some discussion, Regent Power moved, Regent Waters seconded,
and all six Regents present unanimously approved the following resolution, which
designates the vice president and chief financial officer to issue declarations of
intent to reimburse the Regents for project expenditures from the proceeds of
bonds.
Resolution of the Regents of the University of Michigan Authorizing
the Issuance of Declarations of Intent to Reimburse the Regents
for Project Expenditures from the Proceeds of Bonds
WHEREASM the Regents of the University of Michigan (the "Issuer") is a constitutional body
corporate established pursuant to Article VIII, Section 5 of the Michigan Constitution of 1963, as
amended, with genera supervision of the University of Michigan (the University") and the control
and direction ofall expenditures from the Universitys funds; and
WHEREAS, the United States Treasury has issued regulations7 codified as Treas. Reg. Section
1.103-18 (the "Reulations"), requiring the prior declaration of an issuer's intent to reimburse itself
from debt proceeds for expenditures paid pnrior to the issuance of the debt obligations; and
WHEREAS, the Regulations specifically permit a bond issuer to delegate to a person the power
to issue declarations of intent to reimburse the issuer from debt proceeds for expenditures made by
the issuer prior to the issuance of the debt; and
WHEREAS, in order to maximize the efficient use of University funds it is necessary to
authorize the vice president and chief financial officer to issue declarations of intent to reimburse,
in accordance with the Regulations.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF
MICHIGAN, that the vice president and chief financial officer is hereby delegated the power,
and duly authorized, to issue for and on behalf of the Issuer, declarations of intent to reimburse the
Issuer from the proceeds of the future debt of the Issuer for expenditures paid prior to the issuance
of the debt for any projects of the Issuer, all in accordance with the Reguations. Such declarations
shall comply with all requirements of the Regulations, including, but not limited to, requirements
with respect to public inspection of the declarations.

Resolution Honoring Michigan Wolverines Men's Basketball Team
Regent McFee offered the following resolution:
RESOLUTION
The Regents of the University of Michigan wish to commend the
Michigan Wolverine men's basketball team for their extraordinary season.
This basketball team, widely heralded from the start of the season as
the 'Fab Five," but in reality an entire team of players, coaches, and staff
dedicated to working together to achieve a common goal, astounded
basketball fans all season long. After finishing third in the Big Ten
Conference, they surprised sports pundits by winning the southeastern
regional championship with a thrilling overtime victory over Ohio State.
They went on to defeat the University of Cincinnati in the semi-finals
of the national championship, but fell one game short of their ultimate
goal losing the championship to number-one-ranked Duke University.


-259 -



April Meeting 1992


Their goal they said, was to "shock the world." Indeed, they did that
and more: They inspired Michigan alumni and fans everywhere by proving
that a team that sets goals and works hard to achieve them can succeed
against overwhelming odds. In doing so, they transcended sports by being
models for all of us in our daily lives.
The Regents salute the 1991-92 men's basketball team and look
forward to their fulfilling their dream in the years to come
Regent Nielsen seconded the motion, and it was adopted by acclamation.
Regent McFee noted that five Regents had attended the Final Four games, and
that all are proud of the way the team members, both individually and collectively, conducted themselves during that time.
Status of the 1992-93 State Budget Request
President Duderstadt called on Vice President Kennedy, who noted that the
governor was to issue an executive order that day which would exclude education
from proposed reductions of $200 million. However, the legislature must either
accept or reject the executive order, and some members feel that reductions
ought to be made across all sectors of the budget which would include higher
education. Therefore, it is hard to predictit  the  al outcome of the governor's
proposal.
President Duderstadt noted that like many states, Michigan is in the midst of
a fiscal crisis, but that even in the midst of deep budget cuts, the governor and
legislature have made education a priority. The governor's exemption of higher
education from his executive order reflects his continuing commitment to
education. The president reiterated the University's pledge to work with state
leaders in supporting the difficult actions that must be taken if Michigan is to
regain strength and prosperity. He expressed his appreciation for the decision to
make education a top priority in Michigan, which will enable the state to develop
its human resources to serve as the capital of the new economy.
Regent Nielsen observed that at the budget hearings, the possibility was
raised of utilizing the expertise of the University's faculty and staff to assist
legislators in dealing with the problems confronting them. He suggested that this
idea be explored further, as it would benefit both the state and perhaps local
governments as well as the University.
Vice President Kennedy pointed out that the Institute for Public Policy
Studies (IPPS) has held workshops for state legislators along the lines suggested
by Regent Nielsen, and he supported Regent Nielsen's suggestion as being a
useful way to utilize the University's resources to better serve the state.
Regent Baker observed that the state's current fiscal problems are similar to
those it faced during the early 1980s. He wanted to be sure that the legislature is
aware of the damage being done to the institution due to the fiscal constraints.
President Duderstadt reported that he and other University officials had
completed a videotaped discussion about many of the fiscal issues facing the


-260 -



April Meeting 1992


University, which would be aired on community access cable television in
upcoming weeks.

unanimously approved the minutes of the meeting of March 12, 1992.
Reports
Vice President Womack submitted reports on Investment Transactions, Plant
Extension, Litigation, and Personnel-Labor Relations. He also submitted a
Report on Non-Competitive Purchases over $2,000 from Single Sources from
January 1 through March 31, 1992.
Olympia & York Investment. With respect to the investment report, Vice
President Womack noted that the University Investment Pool has a $30 million
investment in Olympia & York Floating Rate First Mortgage Notes (now called
237 Park Avenue Associate Senior First Mortgage Notes). He emphasized that
the University is not an investor in any of Olympia & York's properties except for
three separately capitalized commercial properties in Manhattan. He called on
Mr. Norman Herbert, the University's investment officer, to comment.
Mr. Herbert reviewed information from a handout he distributed that explained the nature of the University's investment in the Olympia & York properties. He noted that the University's investment in these notes is secured by first
lien mortgages on all three properties and lease hold interests in addition on two
of the three properties, and that every monthly payment has been received by the
University during its holding period. Mr. Herbert explained further the extent
and cause of Olympia & York's current cash flow problems. He noted that the
market value of the University's Olympia & York investment represents about
2.3 percent of the investment pool, and that this is under the cap of 5.0 percent of
the pool's value in floating notes. Mr. Herbert concluded his remarks with
information about the cash flow and occupancy rates from the three buildings.
Regent Baker made further observations about Olympia & York, and noted
that he had opposed this investment because, as he recollected, it didn't follow
the basic criteria established by the Regents for bond investment. He pointed
out that the owners of the securities have the right to foreclose in the event of
nonpayment, and stated his expectation that staff would carefully evaluate this
option and proceed promptly with foreclosure if payments are not forthcoming.
Mr. Herbert confirmed that the University is in close contact with the trustee,
and would collaborate with the other noteholders in pursuing the options
available to them in the event of default, including foreclosure. He noted that
the buildings continue to represent excellent values, and that they are secured,
first mortgage lien interest notes.


-261 -



April Meeting 1992


There was further discussion of this issue, with comments by Regents Baker,
Varner, Power, Smith, and Brown. Mr. Herbert noted that the buildings had apprecated in value since the notes were originally issued, and that although real
estate values around the world had declined in recent years, they were especially
optimistic about the two properties in midtown New York City.
Vice President Womack emphasized that there is a downside risk to any investment, and the purpose of this discussion was to put on the record the
distinction between Olympia & York's general situation and the three properties
in which the University has exposure.
Following further discussion, Vice President Kelly submitted monthly reports
of Projects Established, Research and Other Activities, and Summaries of a
Selection of Current Research and Sponsored Projects. On a motion by Regent
Varner, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents voted unanimously to receive
the reports.

Retirement Memoirs
On a motion by Regent Power, seconded by Regent Smith, the Regents voted
unanimously to adopt the following retirement memoir:
Peter H. Amann, professor of history at the University of Michigan-Dearborn,
will retire from active faculty status on April 30, 1992.
A native of Austria, Professor Amann arrived in the United States as a refugee in 1941. He received his BA  degree with honors from Oberlin College in
1947. After stints as a salesman and machinist, he enrolled in the history graduate
program of the University of Chicago where he received his M.A. degree in 1953
and his Ph.D. degree in 1958. From 1956-59, he served as an instructor of history
at Bowdoin College and from 1959-65, as assistant and then associate professor at
Oakland University. He then went to the State University of New York at
Binghamton, before accepting an appointment as professor of history at the University of Michigan-Dearborn in 1968.
As a scholar, Professor Amann's interests range from French to American history and from the eighteenth to the twentieth centuries. He has studied de
Tocqueville's intellectual influence on later historians, a curious nineteenthcentury American millennial movement, Parisian popular mobilization during the
French Revolution of 1848, theoretical constructs of revolution, depression-era
American radical right movements, agricultural modernization in contemporary
France, and, currently, the impact of the French Revolution of 1789 on French
peasant communities. Professor Amann has written and published, in both English and French, in major professional journals, including the American Historical
Review, Journal of Modem History, International Review of Social History, Comparative Studies in History and Society, Revue d'histoire de la Deuxieme Guerre Mondiale,
European History Quarterly, and the New England Quarterly. Several of his articles
have been anthologized, some of them repeatedly. He has also authored two favorably-received scholarly books and several anthologies intended for undergraduates.
Professor Amann has successfully sought to balance his commitment to historical scholarship with an equal commitment to liberal education at the undergraduate level and conscientious participation in faculty governance. Over the years, he
developed and taught a wide range of courses, many of them far outside his specialties, and he also participated in the basic interdisciplinary course which shapes
the Honors Program. Professor Amann received the first University of MichiganDearborn teaching award in 1975 and was also the first recipient of the William B.
Stirton Distinguished Professorship. He also participated in numerous faculty


-270 -



April Meeting 1992


advisory and search committees.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his dedicated service by
naming Peter H. Amann Professor Emeritus of History.

Refinancing of $56 Million Hospital Revenue Bonds, Series 1986B
Vice President Womack explained this proposal to refinance the outstanding
$56 million Hospital Revenue Bonds, Series 1986B, variable rate issue, because of
the opportunity to eliminate the costs associated with the letter of credit that is required as a liquidity facility. The liquidity requirement would instead be provided
through the use of the Hospitals' cash and cash equivalents or marketable securities.
In response to questions from Regent Nielsen, Vice President Womack emphasized that the $56 million in liquid assets would not be a set-aside; that amount
would always be available reardless of the circumstances. Mr. Herbert pointed
out that at any one time the University always has from $200 million to $250 million in liquid assets available as part o a University-wide pool.
Regent Baker pointed out that $5  on would be saved over the life of the
bond under this proposal. Vice President Womack reported that the issuing costs
would be recovered m about two years.
There being no farther discussion, Regent Brown moved that the Regents
adopt a resolution which authorizes the vice president and chief financial officer
to:
1)  together with the Underwriters, develop the terms and legal documentation for the bonds, and to prepare, circulate and execute preliminary and final official statements describing the bonds, the
University, the Hospital, and its affairs; and
2)  to apply for and obtain from Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's Corporation their ratings on the bonds; and
3)  to obtain a final proposal for the Bonds, including price and initial
interest rate, negotiate, execute and deliver the bond purchase and
remarketing agreement with the underwriters, a trust indenture


-271 -



April Meeting 1992


with a trustee to be selected, a tender agent agreement with a tender agent to be selected and related documentation setting forth
the terms of the bonds and the sale and remarketing thereof all
within the limitations of the following resolution.
Regent Power seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.

Proposed License Agreement between the University of Michigan and MetaComputer
Regent Power moved, Regent Varner seconded, and all seven Regents present unanimously approved, a license agreement between the University of Michigan
and MetaComputer, Inc., to develop and commercialize a computer software program,
"AV Tracker." Because the owner of MetaComputer, Peter Wurman, is also a University employee, this arrangement falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest
Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the contract will be the Regents of the University of
Michigan and MetaComputer, Inc., a corporation owned by Peter
Wurman.
2.  Terms of the contract include: an effective duration of the term of
the University's copyright in the program, and consideration to the
University consisting of payment of royalties, including minimum
royalties, on licenses of the program to end users and to
sublicensee developers. Royalties wil be paid at a rate of 10 percent for revenues from the license of the program to end users and
25 percent for revenues from the license of the program to
sublicensee developers. Minimum royalties shall commence in
1993; such minimum royalties shall be $250.00 per year. The University retains ownership of the program, and royalties will be paid
to the University on revenues generated by any derivative works
developed by MetaComputer from the program. The University
retains the right to use the program internally. MetaComputer
shall make reasonable efforts to pursue the commercial development of the program. There is no use of facilities or services of the
University included in the contract and no assignment of University employees for fulfillment of the contract.
3.  Peter Wurman's pecuniary interest in the contract arises from his
ownership of MetaComputer. This corporation will receive revenues from its licensing of the program, and the University will receive a share of those revenues. Wurman's interest in that corporation will be in lieu of participation in the sharing of royalties received by the University in accordance with University policy.

Ford Hospital

and Henry Ford Hospital (HFH) for HFH's participation in clinical core activities supported by a grant to the University from the National Institutes of Health,
as described in the Regents communication. Because the principal investigators
who are parties to the subcontract, Drs. John Popovich, Jr. and Robert Hyzy, are
employees of Henry Ford Hospital and also hold clinical appointments at the
Unmversity of Michigan, this arrangement falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance
with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the subcontract will be Henry Ford Hospital (HFH) and
the Regents of the University of Michigan Raymond F. Jones, administrative director for research, wil sign the subcontract for
Henry Ford Hospital.
2.  The subcontract will obligate HFH to participate in the clinical
core activities. Specifically, HFH will support the needs of the individual research projects to obtain patient samples and clinical
data and assist in the data compilation and analysis. A total subcontract of $854,490 is planned over the five-year period. The proposed scope of work and budget are described in the subcontract.
3.  Neither Dr. Popovich nor Dr. Hyzy will receive a salary or other
pecuniary benefit from the University. Their Clinical Track I
appointments at the University are without effort, without salary,
and do not allow them to see patients at the University under any

activities will be reimbursed by HFH under the subcontract.
Revision of Regents' Bylaw Section 3.07 (Approval and Execution of University
Documents)
Vice President Womack submitted a proposal to change in Regents' Bylaw
Section 3.07 to designate specifically certain officers of the institution to transact
certain business, provides for the University to execute named documents, and
provides that delegation by the vice president and chief financial officer shall be
in writing to eliminate any question of the grant of authority to a particular individual. He noted that Mr. John Ketelhut, of the general counsel's office, had
drafted the bylaw revision. Vice President Womack also pointed out that no new
positions would be added as a result of the bylaw changes; they simply recognize
and reflect the University's current business practices.
In the discussion that followed, Mr. Ketelhut pointed out that new language
in paragraph.a. was written to facilitate real estate transactions involving estates
in other states. Regent Baker stated that he was troubled that the proposed
bylaw changes separate the Regents from the decision-making process, in that
transactions can take place without the Regents' knowledge until after the fact.
Mr. Herbebrt responded that the benefit of the change would be that it enables the executor to deliver to a purchaser without the property being titled to
the Regents, which is a benefit to the University in several respects, including
avoiding possible involvement with questions of hazardous waste contamination,
which Regent Baker had pointed out.
Further discussion followed about the details of the proposed bylaw change.
In response to a comment from Regent Baker about the reporting mechanism,
Vice President Womack stated that all transactions occurring under the bylaw
provision would be highlighted in reporting to the Regents.
Following a five-minute recess, Regent Nielsen said he would support the
bylaw change, but asked that the Regents receive a separate report monthly highlighting the transactions that occur. Following further discussion, it was decided
that the transactions would be reported on and highlighted monthly in a manner
determined to be most instructive by the development and investment staffs.
On a motion by Regent Varner, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved a revision of Regents' Bylaw Section 3.07. The following
is the text of the revised bylaw:
Sec. 3.07: Approval and Execution of University Documents
1.  All transactions involving the purchase, sale, or other disposition of
real property shall be first approved and authorized by the Board.
Unless othenvrwise specifically provided by the Board all land contracts
and deeds conveying University property shall be executed by the president and the vice president and chief financial officer.

Revision of Regents' Bylaws Sections 2.09, 7.03, 7.04, 7.05, 11.219 (Office of the
Vice President for Student Affairs)
Vice President Kennedy noted that this revision would change all mention in
the bylaws of the position of vice president for student services to vice president
for student affairs. Vice President Hartford observed t   this would make the
University's title for this position consistent with that of its peer institutions.

unanimously approved revisions to Regents' Bylaws Section 2.09. 7.03, 7.04, 7.05,
and 11.219. The text of the revised bylaws follows:
Sec. 209. The Vice President for Sudent Affairs
The vice president for student affairs shall be the chief administrative
officer of the Office of Student Affairs; shall designate heads of the various
units of the Office of Student Affairs, with the advice of the Student Affairs
Policy Board; and shall advise the Board, the president, the governing faculties, and other appropriate agencies concerning student affairs and student services in general (See also Sec. 7.04.)
Sec. 7.03. Office ofStudentAffairs
The Office of Student Affairs (hereinafter sometimes referred to in
these bylaws as OSA) shall provide programs relating to housing, counseling, student organizations, health, occupational information, religious affairs, student-community relations, the International Center, and such


-278 -



April Meeting 1992


other programs as may from time to time be delegated to it.
Sec. 7.04. Vice President for StudentAffairs
The vice president for student affairs shall be the chief administrative
officer of the Office of Student Affairs, shall designate newly-appointed
heads of the various units of OSA with the advice of the Student Affairs
Policy Boad, and shall advise the Board of Regents, the president, the governing faculties, and other appropriate agencies concerning student affairs
and student services in general
Sec. 7.05. Student Participation in Decision-Making
1. Student participation in University decision-making is important
to the quality of student life at the University, and shall be encouraged The vice president for student affairs shall assist students in promoting the establishment of effective mechanisms for
such student participation.
2  A Student Affairs Policy Board is hereby created. The board
shall have nine members, composed of students and faculty, there
being one more student than faculty, with the vice president for
student affairs serving as chair without vote
a. Student members shall be appointed by AMSA, and no more
than two shall come from any one school or college Where
school or college government exists, MSA shall consult them
before appointing any student from that school or college.
b. Faculty members shall be appointed by the Senate Assembly,
and not more than two members shall come from any one
school or college
c   The terms of office shall be staggered and shall be not less
than one year nor more than three, and the procedures for selecting members shall so long as they are consistent with (a)
and (b) above, be determined by the appropriate appointing
body.
d. In the event the appointing bodies fail to act within a reasonable time, the Student Affairs Policy Board shall be empowered to name replacements.
3. The director of each student affairs unit shall be the chief administrative officer of the director's unit and shall report to the vice
president for student affairs. Policy boards may be established by
the vice president for student affairs and the Student Affairs
Policy Board for each administrative unit of OSA, in which case
the unit director shall serve as chair without vote of the policy
board.

Sec. 11.219. The Department of Athletics: Advisor Committee on Recreational Sorts
The Advisory Committee on Recreational Sports shall be constituted
as follows: (1) the associate director for recreational sports ex ocio: (2)
four members of the University Senate to be appointed by the president
from a panel of senate members chosen by SACUA, subject to the approval of the Board of Regents. The appointed members shall hold office
for two years but in no event shall any member of the senate serve more
than two terms, except that if a member be appointed to fill an unexpired
term of one year or less that member shall also be eligible for two full
terms. The terms of the members shall be staggered so that two terms shall
expire each year. The panel from which the appointments are made each
year shall be unranked and contain twice the number of names as there are
vacancies If a vacancy in the appointive senate membership shall occur
from causes other than the completion of the appointive term, the president
is authorized to make an interim appointment from the most recent panel
of names submitted by SACUA, or, if the president so requests, from a new
panel of names submitted by SACUA; (3) a staff representative from the
Office of Student Affairs selected by the vice president for student affairs;
(4) four students of the University to be appointed by the president from a
panel of students chosen by MSA, subject to approval by the Board of Regents. The student members shall serve two-year terms which shall be staggered so that two students are appointed each year. In no event shall any
student member serve more than two terms consecutively, except that if a
member shall be appointed to fill an unexpired term of one year or less,
that member shall also be eligible for two full terms. The panelfrom which
the appointments are made shall be unranked and shall contain twice the
number of names as there are vacancies. If a vacancy in the appointive
student membership shall occur from causes other than the completion of
the appointive term, the president is authorized to make an interim appointment from the most recent panel of names submitted by MSA, or, if
the president so requests, from a new panel of names chosen by MSA.

MAY MEETING, 1992


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, May 14, 1992
The Regents met at 1:10 P.M. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Smith, Varner,
and Waters. Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, and Vice Presidents Hartford, Kelly, and Womack were also present, as were Chancellors Jones and Wilson. Provost Whitaker and Vice President Cosovich were absent; Associate Vice
President Holbrook attended in place of Provost Whitaker.
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and called on Regent
Nielsen, who made the following motion:
Executive Session Motion
Pursuant to Sections 8(e), 8(f), and 8(h) of the Michigan Open Meetings Act, as
amended by 1984 PA 202, move that the Board ofegents meet in closed ofsession
on May 14, 1992, at 3:00 P.M. in the Regents' Room, Fleming Administration Building, for the purpose of considering material exempt from discussion or disclosure by
the Michigan Freedom of Information Act. Such exempt material consists of consulting with the Board's legal counsel in connection with specific pending litigation
[sections 8(e) and 8(h)], and the review of the contents of applications for employment, where confidentiality has been requested by the candidates [section 8(f)].
Regent Power seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
CESF Report - Ann Arbor Campus
President Duderstadt called on Professor Ejner Jensen, chair of the Senate
Advisory Committee on University Affairs. Professor Jensen introduced Professor Emeritus Fred Beutler, chair of the Committee on the Economic Status of
the Faculty, to present that committee's report.
Professor Beutler's presentation concentrated on three topics: an analysis of
faculty salaries, concerns about changes in health benefits, and administrative
growth. The salary analysis shows that average salaries for assistant and associate
professor ranks are higher than the average of peer institutions, while those for
full professors are lower. CESF describes this phenomenon as a "loyalty tax" on
full professors, and the group believes that it is destructive to the morale of
senior faculty and promotes their departure. They proposed that CESF and the
administration jointly undertake further analysis and study of this issue.
There are several issues of concern: in the area of health benefits: the perceived possibility that fiscal constraints might lead to changes in coverage without
CESFs having been consulted, and long-range prospects for the continuation of
medical benefits for retirees. The latter issue is of particular concern because
this is an unfunded liability with a potential total of over $200 million.


-283 -



May Meeting, 1992


The pattern of growth in University administration, as documented in the
Holbrook Report (March 1991), remains an area of concern to faculty. CESF
recommends that a public report focusing on changes in staffing in all employee
categories be issued annually so that a meaningful dialogue can be undertaken on
priorities.
In the discussion that followed, Associate Vice President Holbrook stated
that CESF would be invited to play an active role in any discussion of changes in
staff benefits. In response to a question from Regent Power, Vice President
Womack confirmed that the future liability for retiree health care benefits does
indeed represent a major financial problem for the University.
Following further discussion of this issue, the president called on Chancellor
Wilson, who introduced Professor Arefaine Yohannes, chair of CESF at UMDearborn.
CESF Report, UM-Dearborn
Professor Yohannes noted that his committee's recommendations are the
same as those of last year: to raise the average UM-D faculty salaries to the
median level of Michigan HA average salaries in the short-run and to at least the
80th percentile level in the long-run; and to provide tuition assistance to spouses
and dependents of faculty. He noted that not much progress had been made
toward achieving these goals, although the figures might be somewhat more encouraging if spring/summer salaries were included.
Regent Power noted that Chancellor Wilson does not disagree with the
salary goals, and that the major stumbling block toward achieving these goals is
in the willingness of the state legislature to fund the Dearborn campus. Professor
Yohannes concurred, noting that Chancellor Wilson had implemented some special merit increases, although these had not substantially reduced the gap.
Regent Baker noted that the Regents are limited in the actions they can take
by the funds appropriated by the legislature.
Following further comments, the president called on Chancellor Jones, who
introduced Professor Charles Johnston, CESF committee member at UM-Flint.
CESF Report, UM-Flint
Professor Johnston noted that he was substituting for the CESF chair, Professor Kenneth West, who could not be present.
Professor Johnston's report focused on four areas of concern for faculty at
UM-Flint: 1) the average salary of three tenure track ranks at UM-Flint compared to three other sets of institutions; 2) the distribution of faculty ranks, especially the percentages of nontenure track positions; 3) the use of part-time (adjunct) faculty; 4) a comparison of average faculty salaries among the several
schools and colleges at UM-Flint.
CESF figures show that salaries at UM-Flint are average compared with


-284 -



May Meeting, 1992


peers; the goal is to be at the 80th percentile. They also show that UM-Flint has
a higher percentage of nontenure track full-time and adjunct (part-time) faculty
than its peer institutions, and that CESF believes this to be a very serious problem that must be addressed by the administration.
Regent McFee pointed out that the use of adjunct faculty can be viewed in a
positive light, in that part-time faculty allow the tniversity to make use of community members with specific areas of expertise and thereby enhance the course
opportunities available to students. Chancellor Jones observed that some of the
reliance on part- time faculty is a result of the significant enrollment growth that
occurred during the 1980s. He also said that part-time faculty are very valuable
in the Schools of Management and Health Sciences, although they are a concern
in the College of Arts and Sciences. He noted that some of the lack of tenure opportunities can be attributed to demographic factors, whereby large numbers of
faculty have been reaching retirement age over the past few years.
Following further discussion, the president turned to the regular business
agenda.

Sale of $56,000,000 Adjustable Rate Demand Hospital Revenue Refunding
Bonds, Series 1992A
Vice President Womack informed the Regents that the Adjustable Rate Demand Hospital Revenue Refunding Bonds, Series 1992A, were sold on May 13,
1992, and were remarketed at an initial rate of 32 percent. The bond issuance
costs will be recovered in one year, yielding a savings of about $184,000 per year
thereafter.
Vice President Womack read the following opinion from Moody's Municipal
Credit Report of May 12, 1992 into the record:
Strong regional draw provided by the breadth and quality of services has
resulted in steady improving utilization. The presence of the University
and its well respected Medical School further enhances the long-term
credit strength by providing a constant flow of a well qualified medical
staff. These factors are supported by excellent financial performance
which is enhanced by an outstanding liquidity position and a
state-of-the- art facility. The VMIG 1 rating reflects the University of
Michigan Hospitals' own short-term credit quality. Factors contributing
to this high quality include a sizable cash position and the liquidity of
the investment portfolio, as well as strong internal investment
management.
Financing of Major Capital Projects
Vice President Womack noted that the Regents had been apprised of several
major capital projects that were of critical importance to the University. State
capital outlay funding had been approved for the first two of these projects, but
there is little likelihood of any funds being appropriated in the near future. Vice
President Womack said that he had concluded that the combination of both low
interest rates and a competitive construction bidding climate provide an
opportunity for the University to proceed with these critically needed projects,
which have a combined total cost of $62.5 million. He stated that all or part of
the costs of the projects would be financed by the issuance of tax exempt bonds,
most likely but not necessarily, at fixed rate terms secured by a pledge of student
fees, and amortized over a period of up to 30 years.
The projects, as described in the Regents communication, include renovation
of the East Engineering Building to provide consolidated quarters for the
Departments of Mathematics and Psychology ($27.5 million); an addition to
Randall Laboratory for the Physics Department ($21.4 million); an addition to
the Undergraduate Library ($6.85 million); and capital support for additional
administrative office space ($6.5 million).


-286 -



May Meeting, 992


Following Vice President Womack's description of the projects, Regent
Power moved that the Regents approve the University's financing all the projects
as described, approve development of plans for the additions to the Undergraduate Library, authorize completion of contract documents for the East Engineering renovation and the Randall Laboratory addition, authorize the provision of
resources for support of administrative offices, and authorize the appointment of
Albert Kahn and Associates as architect for the library. Regent Waters seconded
the motion.
Regent Baker observed that in the past, most major building and maintenance projects had been paid for by the state; obligating student fees for this type
of undertaking would be a long-term obligation, and would represent a major
turning point Tuition increases and facuty salaries would be on the agenda in
upcoming months, and Regent Baker calculated that the cost for the proposed
projects, at 33,000 students, would equal about $2,300. Regent Baker noted that
he had consistently objected to the use of student fees as pledges for any use
other than those directly related to students, and expressed concern about how
this would affect the cost of education over the life of the bonds.
President Duderstadt responded that with the exception of three major
projects in which the state had funded a portion of the costs, all other construction on campus over the past 20 years had been financed by University sources,
including student fees. This is the sixth year of a freeze on state capital outlay
funding, and funding will likely not be resumed in the near future. The University's own calculation is that the cost of the debt service for these projects will be
approximately $5 million per year, which equals about $130-$140 per student.
One hundred dollars of that amount was put in place with the $50 per term infrastructure fee that was instituted in 1991. The president stated his opinion that an
assessment for improvements in academic facilities should be a far higher priority
than paying for athletic facilities.
Regent Nielsen opined that state funding for capital facilities is unlikely to
happen in this century; thus decisions had to be made. He also questioned
Regent Baker's figures, noting that the facilities would be funded over 30 years
and used over a half century; they would therefore be used by possibly 500,000
students during that time. He also pointed out that construction costs would not
decline, and mentioned the negative effect there might be on retention and recruitment of faculty if the projects are not undertaken. Thus he concluded that
the Regents should go ahead with the projects.
Regent Power pointed out that the proposed action is prudent financially, as
interest rates and construction costs were favorable at the current time. Regent
Power said that the other issue had to do with debt service coverage, and asked
Vice President Womack to address that issue.
Vice President Womack explained that a pledge of student fees refers to
more than tuition; the only thing that cannot be pledged is the state appropriation. What one pledges and what is used to pay the debt service is not the same.
Fees are pledged because that is a continuing stream of income which the Regents have control over, and results in a better rating. But all unrestricted funds


-287 -



May Meeting, 199


are commingled and, with the exception of the state appropriation, all funds are
available to pay this debt.
Regent Power pointed out that the University's debt obligation as a function
of streams of income available to service the debt ranks relatively low among universities nationally. Mr. Herbert reported that the University's student fee coverage is 20 times the average debt service. Regent Power concluded that since the
state appeared to be unable to support the University's capital needs, it was a
question of whether the Regents ought to manage the Umversity so as to optimize it as a resource for students and for the state, and he concluded that they
should.
Regent McFee supported this observation, noting that she had considered
whether the Regents should "take the state off the hook" by proceeding with the
funding for capital projects using its own resources. But she recognized that the
state was not going to be in a position to obtain the resources in time to preserve
these assets, so that it was important to protect the institution in the best possible
way it has available to it.
Regent Smith asked how the cost of the debt at $140 per student would
impact tuition, noting that she would like to have this information before voting
on the issue.
President Duderstadt responded that the $50 per term infrastructure fee,
which generates slightly more than $3.2 million per year, is already covered. The
remainder will have to be covered by the fees already in place, and would have to
be weighed against other needs of the institution, including salary programs and
benefits. The administration was not yet prepared to make a tuition recommendation, partly because it does not know yet what the budget situation will be next
year. He sensed that the additional funds necessary for the debt service (approximately $2 million) would probably come off the top of whatever tuition is recommended, rather than driving it up.
Regent Smith responded that this still did not answer her question; Vice
President Holbrook, the chief budget officer, stated that the president's comments were accurate, also noting that indirect cost rates, state appropriation, and
enrollment figures for next year would all impact the tuition recommendations.
President Duderstadt pointed out that this debt service would not be a major
factor in determining the tuition recommendation, as most of the revenue stream
for it is already in place.
Regent Smith observed that with so many uncertainties, she felt it would be
more prudent to wait on this issue, and that she would abstain from voting until
she had more information about what the tuition recommendations would be.
Regent Baker asked why the $62.5 million for capital construction could not
be included in the upcoming Capital Campaign. President Duderstadt responded
that historically, campaigns have had considerable difficulty raising money for facilities, as opposed to people. He also pointed out that there is considerable risk
in embarking on a major campaign, as illustrated by the difficulty the University


-288 -



May Meeting, 1992


experienced in raising funds for the Chemical Sciences Building in an earlier
campaign, in which not enough funds were raised. For the upcoming campaign,
the number of facilities for which funding is being sought has been minimized,
and even those will be very problematic until sufficient major gifts have been
secured to allow proceeding.
Regent Brown pointed out that money received for endowment from the
Capital Campaign will produce income that will help offset some other general
fund requirements. In response to a question from Regent Baker, it was
explained that even though student fees are pledged for the debt service, what is
actually used are unrestricted funds from all sources. There reswould not be an
incremental $130-$140 debt service fee included as part of the tuition assessment;
this amount would be covered in the whole magnitude of the General Fund
budget The $5 million annual debt service would be one of the budget items
included in the General Fund budget.
Following further discussion, Regent Smith noted that she was still unclear
about how tuition would be affected by this. Regent Brown observed that these
facilities have been needed for a long time, the University was now in a position
financially to assume these costs, and students, faculty, and citizens of Michigan
need them.
The vote was then taken on Regent Power's motion to approve funding for
all projects as described in the Regents communication (see above), and it
carried, with Regents Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Varner, and Waters in
favor, Regent Baker opposed, and Regent Smith abstaining.
Venture Capital Investment
Vice President Womack presented a recommendation for commitment of $1
million of the University Endowment to Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers VI,
LP. Following some discussion, Regent Nielsen moved that $1 million of the
University Endowment Fund be committed to Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers
VI, L.P. Regent Brown seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
The meeting then recessed, at 3:00 P.M., to meet in executive session.

Olympia & York Investment
Regent Smith observed that Olympia & York had filed for bankruptcy. She


-289 -



May Meeting, 1992


offered a resolution that Vice President Womack take whatever steps he deems
necessary to protect the interests of the University. Regent Baker seconded the
motion.
Vice President Womack noted that the three properties securing the University's O&Y investment were not involved in the bankruptcy proceedindgs, which at
ths point involve the company's corporate interests, and not their US real estate
interests Because the properties collateralizing the notes generate income
greater than the amount required to service the debt, it would be in O&Y's best
interest to continue to hold those properties. He reiterated that his staff is
maintaining a constant vigil over the situation.
Regent Baker stated that he has every confidence in Vice President Womack
and hisstaff, and hi  that this resolution gives them full authority to do what is
necessary without first seeking approval from the Regents.
Following some further discussion, the vote was taken, and the resolution
was approved unanimously.

Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs. The Regents approved a change in the title
of Donna L McKinley, from dean of student affairs to vice chancellor of student affairs at UM-Dearborn, effective May 18, 1992.
David M. French Professor. The Regents approved the appointment of Eugene
H. Studier as the David M. French Professor at the University of Michigan-Flint, for a
period of two years, effective July 1, 1992.
Recommended promotions to ranks of professor, associate professor, and assistant
professor. Provost Whitaker described the promotion and tenure review process,
noting that it is very extensive and involves both internal and external review. He
commented that an outstanding group of people was being recommended for promotion.
In response to a question from Regent Power, Provost Whitaker observed that the
rate of review of the eligible pool for women and minorities was lower than the rate
for all of the candidates. However, this is because many of the women and minorities
in the review pool were hired within the past three to four years, so they are not really
at the review point. He expressed confidence that the numbers of women and minonties eligible and ready for review will improve in upcoming years.
Provost Whitaker also responded to questions about the retention rate for women
and minorities and the implications of an increasing number of senior faculty retirements.
Following some discussion, Chancellors Wilson and Jones presented faculty promotions from their respective campuses. Then, there being no further questions,
Regent Varner moved, Regent Nielsen seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved, the recommended promotions to ranks of professor, associate professor, and
assistant professor for all three campuses.
