Retirement Memoirs
On a motion by Regent Power, seconded by Regent Nielsen, the Regents
voted unanimously to adopt the following retirement memoirs:
Leslie R Bassett, Albert A. Stanley Distinguished University Professor of
Music (Composition), will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1992.
What could be said were the skeleton to retire from the body? Composition
is the backbone of the art of music; and Leslie Bassett, true composer, himself
possessed of ample backbone and impeccable character, for 40 years has given
critical skeletal support to artistry in the School of Music and far beyond.
Professor Bassett was born in Hanford, California, in 1923. During World
War II, he served as a musician with the 13th Armored Division Band in France
and Germany. He received his BA degree in 1947 from California State University at Fresno, and he completed his M.Mus. and Ph.D. degrees, in 1949 and
1956, respectively, at the University of Michigan, where his principal mentor was
Ross Lee Finney; As recipient of a Fulbright grant, he continued his studies with
Arthur Honegger and Nadia Boulanger in Paris, and subsequently worked with
Roberto Gerhard and Mario Davidovsky. He joined the University of Michigan
faculty in 1952 as an instructor of music (composition); he was promoted to assistant professor in 1956, associate professor in 1960, and professor in 1965.


-304 -



May Meeting, 1992


Having experienced many performances of his works, and having received
numerous awards, prizes, and commissions, Professor Bassett has been much
honored. His hundred-plus compositions are internationally known, having been
performed or recorded by such stellar ensembles as the RAI Symphony Orchestra of Rome, the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Radio Zurich Orchestra, the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, and the Juilliard Quartet. He received the Pulitzer
Prize in 1966, and has also been awarded the prestigious Prix de Rome,
Koussevitsky and Guggenheim fellowships, National Endowment for the Arts
commissions, and membership in the American Academy and Institute of Arts
and Letters. At the University of Michigan, Professor Bassett's honors include
his appointments as the Albert A. Stanley Distinguished University Professor
(since 1977) and the Hemy Russel Lecturer (1984).
The Regents now salute this distinguished musician by naming Leslie R.
Bassett the Albert A. Stanley Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Music.
Joachim Bruhn, professor of German and humanities at the University of
Michigan-Dearborn, retired from active faculty status on April 30, 1992.
A native of Germany, Professor Bruhn received his doctorate from the University of Kiel, Germany, in 1953, and also studied at the University of Zurich,
Oxford University, and at Brown University. Before coming to the University of
Michigan-Dearborn in 1974, he taught at the University of Michigan-Ann Arbor,
Virginia Polytechnic Institute, and Richmond College of CUNY.
Professor Bruhn served as dean of the College of Arts, Sciences, and Letters
at UM-Dearborn from 1974-79 and as director of the Honors Program from
1979-83. He was also instrumental in the creation of the highly successful International Studies Program, serving as director from 1981-84.
As professor of German, Professor Bruhn taught a wide range of courses in
literature and culture. A dynamic and enthusiastic teacher, he had great success
in attracting and keeping students in the German program. For many years, he
was very active in teaching East German literature, at a time when the subject
was often neglected. He maintained active contact with area high schools and
visited classes to inform students and teachers about the foreign language programs at UM-Dearborn. His yearly travels to East and West Germany kept his
teaching informed by direct and up-to-date experience of current events and
trends in the two Germanies; many UM-Dearbomrn students traveled to Germany
to participate in the work and study programs he organized.
Professor Bruhn was also very concerned with developing students' cultural
lives, and regularly organized groups of students and their families to attend Detroit Symphony Orchestra concerts. He made these cultural opportunities a hallmark of the Honors Program during his directorship.
The Regents now salute this veteran teacher and administrator for his service
to the University by naming Joachim Bruhn Professor Emeritus of German and
Humanities.
C. Merle Crawford, professor of marketing in the School of Business Administration, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1992.
Professor Crawford received his B.S. degree in 1948, his M.S. degree in 1949,
and his Ph.D. degree in 1953, all from the University of Illinois. He was an assistant professor at the University of Florida from 1953-55, then worked as a marketing research administrator at Mead Johnson & Company, attaining the position of product management director. He joined the University of Michigan


-305 -



May Meetin    1992


faculty as associate professor of marketing in 1965 and was promoted to
professor in 1967.
Professor Crawford's corporate experience was invaluable in his academic
career, where he concentrated on course development and research in the social
responsibilities of business, new product development strategies, and managing
new product concept generation processes in organizations. As one of the early
members of the marketing faculty, Professor Crawford has been instrumental in
curricular development and in retaining and mentoring promising junior faculty
members to make this one of the pre-eminent marketing departments in the
country. As an example of his strong reputation, he was named marketing educator of the year i 1974.
As an excellent citizen of the school, a valued teacher and researcher, and a
leader in the development and growth of the marketing department, Professor
Crawford will be missed by the faculty and staff of the School of Business Administration, who wish him well in his retirement
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming C. Merle Crawford
Professor Emeritus of Marketing.
William H. Cup, professor of business administration at the University of
Michigan-Dearborn, retired from active faculty status on April 30, 1992.
Professor Culp received his B.S. degree from the University of North Carolina (Chapel Hill) in 1945 and his M.BA and Ph.D. degrees from the University
of Michigan in 1952 and 1961, respectively. He worked as a staff accountant for
Arthur Andersen & Company and taught at Davidson College, the University of
Iowa, and the University of Cincinnati before coming to the University of
Michigan-Dearborn as a visiting associate professor in 1965. Professor Culp was
appointed associate professor of business administration in the School of Management in 1966 and was promoted to professor in 1970. His administrative
duties included several years as chair of the accounting discipline and as a
member of the School of Management's executive committee. He also served on,
and chaired, the Business Operations Advisory Committee, the Academic Affairs
Advisory Committee, and many other unit and campus committees.
Professor Culp's career has been characterized by a diversity of interests in
the teaching and practice of accounting, and in the development of accounting
standards. His teaching has included all levels offered in the school, from principles to graduate courses. He introduced not-for-profit accounting to the curriculum nine years ago and taught it until his retirement. Students found his courses
to be both challenging and rewarding, as letters from graduates testify. Professor
Culp was also active in the accounting profession through participation in numerous professional organizations, including the American Accounting Association,
the Institute of Management Accountants, and the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. His interest in the continuing development of accounting standards found outlet in such activities as editing a column for The Michigan
CPA, presenting continuing education seminars, and submitting critiques of proposed accounting standards. In recognition of his career achievements, Professor
Culp was named the Ernst & Whinney Professor of Management Accounting for
1985-89, the first named professorship in the history of the School of Management.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming
William H. Culp Professor Emeritus of Business Administration.


-306 -



May Meeting, 1992


James F. Filgas, professor of business administration, will retire from active
faculty status on May 31, 1992.
Professor Filgas received his A.B. degree from the University of Michigan in
1956 and his M.BA. and D.BA. degrees from Indiana University in 1962 and
1966, respectively. He taught at Indiana University from 1963-64 and then went
to Northwestern University, where he was an instructor and then assistant professor of business administration, assistant dean, and director of admissions from
1964-69. Professor Filgas joined the University of Michigan School of Business
Administration faculty in 1969 as associate professor and assistant to the dean.
He was appointed director of financial aid in 1971 and served as director of student services from 1974-81. He was promoted to professor of business administration in 1977. Professor Filgas served as the Jesse Jones visiting professor of
management at the University of Notre Dame in 1978.
Professor Filgas served the school with dedication and distinction in the area
of student services. His performance was outstanding, and he was cited for his
skill in relationships both with students and with faculty. His administrative responsibilities included academic discipline for both undergraduate and graduate
students, financial aid, registration, and course selection and counseling. He also
taught in the evening MBA program as time allowed, and returned to full-time
teaching in 1981. Professor Filgas will be remembered fondly as a dedicated citizen of the business school.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming James F. Filgas Professor Emeritus of Business Administration.
Charles F. Fraker, professor of romance languages and literatures, will retire
from active faculty status on May 31, 1992.
Professor Fraker received his BA  degree from the University of Massachusetts in 1945 and his B.S. degree from Yale University in 1946. He completed his
MA degree at Middlebury Spanish School in 1953 and his Ph.D. degree in Spanish at Harvard University in 1963. Professor Fraker taught at the University of
Massachusetts, Harvard University, and Wesleyan University before coming to
the University of Michigan as an assistant professor in 1965. He was promoted to
associate professor in 1968 and professor m 1977, and served in the Department
of Romance Languages and Literatures as a teacher and scholar in the field of
Spanish medieval literature.
Professor Fraker served on various departmental and University committees,
including the Fulbright Selection Committee, the Rackham Fellowship Selection
Committee, and numerous committees within the Spanish teaching and research
group. Professor Fraker was also a devoted mentor of undergraduate and graduate students, having chaired fourteen doctoral committees for students working in
Spanish and been a member of numerous other doctoral and master's degree
committees as well. He also served as a dissertation committee member for tour
doctoral students within the School of Music.
Among Professor Fraker's publications are Studies on the 'Cancionero de
Baena' (1966); Celestina, Genre and Rhetoric (1990); and The Narrative Style of the
"Libro deAlexandre, " as well as 25 articles on various aspects of medieval Spanish
literature. He will be remembered by large numbers of students as an enthusiastic and committed teacher who took enormous pleasure in introducing them to
the intricacies of medieval Spanish literature.
The Regents now salute this distinguished teacher and scholar for his de

-307 -



May Meeting, 1992


voted service by naming Charles F. Fraker Professor Emeritus of Romance Languages and Literatures.
Robert N. Grosse, professor of population planning and international health
and professor of health planning in the School of Public Health and professor of
urban, technological, and environmental planning in the College of Architecture
and Urban Planning, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1992.
Professor Grosse received his A.Bo degree from Columbia College in 1944,
and his MA and Ph.D. degrees from Harvard University in 1946 and 1948, respectively. He worked with the Harvard Research Project on the Structure of the
American Economy from 1949-51 and the Office of Statistical Standards of the
U.S. Bureau of the Budget from 1951-53, where he developed methods of determining capital requirements for the expansion and replacement of industrial capacity. At the Rand Corporation, where he worked from 1953-63, Professor
Grosse participated in the development and application of the methods of system
cost analysis, and headed the project which designed the program budgeting
system of the Department of Defense. From 1963-66, he headed the economics
and costing department of the Research Analysis Corporation, and from 1966-68,
at the U.S. Department of Health, Education, and Welfare, he pioneered the development of methods for analyzing the relationships between expenditures and
outcomes of social programs for use in governmental decision-making.
After joining the faculty at the University of Michigan School of Public
Health as professor of health planning in 1968, Professor Grosse designed and directed the program in health planning. In 1974, he initiated the program in
health and economic development, which he directed until 1985. Professor
Grosse also served as chair of the Department of Health Planning and Administration from 1980-82. In 1985, he was appointed professor in the new Department of Population Planning and International Health and directed, until his
retirement in 1992, its international health degree program at both the master's
and the doctoral levels. In 1990, he was appointed professor of urban, technological, and environmental planning in the College of Architecture and Urban Planning.
A health planning model he developed for application in the third world has
been used by a number of countries to help make decisions about the allocation
of public funds to the health sector. His research on identifying the determinants
of health status in developing countries led to studies of the effects of water
supply and sanitation investments and the relationship of literacy and education
to health status.
The Regents now salute this distinguished economist and health planning
expert for his dedicated service by naming Robert N. Grosse Professor Emeritus'
of Population Planning and International Health, Professor Emeritus of Health
Planning, and Professor Emeritus of Urban, Technological, and Environmental
Planning.
Donald J. Patterson, professor of mechanical engineering in the Department
of Mechanical Engineering and Applied Mechanics, retired from active faculty
status on December 31, 1991, after a long career as an outstanding researcher
and educator in the field of automotive engineering.
Professor Patterson received his B.S.M.E. degree from the University of
Michigan in 1957, his S.M. degree from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in


-308 -



May Meeting, 1992


1958, and his Ph.D. degree from the University of Michigan in 1962. He worked
at General Motors Corporation as a senior project engineer until 1967, and then
spent a year at Ford Motor Company as a supervisor m the Engine and Foundry
Division. In 1964 and 1965, concurrent with his employment at General Motors,
Professor Patterson lectured at the University of Michigan. He joined the faculty
as associate professor in the Department of Mechanical Engineering in 1968. He
received tenure in 1970 and was promoted to professor in 1982.
Throughout his career, Professor Patterson has been one of the department's
most active researchers in engine-related topics. He has carried out
highly-regarded studies in combustion, chemical kinetics, fuels, engine performance, and modeling Specific projects include "engine friction studies, "automotive gasolines for light aircraft," "fuel economy devices," "particulate formation
in diesel combustion," and "fuel economy of engines under cold and warming-up
operations." One of his recent research efforts is a study of cam/lifter forces and
friction for the U.S. Department of Transportation. Professor Patterson has written numerous technical papers, journal articles, and presentations, and
co-authored the book, Emission Control in Internal Combustion Engines, published in 1972.
Professor Patterson has maintained his strong links to industry through his
consulting activities with private firms, including Ford Motor Company, EIC Corporation, Exxon Corporation, and Boeing Corporation. He has also provided ongoing consultation to such government agencies as the Environmental Protection
Agency, the Department of Commerce, and NASA. Within the College of Engineering, Professor Patterson has served as chair of the Automotive Program
Committee, member of the Program Council and the Graduate Studies Committee, and as advisor for environmental engineering students. He has also been
active in the Society of Automotive Engineers.
The Regents now salute this distinguished researcher and educator by
naming Donald J. Patterson Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering.
Harue Wada, research scientist in the Department of Materials, Science, and
Engineering, retired from active status on April 30, 1992, after an outstanding
thirty-year career as a metallurgist.
A native of Japan, Dr. Wada received her B.S. degree (chemistry), M.S.
degree (chemistry/metallurgy), and Ph.D. degree (physical chemistry) from
Hokkaido University in 1956, 1958, and 1963, respectively. Before joining the
University of Michigan, Dr. Wada held research positions with the Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm, Tohoku University in Sendai, the National Research Institute for Metals in Tokyo, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Dr. Wada joined the University of Michigan in 1970 as a research associate.
In 1978, she was appointed assistant research scientist; she was promoted to associate research scientist in 1982 and to research scientist in 1989.
Throughout her career, Dr. Wada has been an outstanding contributor in the
area of the chemistry and thermodynamics of molten metal systems, especially in
the study of interstitials in iron and its alloys. In recent years, she has made substantial advances in the synthesis of ceramic compounds and ceramic whiskers.
Dr. Wada has published over 60 papers during her career.
Dr. Wada is a member of the American Ceramic Society, the Materials Research Society, and the Iron and Steel Institute of Japan, as well as several other


-309 -



May Meeting, 1992


societies. She has been involved ith the enAmerican Association for the Advancement of Science and has contributed her time to the Faculty Women's Caucus,
Summerscience, and the Women in Science program. She is also a member of
Sigma Xi.
The Regents now salute this distinguished research scientist for her dedicated service by naming Harue Wada Research Scientist Emeritus.
David L Wolfe, associate professor of Spanish, will retire from active faculty
status on May 31, 1992.
Professor Wolfe received his B.A., M., and Ph.D. degrees in linguistics
from the University of Michigan in 1955, 1956, and 1966, respectively. His doc
toral dissertation involved a generative-transformational analysis of Spanish verb
forms.
Professor Wolfe joined the University of Michigan faculty as an instructor of
Spanish in 1960, having served as a teaching fellow since 1955. He was appointed
lecturer in 1962, and was promoted to assistant professor in 1967 and associate
professor in 1970. During his many years of active service at Michigan, Professor
Wolfe was associated with the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures as a teacher and scholar in the field of romance linguistics and also as director of the Spanish language program.
During his years of teaching, Professor Wolfe was a senior Fulbright lecturer
in liguistics at the University of Seville and a visiting lecturer at the Menendes y
Pelayo Institute in Spain.
Professor Wolfe's research centered in the area of Spanish language pedagogy. During his career, he produced five major textbooks for the teaching of the
Spanish language which exercised a substantial influence within the United
States. He directed four doctoral dissertations in the area of Hispanic linguistics
and served as a dissertation committee member for eighteen Ph.D. students.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming David
L. Wolfe Associate Professor Emeritus of Spanish.
Memorial Statements
No deaths were reported to the Regents this month.
Special Liquor Licenses
Vice President Womack explained that there are rare occasions on which the
University needs to apply to the Michigan Liquor Control Commission for a special liquor license. The commission has recently changed its application procedure for these one-event licenses, and the University's general counsel has devised a method that will comply with the state's requirements without having to
seek regental approval separately for all future applications.
Mr. John Ketelhut, of the General Counsel's office, responded to questions
from the Regents about the application procedure and the need for special liquor
licenses. Regent Baker stated that given the large numbers of under-age students
at the University, he would like there to be a reference in the resolution that the
licenses are for adult consumption only. Mr. Ketelhut responded that the law requires that licensees will serve neither minors nor people who are visibly intoxicated.


-310 -



May Meeting 1992


Dr. Zuidema, who chaired the task.force on alcohol and illegal substances,
stated that University policy is that the laws will be observed in every instance.
Regent Baker requested that the minutes refer to this policy.
Following further discussion, Regent Baker moved, subject to adherence to
University policy and Regental intent with respect to upholding state law, that
the Regents authorize the vice president and chief financial officer or the vice
president's written designee to apply to the Michigan Liquor Control Commission for the issuance of special liquor licenses to the University for the sale of
beer and wine or beer, wine, and spirits for consumption at specified University
events as they are considered necessary. Regent McFee seconded the motion,
and it was approved unanimously.
UM-Flint Frances Willson Thompson Library and Central Energy Plant/Utility
Distribution System
Chancellor Jones gave a historical overview of plans for the Flint campus library, noting that it had been conceived 14 years ago. Efforts at private
fundraising began in the early 1980s, and at the current time, over $18 million towards construction of the new library has been raised. Expansion of the central
energy plant is also necessary to service the new library, and the state has made it
clear that power plants will no longer be considered for state funding. Construction financing must be secured through student fees; however, this project is such
a critical need on the Flint campus that Chancellor Jones believes most students
would endorse this type of financing.
Vice President Womack described all of the aspects of the proposal, noting
that the exact amount of financing is as yet undetermined.
Regent Nielsen moved the approval of the UM-Flint Frances Willson
Thompson Library and central energy plant/utility distribution system, as described in the Regents communication. He observed that this project is long
overdue and desperately needed, and that the facility will serve the Flint
community as well as the campus.
Regent Baker seconded the motion, and noted the remarkable progress that
has been made on the Flint campus in the 15 years that it has been in existence.
Regent Power expressed his support for the project, and pointed out that the
field of library science is undergoing a tremendous revolution. He requested that
the architects be required to consult extensively with specialists in this field as
they design the project, noting the design should anticipate changes in this rapidly
evolving field. He asked that when the design is brought back to the Regents, a
specific portion of that report address how the design will accommodate the
changes occurring in the field of library science.
Vice President Womack clarified that the maximum total indebtedness for
the project during the time that pledges are maturing would be $7 million, including $3.5 million for the central energy plant.


-311 -



May Meeting, 1992


There being no further discussion, the vote was taken, and the Regents unanimously approved the following: the revised project budget for the library; soliciting bids and awarding a construction contract to the successful bidder, providing
the contract value is within the approved budget; expansion of the central energy
plant utility distribution system and authoriztion of the appointment of Harley
Ellington Pierce Yee Associates, Inc. as the architects-engineers; and financing a
portion of both projects' construction cash flow through the issuance of tax
exempt debt.

University of Michigan Hospitals Certificate of Need for Ambulatory Surgery
Center
Vice Provost Zuidema explained that growth in the demand for ambulatory
surgery services has exceeded the capacity of the operating rooms at University
of Michigan Hospitals, which were built with a primary focus on inpatients. The
combined growth of inpatient and outpatient surgery has also increased the demands on the existing surgical facilities.
The University of Michigan Hospitals Executive Board is proposing to relieve the over-utilized adult operating room suite by building a six-operatingroom, two-procedure-room ambulatory surgery center off-site at a location m
close proximity to the Medical Campus.
On a motion by Regent Nielsen, seconded by Regent Smith, the Regents
unanimously approved submission of a Certificate of Need to the Michigan


-312 -



May Meeting, 1992


Department of Public Health to build a freestanding off-site ambulatory surgery
center.

Medical Center North Entrance Parking Structure
Vice President Womack called on Mr. Douglas Hanna, assistant director of
capital programs to give a presentation on the design of the Medical Center
North Entrance Parking Structure.
Mr. Hanna announced that the Certificate of Need applications for both the
Cancer and Geriatrics Center and the North Entrance Parking Structure had recently been approved. He displayed site maps and drawings of the interior of the
six-floor structure, along with renderings of the Cancer and Geriatrics Center,
parking structure and parking structure office building on the site, and responded
to questions from the Regents about various features of the design. He also displayed a model of the entire complex, which illustrates the transition from the
parking structure to the Cancer and Geriatrics facility and how it fits in with the
surrounding buildings.
Regent Power observed that the design does not include a place for cars to
turn around in if they miss the entrance to the parking structure, and requested
that this issue be addressed before the plans are finalized.
Following additional discussion, Regent Power moved approval of the design
of the North Entrance Parking Structure as presented. Regent Nielsen seconded
the motion, and it was adopted unanimously.

Reassignment of Ownership Interest in Intellectual Property (Jess G. Thoene,
M.D.)
On a motion by Regent Smith, seconded by Regent Varer, all seven Regents present unanimously approved reassignment of the University's ownership
interest in the intellectual property "Method of Treating HIV Infection to its employee/inventor, Jess G. Thoene, M.D. Because Dr. Thoene is an employee of
the University who will also be a party to the assignment agreement, this arrangement falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following
information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the assignment agreement will be the University of
Michigan and Jess G. Thoene, M.D.
2.  The terms and pecuniary interests were previously disclosed to and
approved by the Regents on July 16, 1987, and are hereby
incorporated by reference in this Regental action.

Statement from Regent Baker about Alumni Association and Regental Candidates
Regent Baker announced that he wanted to put a motion on the table. He
explained that it involves Regent Brown, and as he had not yet had a chance to
discuss it with him and he hadn't known he was not going to be here today, he
would not seek action on the motion.


-314 -



May Meeting, 1992


"One of Michigan's traditions is that the University and its Alumni Association by and large do not involve themselves in the elections of members of the
Board of Regents. The proper method of electing regents is clearly stated in the
Constitution of the State of Michigan, wherein nomination of such candidates is
left to the respective political party. While it saddens me to bring this matter forward to enter the public record, it may be necessary that a line be drawn clearly
delineating appropriate and inappropriate political involvement in regental elections by the University of Michigan Alumni Association. It seems that the Regents can be helpful in providing this insight.
It has been observed that some regents emeriti, all of whom are directors of
the Alumni Association, have established themselves as a committee to recommend candidates for the office of regent for the Republican Party. The committee has recruited two candidates, one male and one female, to run against two
Republican office holders, Regent Veronica Smith and Regent Neal Nielsen, in
1992. Further, these candidates have been interviewed by Mr. Forman, the president of the Alumni Association. In addition, at least one of these candidates has
been presented to officials of Governor Engler's administration as candidates satisfactory to the committee.
It is unclear what the actual involvement of the Alumni Association is in this
matter, but on the surface it appears an effort to unseat both Regents Nielsen
and Smith, and it may have its roots in the Alumni Association. Therefore, I
move that Regent Paul Brown and Regent Deane Baker be named as a committee of two by the Regents and be authorized to review and discuss this matter
with Mr. Forman, directors of the Alumni Association, and others who might provide insight into the genesis of the committee and its purposes. The comrmttee
would then report its findings of the committee to the Board of Regents.
Regent Baker indicated he would leave the motion on the table for either
action or up and down at the next meeting.
The president then turned to the final action items.

medical campus. As the flagship institution of the state, the University of Michigan bears proportionately greater risk in exposure to the state's financial and political stresses than other educational institutions. By the board's actions, it was

-316 -



JUNE MEETING, 1992


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, June 11, 1992
The Regents met at 1:00 P.M. in the Regents' Room. Present were President
Duderstadt and Regents Baker, Brown, McFee, Nielsen, Power, Smith, Varner,
and Waters. Provost Whitaker, Vice President and Secretary Kennedy, and Vice
Presidents Cosovich, Hartford, Kelly, and Womack were also present, as was
Chancellor Jones. Chancellor Wilson was absent; Provost Simpson attended in
her place.
President Duderstadt called the meeting to order and called on Regent
Nielsen, who made the following motion:
Executive Session Motion
Pursuant to Section 8(e) of the Michigan Open Meetings Act, as amended by
1984 PA 202, I move that the Board of Regents meet in closed session in the Regents' Room on June 11, 1992, immediately following completion of the business
portion of the Regents' Meeting for the purpose of considering material exempt from
discussion or disclosure by the Michigan Freedom of Information Act. Such exempt
material consists of consulting with the Board's attorney regarding trial or settlement
strategy in connection with specific pending litigation
Regent Power seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Proposed 1992-93 UM Hospitals Operating Budget
President Duderstadt called on Vice President Womack, who introduced Mr.
John Forsyth, executive director of University of Michigan Hospitals, to present
the proposed 1992-93 UM Hospitals Operating Budget.
Mr. Forsyth observed that the major challenge in preparing the operating
budget was to balance academic needs and health care financial realities. He
outlined the Hospitals' historical responses to the changing environment since
1984, describing a number of significant actions the Hospitals had taken during
that time. He enumerated the challenges he had identified in the 1991-92
budget, and described what had been done to meet each one. The challenges
identified include continuing existing levels of academic support; continuing to
focus growth and maximize use of fixed resources; maintaining high quality staff
with a competitive compensation program; continuing to fund depreciation; improving the payer mix; improving competitive position; and breaking-even on operations in FY 1992. He noted that the cost per case in FY 1992 had been reduced significantly under the budgeted amount.
Mr. Forsyth pointed out that in 1992, the return on operations was 5.6 percent, with a 10.4 percent return on total margin; these are the best returns since
1985. From a historical perspective, prior to 1979, operating margins either did
not exist, or were negative.


-317 -



June Meeting, 1992


The 1992-93 budget is a "no-growth" budget. With regard to cost, the objec
tives are to continue cost effectiveness program reductions; enhance academic
support; increase admissions and clinic visits/decrease length of stay; self-fund a
competitive salary program; and maintain the emphasis on cost per case. Room
rates will be reduced (for routine room rates) or maintained (intensive care).
The results will be to maintain the high quality of staff and patient care, improve
the Hospitals' competitive position, and enhance its financial strength.
Mr. Forsyth displayed graphs and tables illustrating the exact figures that will
be used to achieve these goals. He concluded his presentation by re questing that
the Regents approve the proposed FY 1993 operating budget as described.
Following some discussion, Regent Baker moved approval of the proposed
1992-93 UM Hospitals operating budget, including a reduction in the private/semi- private room rate of 20.6 percent and no change in the intensive care
unit room rate. Regent Nielsen seconded the motion, and it was approved unani
mously.
Historical Overview of M-Care, Inc.
Vice President Womack introduced Mr. Peter Roberts, president of M-Care,
Inc., to present a historical overview of M-Care.
Mr. Roberts reported that M-Care had developed into a very successful
health maintenance organization, and gave a slide presentation describing the locations of its service area, providers, and membership. He noted that membership had grown from 5,107 in 1986, its first year of operation, to 40,905 in 1992,
and that the organization had achieved an operating break-even position in 1989
and a positive fund balance in 1991. The M-Care strategic plan for 1992-94 calls
for enhancement and strengthening of existing operating systems, diversification
into new market segments, and increased support for the teaching and health service research activities of the University.
President Duderstadt and Regent Power commented on the outstanding
leadership and impressive performance of M-Care.
Michigan Student Assembly Financial Matters
The president called on Vice President Hartford to present a report on financial matters related to Michigan Student Assembly.
Report on Current Fiscal Year. Vice President Hartford called on Mr.
Rodger Wolf, assistant to the vice president for student affairs, to present the
report. Mr. Wolf said that this report was one of the best that had been submitted in recent years. The audited financial statements indicate an excellent fund
balance, good financial position, improved controls, and a better management
letter than had been seen in the past.
In response to a question from Regent Nielsen about how this budget compares to other student government budgets around the country, Mr. Wolf stated
that a survey of peer institutions was planned for the coming year. Regent


-318 -



June Meeting, 1992


Nielsen indicated that the cash balance appeared to be larger than necessary; Mr.
Wolf reported that on August 31, 1992, the balance estimate will be about
$70,000. Mr. Wolf indicated that the auditors recommend that there be a cash
reserve for working capital purposes of $40,000-$50,000. The additional reserves
could be used for various program purposes.
Regent Nielsen observed that the fact that the cash balance is so high might
be an indication that the student fee assessment is too high. Further conversation
ensued on that topic, with Mr. Wolf and Vice President Hartford indicating that
any extra reserves could be used for additional programming, student organization funding, and funding for depredation on equipment.
Mr. Wolf reported that in response to a regental mandate, Michigan Student
Assembly had hired a full-time bookkeeper/financial analyst in January 1992. In
response to a question from Regent Nielsen, Mr. Wolf confirmed that a former
secretary had been indicted for misappropriating funds from Student Legal Services during the past calendar year.
Regent Baker expressed agreement with Regent Nielsen that if there were
surplus funds, the MSA fee assessment should be reduced. In response to a question from Regent Baker about the defalcation at Student Legal Services, Mr.
Wolf pointed out that at the time of last year's MSA presentation to the Regents,
nobody was aware that it had occurred. When it became known, law enforcement authorities were notified and immediate action was taken to apprehend the
former employee.
Regent Power observed that the management letter was an improvement
over the last one. He questioned the degree to which financial oversight and
scrutiny is welcomed within MSA, Student Legal Services, and the Ann Arbor
Tenants Union. Mr. Wolf responded that although the officers were cooperative,
he believed organizations did not welcome this type of oversight of their financial
affairs and would prefer that it did not occur. Mr. Carl Smith, director of University Audits, concurred that this has been the case historically.
Vice President Hartford observed that there is a lack of clarity about the role
of MSA within the University: Is it autonomous? Is it a student organization
which receives oversight, and who provides this oversight? Are the people who
work for student organizations University employees, and how are they supervised? Vice President Hartford believes that the lack of clarity about these issues
causes tension.
Regent Power noted that the Regents generally support the idea of student
government and have expressed this support by agreeing to assess a fee to support it. However, by enacting this fee, the Regents have an obligation to insure
that the financial propriety among the'student organizations they fund is absolutely perfect, which is why they have required the audits. To that end, he suggested that the vice president for student affairs might report to the Regents on a
regular basis the degree to which financial oversight is welcomed by the organizations.
Further discussion ensued about this idea. Regent Baker pointed out that


-319 -



June Meeting 1992


the Regents have historically supported an independent student government, and
they should not try to control student organizations. Regent Power responded
that the report he suggested might be considered as performing a function similar
to that of an audit committee in a corporation.
1992-93 Fee Assessments for Michigan Student Assembly and School/College
Governments
Following further discussion about oversight of MSA financial affairs, Vice
President Hartford introduced Ms. Ede Fox, president of MSA. Vice President
Hartford reviewed the administration's recommendation that the 1992-93 fee assessments be maintained at $627 per student per term for MSA and $1.00 per
student per term for school/college governments and that the $35 cent fee for
Michigan Collegiate Coalition be eliminated. This recommendation is based on
a student referendum in March 1992, in which students voted to cap the MSA fee
at its current level. She pointed out that MSA has prepared its own recommendation of $7.05 per student per term.
Ms. Fox introduced Mr. Roger DeRoo, student general counsel, and Mr.
Hunter VanValkenberg, vice president of MSA. Ms. Fox stated that she has
withdrawn herself from the MSA budget process because her father works for
Student Legal Services. She said she would also remove herself from the organization's discussion of the budget when it is considered for adoption by MSA representatives. She then turned the floor over to Mr. DeRoo.
Mr. DeRoo described the budget process undertaken by MSA, and noted
that organizations receiving allocations from MSA have their own budget oversight. He stated that all money raised by student fees will go into escrow, and will
not be appropriated until approved by a student referendum. He stated that
MSA had recently mandated an increase in its reserve fund from two percent of
its internal budget to five percent of its external budget (approximately $25,000).
Mr. DeRoo reported that MSA officers are requesting an increase of 6.9 percent (43 cents per student per term) over the current rate of $6.27. They are also
recommending that the 35 cents per student per term currently being allotted to
the Michigan Collegiate Coalition be transferred to MSA for appropriation to
MCC, rather than appear as a separate assessment designated for MCC. He then
reviewed the detailed combined budget proposal for Michigan Student Assembly,
Student Legal Services, and the Ann Arbor Tenants Union, and turned the floor
over to Mr. VanValkenberg.
Mr. VanValkenberg stated that he is the chair of the board of Student Legal
Services, and reviewed the proposed budget for SLS. He described SLS as a free,
pre- paid legal service for students. SLS is requesting a 6.67 percent increase,
almost entirely for salaries. He reported that the caseload last year was 3200 for
three attorneys, with 120-130 new cases coming in per month.
Mr. DeRoo then described the activities of the Ann Arbor Tenants Union,
noting that its budget had been cut by 48 percent last year. One of the positive
results of this budget cut had been that AATU had increased its reliance on external sources for funding. The budget calls for partial restoration of funding


-320 -



June Meeting, 1992


from MSA to hire one half-time person to enable full restoration of services and
a more aggressive fundraising effort. A long-term goal is that one-third of the
income of AATU will come from external sources.
Mr. DeRoo concluded his remarks by describing the activities of the Michigan Collegiate Coalition, noting that this organization works in conjunction with
the University's legislative efforts on common concerns, such as obtaining increased state appropriations and increased student financial aid from the federal
government. He reported that Michigan Collegiate Coalition enjoys universal
support among students and assembly members of all political persuasions. MSA
leadership is recommending direct funding of MCC by MSA, rather than through
a separate, mandatory assessment.
Mr. DeRoo summarized MSA's recommendation as amounting to $7.05 per
student per term, of which 43 cents would go toward improved services and programming and 35 cents would be a transfer of the current 35 cent MCC assessment to MSA.
In response to a question from Regent McFee, a discussion ensued about the
scope of services, charges, caseload, and policies of Student Legal Services.
Regent McFee requested information on the full scope of services provide by
Student Legal Services.
Regent McFee commented that the discussion about MSA fees and financial
matters reveals how the relationship between MSA and the administration is
changing, and needs to continue to develop and be explored. She supported Vice
President Hartford's assertion that a strong student government is a positive element in any university.
Mr. VanValkenberg reported that he fully supported MSA's hiring of an accountant, and welcomed the oversight of the vice president for student affairs in
preventing malfeasance or mistakes. He expressed the hope that next year's
management letter would be completely clean.
Regent Baker stated that funding for Student Legal Services is not analogous
to funding for University Health Service, as Mr. VanValkenberg had suggested
earlier. He reviewed the history of mandatory student fees for PIRGIM, an organization for which funding fell dramatically when the fee was made voluntary,
and stated his objection to mandatory fees and their use for political purposes.
Regent Baker stated his opinion that the Ann Arbor Tenants Union is a political
organization and that he objected to student fees being used to pay for it.
Following further discussion, the president called for a 10-minute recess.
The meeting resumed at 3:10 P.M.
1992-93 University Health Service Fee
President Duderstadt called on Vice President Hartford to present the
1992-93 University Health Service fee.
Vice President Hartford reported that the proposal is to increase the fee by


-321 -



June Meeting, 1992


6.21 percent, or $5.11 per student per term. This would raise the fee to $8736
per student per term, from its current amount of $82.25 per student per term.
In response to a question from Regent McFee, Dr. Caesar Briefer, director
of University Health Service, explained that students are not charged for any services received at the University  ealth Service, except for pharmacy, orthopedic
appliances, elective refraction, and certain immunizations. All primary care,
subspecialty care, laboratory and x-ray service is provided at no charge. Any service performed outside of the University Health Service is not covered.
Following further discussion, the Regents turned to the regular business
agenda, noting that the vote on student fee issues would not occur until after
public comments.

Administrative Reorganization at UM-Flint
Chancellor Jones reported that he was recommending a reorganization of the
units that report to the chancellor's office at UM-Flint. This will involve a merging of the external relations functions into a newly established Office of Institutional Advancement. This office will be headed by a person in a new position, vice
chancellor for institutional advancement.
The Office of Broadcasting will report to the provost and vice chancellor for
academic affairs, and the Office of Multicultural Initiatives will be established as a
cabinet-level executive office.
Chancellor Jones reported that these changes would streamline the functions
of the chancellor's office and would also result in a savings of $100,000.
On a motion by Regent Nielsen, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously approved the administrative reorganization at UM-Flint, as described in the Regents communication.

Retirement Memoirs
On a motion by Regent Smith, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
unanimously adopted the following retirement memoirs:
Morris Bornstein, professor of economics and research scientist, retired from
active faculty status on May 31, 1992, after a most productive career in teaching,
research, and public policy.
Born in Detroit, Professor Bornstein received his A.B., AM., and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1947, 1948, and 1952, respectively. He
worked as an economist for the U.S. government from 1951-58, except for a stint
in the military from 1953-55. Professor Bornstein joined the faculty of the
University of Michigan as an assistant professor in 1958. He was promoted to associate professor in 1962 and full professor in 1964, and received the additional
appointment of research scientist in 1977. Professor Bornstein served as director
of the Center for Russian and East European Studies from 1966-69. He had visiting appointments at Harvard University in 1962-63 and at Stanford in 1969-70.
Throughout his career, Professor Bornstein's specialty has been the field of
comparative economic systems, with special attention to the economy of the


-333 -



Jue Meeting, 1992


Soviet Union. A world-renowned expert on the Soviet system of central planning, he is known especially for his contributions to the understanding of the
Soviet price system. As head of the Comparative Systems Project at the University of Michigan, Professor Bornstein originated and obtained Ford Foundation
funding for a series of very influential conferences in the field of comparative systems.
Professor Bornstein has authored and edited numerous books, including a
very successful book of readings on the Soviet economy that went through four
editions. His most recent book, published in 1985, was a monograph on the
transfer of western technology to the Soviet Union. He is also the author of a
large number of academic articles. These range from a classic article on the
Soviet price system published in 1962 in the American Economic Review, through
numerous contributions in more specialized journals dealing with Soviet studies,
to his most recent work on problems of transition and reform in the Soviet
Union.
The Regents now salute this distinguished economist for his dedicated service by naming Morris Bornstein Professor Emeritus of Economics and Research
Scientist Emeritus.
Frances E. Bull, M.D., professor of internal medicine, will retire from active
faculty status on June 30, 1992. She has enjoyed a most productive career as a
respected teacher and leader in medical oncology.
An Ann Arbor native, Dr. Bull received her B.S. degree with distinction from
the University of Michigan in 1948, after which she entered the University of
Michigan Medical School where she earned her M.D. degree in 1952. She received house staff training at the University of Minnesota and at the Mayo Clinic
and then returned to the University of Michigan to complete her training in
oncology. She also earned her M.S. degree from the University of Minnesota in
1963.
Dr. Bull joined the faculty of the University of Michigan as an instructor in
internal medicine in 1957; she was promoted to assistant professor in 1964, associate professor in 1968, and professor in 1974. She served as head of the section
of medical oncology in the Department of Internal Medicine from 1971-78.
During this time, she was responsible for significant growth in the division and establishment of a training program.
Dr. Bull has played a major role in medical student curriculum design, and
her outstanding teaching abilities have been recognized by her winmng the
Senior Residents Teaching Award in 1971 and the Sophomore Medical Student
Teaching Award in 1987, 1988, 1989, 1990, and 1991. Dr. Bull has remained the
major contributor to the design of the oncology curriculum in medical teaching at
the University of Michigan. In addition to these accomplishments in teaching
and administration, Dr. Bull has made important contributions to the design of
clinical trials in medical oncology.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health educator for her dedicated
service by naming Frances E. Bull Professor Emeritus of Internal Medicine.
J. Robert Cairns, professor of mechanical engineering at the University of
Michigan-Dearborn, retired from active faculty status on April 30, 1992, after
many years of faithful and dedicated service.


-334 -



June Meeting, 1992


Professor Cairns received his B.M.E. degree from the University of Detroit
in 1954 and his M.S.E. (engineering mechanics) and Ph.D. (mechanical engineering) degrees from the University of Michigan in 1959 and 1963, respectively.
Before joining the Dearborn campus, Professor Cairns was an instructor in the
Department of Engineering Mechanics at the University of Detroit from 1954-57
and at the University of Michigan-Ann Arbor from 1957-63.
Professor Cairns joined the Dearborn campus in 1963 as an assistant professor of mechanical engineering; he was promoted to associate professor in 1965
and to professor of mechanical engineering in 1968. He served as chair of the
Division of Engineering from 1964-75 and dean of the School of Engineering
from 1975-80.
Having been involved in engineering education for more than 30 years,
throughout his career Professor Cairns has lectured nationally, served as a consultant to various corporations, and authored significant publications. He is also
a member of and extensively involved in, many professional engineering societies. Professor Cairns' University service includes membership on many committees over the years, including the School of Engineering Computer Committee,
Curriculum Coordinating Committee, Campus Facilities Planning Committee,
Chancellor's Task Force on Facilities, and the Scholarship Committee.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his dedicated service by
naming J. Robert Cairns Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering.
Ernest H. Y. Chu, professor of human genetics, will retire from active faculty
status on June 30, 1992.
Considered one of the founding fathers of the study of human chromosomes,
Professor Chu completed his undergraduate education in China, and then attended the University of California at Berkeley, where he earned his M.S. degree
in 1951 and his Ph.D. degree in 1954. He hefd positions at Yale University and
Oak Ridge National Laboratory prior to joining the University of Michigan as
professor of human genetics in 1972.
When the introduction of new techniques initiated the modern era in
cytogenetics in the mid-1950s, Professor Chu immediately became involved in delineating the contribution of chromosomal abnormalities to human defects and in
comparative studies of the cytogenetics of the primates. His interests then
evolved toward the field of somatic cell genetics, in which basic genetic problems
are studied by manipulating human cells under cell culture conditions. This approach yields insights into certain important genetic questions which often cannot
be obtained any other way. Professor Chu's early work involved studies of the effects of x-rays and ultraviolet radiation on chromosomes. Later, he focused on
studying the ability of various chemical agents and x-rays to induce apparent genetic changes (mutations) in human cells in culture. Such studies are proving to
be very important in the screening of chemicals for their potential mutagenic
effect on human populations. Characteristic of Professor Chu's career is his
continuing use of the very latest techniques, with ever increasing precision in defining exactly how chemicals and x-rays work in producing genetic damage. His
scientific achievements have been recognized in many ways, most recently, in
1991, by the receipt of the Environmental Mutagen Society Award for life-time
achievement in basic research.
From the time of his arrival, Professor Chu has contributed to the training of
graduate students in the Department of Human Genetics by co-teaching the
course in cytogenetics and somatic cell genetics; he was popular with pre- and


-335 -



June Meeting 1992


postdoctoral students and visiting scientists.
Throughout his career, Professor Chu has maintained a strong interest in furthering the cause of genetics in his native China, and his laboratory has hosted
many students from the two Chinas. For the past two years, he has served as the
acting head of the Department of Biology m the newly-organized Hong Kong
University of Science and Technology.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Ernest H. Y. Chu
Professor Emeritus of Human Genetics.
John C. Floyd, Jr., M.D., professor of internal medicine, will retire from
active faculty status on June 30, 1992, following a most productive career as a
teacher, researcher, and clinician.
A native of Louisiana, Dr. Floyd received his BA and M.D. degrees from
Louisiana State University in 1949 and 1954, respectively. He then undertook his
internship and residency training at the University of Michigan, following which
he servedas a junior clinical instructor, instructor in internal medicine, and assistant coordinator of the Clinical Radioisotope Unit from 1957-59. Dr. Floyd returned to Louisiana State University School of Medicine in 1959 as an instructor
of internal medicine, then came back to the University's Division of Endocrinology and Metabolism in 1960 to enter a fellowship program. Following his fellowship training, Dr. Floyd joined the faculty as an assistant professor of internal
medicine in 1961. He was promoted to associate professor in 1964 and professor
in 1970.
During his tenure, Dr. Floyd made major contributions to instructional, clinical research, and patient care programs in the Department of Internal Medicine.
He was instrumental in establishing the Michigan Diabetes Research and Training Center and served as director of the Diabetes Center Unit and Clinic from
1977-86, as well as associate director of the center. In 1986, Dr. Floyd also began
serving as an instructor in the Diabetes Epidemiology Training Program in the
Schootof Public Health. A brilliant teacher and outstanding clinician, he has devoted a good portion of his academic career to training medical students, residents, and fellows in clinical medicine.
Over the years, Dr. Floyd has been active in numerous scientific endeavors
and committees furthering the field of diabetes care and research on a national
level. He was especially influential in the American Diabetes Association, serving in various committee roles and as a member of the board of directors from
1974-80. He continues to play an important part in diabetes research as technical
advisor to the Grants Advisory Panel for Research and Development on Health
Care Cost Containment of the Michigan Health Care Education and Research
Foundation and as chair of the Diabetes Policy Advisory Council of the Michigan
Department of Public Health.
Dr. Floyd's exemplary contributions to clinical investigation include having
established himself as a national authority on the physiology of insulin secretion
in humans. He is also wholly responsible for establishing the first radioimmunoassay for a polypeptide hormone to be employed in the clinical laboratories at
the University of Michigan.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health educator for his dedicated
service by naming John C. Floyd, Jr., Professor Emeritus of Internal Medicine.
Bert G. Hornback, professor of English, will retire from active faculty status
on June 30, 1992, after a highly productive career as teacher and scholar.


-336 -



June Meeting 1992


A native of Kentucky, Professor Hornback received his AB., M.A., and
Ph.D. degrees from the University of Notre Dame in 1957, 1961, and 1964, respectively. He came to the University of Michigan as an instructor in 1964 and
was promoted to assistant professor in 1965, associate professor in 1970, and professor in 1975. Among his honors are a Distinguished Faculty Award, the Ruth
M. Sinclair Award for Honors Academic Counselling (twice), and the Amoco
Foundation Good Teaching Award.
Professor Hornback has published a number of books on Charles Dickens,
Thomas Hardy, and George Eliot, as well as numerous articles dealing with British authors and, more recently, with issues of education and leadership. Active in
literary arts and the theater, he has written, directed, or performed with the
Wolgomat Society, Lord Chamberlain's Players, and the Umversity of Michigan
Opera Professor Hornback has given more than 250 readings nationwide from
the workss of Charles Dickens, his chief enthusiasm and scholarly focus. He also
wrote    te, hosted, and acted in a tenpart series of 30Sminute programs on The
Dickens World" for the University of Michigan Television Center.
As counselor of undergraduate students, Professor Hornback has often gone
to extra lengths to ensure that honors students could enroll in courses that would
be most useful to them. Most of his upper-level classes are held at his own home,
where instruction in the world of Charles Dickens may be obtained through
examination of the walls and furniture. He has lon been concerned for the
ambience of the learning community as well as for the good of its individual
members.
Professor Homback's friendships with contemporary poets have brought such
writers as Seamus Heaney, Donald Hall, Galway Kinnell, and Wendell Berry to
read        in    again andag ain. Also extraordinary have been his annual
summer trips to Europe with a handful of undergraduates. These trips combine
reading for academic credit with the opportunity to visit monuments of the
Hellenic world, London, Stratford, and the world of Shakespeare, Dublin, and
the worlds of Yeats and Joyce.
Professor Hormback has been a significant member of the University community since his arrival, serving on committees, and stimulating the minds of undergraduates and colleagues alike. He has not forborne to speak publicly to issues
of University purpose and governance. In this, he models himself on the role of
the Greek citizen in its ideal form.
The Regents now honor this distinguished scholar, teacher, and educator by
naming Bert G. Hornback Professor Emeritus of English.
Wilbert J. McKeachie, professor of psychology in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts and research scientist in the Center for Research on Learning and Teaching, will retire from active faculty status on June 30, 1992.
Professor McKeachie received his B.A. degree from Michigan State Normal
College in 1942 and his M.A and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan
in 1946 and 1949, respectively. He joined the faculty of the Department of
Psychology as an instructor in 1948 and was promoted to assistant professor in
1950, associate professor in 1955, and professor in 1960. He has received honorary degrees from the University of Cincinnati, Denison University, Eastern Michigan University, Hope College, and Northwestern University.
Professor McKeachie is the author of more than 20 books and separates,
nearly 100 chapters, 70 research and scholarly articles, and nearly 100 other articles dealing with a wide variety of subjects related in one way or another to his


-337 -



June Meeting, 1992


primary interests: undergraduate education and college teaching. His marvelous
book Teaching Tips: A Guidebook for the Beginning College Teacher, which first
appeared in 1951, is now in its eighth edition and is still recognized as the preeminent guide for beginning college teachers.
Within the University, Professor McKeachie chaired the Department of Psychology from 1961-71 and served as director of the Center for Research on
Learning and Teaching (1975-83) and associate director of the National Center
for Research to Improve Postsecondary Teaching and Learning (1986-91). He
has also chaired the academic senate, presided over the University's chapter of
the AAUP, and served on or chaired major University committees and search
committees. His administrative contributions were recognized in 1990 when he
received the Distinguished Facult Governance Award.
Outside the University, Professor McKeachie served the American Psychological Association as president from 1975-76, as a member of the board of directors for nearly two decades, and as president of the divisions on the teaching of
psychology (1956-57), general psychology (1972-73), and educational psychotogy
(1975-76). He has also served as president of the Michigan Psychological Association, the American Psychologica Foundation, and the American Association for
Higher Education. In 1985, Professor McKeachie received the American Psychological Foundation's award for distinguished teaching of psychology, and in 1987,
he was honored with the American Psychological Association's award for distinguished career contributions to education and training in psychology.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Wilbert
J. McKeachie Professor Emeritus of Psychology and Research Scientist Emeritus.
Fred C. Munson, professor of health services management and policy in the
School of Public Health, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1992, after
a distinguished career as a scholar and teacher.
Professor Munson received his B.S. degree from the School of Industrial and
Labor Relations at Cornell University in 1952 and his Ph.D. degree in economics
from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1959. He joined the University of
Michigan faculty in 1959 as assistant professor of industrial relations in the
School of Business Administration and was promoted to associate professor in
1963. He joined the School of Public Health in 1969 as associate professor of
hospital administration and associate professor of population planning and was
promoted to full professor in 1971. Professor Munson's title changed to professor of health services management and policy in 1986.
Professor Munson's research interest has been in the study of organizations,
specifically health organizations. In recent years, his major research has concerned academic health centers and the problems of implementing change in organizations. Professor Munson has a long history of community service as an advisor to hospitals and health agencies in this country and as a planner and designer of appropriate health organization structures in developing nations.
During his tenure with the University of Michigan, Professor Munson has
been deeply involved in the teaching programs and has served on numerous dissertation committees. His colleagues have admired Professor Munson's great
ability to motivate his students.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Fred C. Munson Professor Emeritus of Health Services Management and Policy.

Guy G. Reiff, professor of movement science in the Division of Kinesiology,
retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1992, after 32 productive years of
teaching, administrationg,coa   and research..
Professor Reiff is widely re zed for s  ed  his contributions to youth fitness,
having served as an advisor to the President's Council on Fitness and Sports
through five presidents. In 1989, he was honored as one of the nation's ten
healthy Amencan fitness leaders and as a national master in sports/fitness by the
President's Council.
Following service in the U.S. Navy during World War I, where he received
four campaign ribbons for naval amphibious operations, Professor Reiff earned
his B.S. degree from the University of Southern California (1952); his M.A.
degree from Colorado State College of Education (1955) and his Ph.D. degree
from the University of Michigan (1964). During the 1950s, he played professional baseball, scouted for the Denver Bears, and coached high school atetics.
Professor Reiff joined the University of Michigan faculty as an instructor in
1960. He was promoted to associate supervisor of physical education for men
and assistant professor in 1965, associate professor of physical education in 1967,
and professor in 1971. He taught various physical education courses and administered several academic programs from 1965-76, and conducted five national
comparison studies of youth fitness. In 1983, Professor Reiff established Fitness
for Youth, a K-12 physical education program emphasizing exercise, nutrition,
and healthy life-style habits. He has written many articles and addressed hundreds of alumni, civic, and service groups on behalf of children's fitness.
The Regents now salute this distinguished physical educator for his contributions and achievements by naming Guy G. Reiff Professor Emeritus of Movement Science.
Johannes Tall, associate professor of music at the University of MichiganFlint, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1992, after a most productive
career as a teacher, musician, and department leader.
Borm in Estonia, Professor Tall studied at the State Conservatory of Music in
Tallinn, Estonia; Borgarskolan, in Stockholm, Sweden; and N. S. W. State Conservatory of Music, in Sydney, Australia. He received his MA. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Minnesota in 1961 and 1969, respectively. Professor
Tall came to UM-Flint in 1974 as associate professor of music without tenure.
He was granted tenure in 1976.
As one of the founding faculty members of the UM-Flint Department of
Music, Professor Tall helped design the music curriculum. He also founded the
University's Town and Gown Orchestra, served on many University committees,
and was chair of the department for six years. A composer and ethnomusicologist, he served as a speaker and panelist at a number of conferences concerned
with music of the Baltic states and conducted at the world-famous "folk songfest"
in his native city of Tallinn, Estonia. Professor Tall's compositions have been
performed in the United States, Australia, Europe, and Canada; one of his orchestral compositions will be performed by the Detroit Symphony Orchestra,
with Neeme Jarvi conducting, during the 1993 season.
The Regents now salute this distinguished musician for his dedicated service
by naming Johannes Tall Associate Professor Emeritus of Music.
Vera Terpstra, professor of international business in the School of Business
Administration, will retire from active faculty service on June 30, 1992.


-339 -



June Meeting, 1992


Professor Terpstra received his B.BA, M.BA, and Ph.D. degrees from the
University of Michigan in 1950, 1951, and 1965, respectively. Following completion of his Ph.D. degree, he was an assistant professor at the Wharton School at
the University of Pennsylvania for two years before joining the faculty at the University of Michigan School of Business Administration as an associate professor
in 1966. As only the second member of the growing international business faculty, Professor Terpstra brought a wealth of experience in the international area,
including training at the University of Brussels and nine years of educational
missionary service in the Congo. He was promoted to professor of international
business in 1971.
During his tenure at the School of Business Administration, Professor
Terpstra was influential in helping to build a strong international business discipline. He was recognized both nationally and internationally for his work in
American business and marketing, international trade, Chinese international
trade, and strategic alliances. Professor Terpstra has been a good citizen of the
school and a strong teacher. He has made significant contributions to the school
and to his profession, and the faculty and staff wish him a long and satisfying retirement.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Vern Terpstra Professor Emeritus of International Business.
George R Thompson, M.D, professor of internal medicine in the Medical
School and physician in the Health Service Clinic Services, will retire from active
faculty status on June 30, 1992, after a career at the University of Michigan that
has spanned parts of five decades.
Born in Ann Arbor in 1930, Dr. Thompson graduated from Ann Arbor's University High School and received both his B.S. (1950) and M.D. (1954) degrees
from the University of Michigan. After a year of internship at The Ohio State
University, he returned to the University of Michigan in 1955 as a resident in
internal medicine. He served in the U.S. Navy Medical Corps from 1958-60 and
subsequently completed his rheumatology fellowship at the University of Michigan's Rackham Arthritis Research Unit. Dr. Thompson joined the faculty as an
instructor in internal medicine in 1962. He was promoted to assistant professor
in 1965, associate professor in 1969, and professor in 1976.
From 1963-84, Dr. Thompson directed the rheumatology service at Wayne
County General Hospital. In this setting, he trained dozens of rheumatology fellows and hundreds of medical students and house officers. Dr. Thompson was
known as a dedicated and highly effective clinician and teacher. The author of
approximately 50 publications in the field of clinical rheumatology, he has also
been a member and officer of numerous medical and scientific societies, at both
the local and regional levels.
When the University of Michigan ended its teaching affiliation with Wayne
County General Hospital in 1984, Dr. Thompson was appointed acting director
of ambulatory care and staff rheumatologist at the Veterans Administration
Medical Center in Ann Arbor. He held these positions until 1987, at which time
he transferred to the University Health Service as a senior physician.
After his retirement from active faculty status, Dr. Thompson will continue
to be active as a senior clinician and teacher in rheumatology.
The Regents now salute this distinguished clinical scholar for his lengthy and
dedicated service by naming George R. Thompson Professor Emeritus of Internal Medicine.

Memorials
No deaths were reported to the Regents this month.
Authorization for Expenditures in 1992-93
Regent Brown moved, Regent McFee seconded, and the Regents unanimously approved the following: Until 1992-93 budgets are prepared and approved, 1) payments for non-salary expenditures in fiscal 1992-93 will be made at
a rate not to exceed the monthly budget levels for 1991-92; and 2) Salary expenditures in 1992-93 will be made on the basis of salary budgets in effect for
1991-92.
620 Oxford Road, Ann Arbor
On a motion by Regent Smith, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved acquisition of the property at 620 Oxford Road, Ann
Arbor, at a price of $340,000. Funds to acquire the property and make minimal
improvements and code renovations will be provided by a $500,000 gift designated for this purpose.
Flint Real Estate
On a motion by Regent Nielsen, seconded by Regent Smith, the Regents
voted unanimously to accept the property located at 1026 Kensington Avenue,
Flint, recognizing there will be expenses associated with its ownership including
utilities and maintenance. Upon receipt of the appraisal, the property will be offered for sale and is expected to be sold at a minimum of the appraised value less
marketing and closing costs. The proceeds from the sale will benefit the Frances
Willson Thompson Library.
University of Michigan Hospitals Mott Renewal Project
The Regents were informed that a contract has been awarded to the firm of
Walbridge, Aldinger Company of Detroit for construction of the University of
Michigan Hospitals Mott Renewal Project. The final proposed budget, as detailed in the Regents communication, will be $46,475,750.

1992-93 University Health Service Fee
On a motion by Regent Waters, seconded by Regent Brown, the Regents
