per student per term.
1992-93 Michigan Student Assembly and School/College Government Fee Assessments
Vice President Hartford enumerated the four proposals before the Regents:
1) $1.00 per student per term for school/college governments (unchanged from
previous year); 2) Eliminate the current $.35 mandatory fee for Michigan
Collegiate Coalition and instead recommend that MSA fund MCC with its own


-342 -



June Meeting, 1992


funds or by alternate methods; 3) Vice President Hartford's recommendation of
retaining the current MSA fee of $6.27; and 4) MSA's proposal to increase the
MSA fee to $7.05, which would include an increase of $.43 over the current fee
and $.35 to support the Michigan Collegiate Coalition.
School/College Government Fee. Regent Brown moved to maintain the
school/college government fee at $1.00 per student per term. Regent Smith seconded the motion, and it was adopted unanimously.
Michigan Collegiate Coalition. Regent Smith moved to eliminate the mandatory fee of $35 per student per term for Michigan Collegiate Coalition. Regent Varner seconded the motion.
In response to a question from Regent McFee, it was explained that the fee
for Michigan Collegiate Coalition was established four years ago, following a
student referendum requesting that this be done.
Regent Baker observed that he had reviewed the minutes from past meetings
about actions related to the Michigan Collegiate Coalition. In 1988, the Regents
had made strong arguments that MCC, in its lobbying activities, should not take
positions counter to the best interests of the University. He recalled that at the
time of the founding of Student Legal Services, it was made clear that they would
not be allowed to sue the University. Thus, the historical record indicates that
student organizations should not take a position opposed to that of the
University; since MCC has taken such positions, he was in support of Regent
Smith's motion.
Regent Brown stated that although it is difficult for him to go against the
results of a student referendum, he agreed with Regent Baker that the Regents'
original intent in approving funding for the MCC was that it not take positions
contrary to the Umnversity's interests. MCC's support of a proposed constitutional amendment to limit tuition was a fatal mistake, so he would support the
motion.
The vote was then taken, and the motion to eliminate the mandatory fee of
$.35 for Michigan Collegiate Coalition was approved unanimously.
Michigan Student Assembly Fee for 1992-93. Regent Waters moved to set
the 1992-93 fee assessment for MSA at $6.27 per student per term. Regent
McFee seconded the motion.
Regent Brown noted that students themselves had voted to maintain the fee
at $6.27. Regent Baker reviewed the recent history of MSA elections and noted
that the MSA representatives speaking in favor of an increased fee were of a
different political persuasion than the majority of the assembly.
Regent Power stated that he agreed with Regent Brown's concern about
going against the referendum approving the capped rate. He also stated his
opinion that Regents should not get involved in student partisan political activity.
Regent Power also pointed out that the proposal advocating the increased fee


-343 -



June Meeting, 1992


had budgeted the increase to be applied only to Student Legal Services, not for
other MSA operations.
Regent McFee said that she would support the motion, and observed that if
the current motion passes, MSA would still be able to support MCC out of its
current budget. She also expressed a desire to strengthen student government
and develop better communication with it She asked Vice President Hartford to
continue meeting with student government leaders in developing and evaluating
their budget process. She pointed out that the Regents are not adversaries; they
are overseers attempting through whatever means possible to strengthen and
encourage student government so that it becomes a learning experience similar
to that of other experiences they have while they are here.
Following further discussion, Regent Nielsen observed that the referendum
approved by the students appears to state that the students themselves have the
power to determine what fees they will pay, regardless of decisions made by the
Regents. Regent Nielsen then suggested that because of the historical financial
mismanagement and lack of accountability, and reluctance of student organizations to improve oversight of their financial affairs, Regent Waters' motion be
amended to require the MSA executive officers to work with the director of
University audits to develop acceptable accounting procedures. The proposal for
doing so would have to be submitted to the Regents within six months; if this
were not done, the student fee for the winter term would not be implemented.
Regent Waters did not accept this as a friendly amendment. Regent Brown
pointed out that the type of financial oversight suggested by Regent Nielsen is
already in place. Regent Power agreed, and noted that the issue now involves
cooperation between the student organizations and the audit, which is normally
dealt with in a report by the auditor to the audit committee. That is why he had
suggested earlier that Vice President Hartford consult with others and report to
the board about how best to achieve this outcome. President Duderstadt
responded this could be done in the fall.
The vote was then taken on Regent Waters' motion to set 1992-93 MSA fees
at $6.27 per student per term; it carried unanimously.
There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned. The next
meeting is scheduled on July 16-17, 1992. Regents' transportation, accommodation, telephone, and miscellaneous expenses for the month of May 1992 totalled
$2,893.08.
